reviews.reviewTitle: Great at first and then started to dissapoint
reviews.reviewText:
=== 1 YEAR OF OWNERSHIP REVIEW ===
I've now owned this grinder for a little less than a year, and I'm sad to say that it has not lived up to my initial impressions. The quality that I initially perceived is just not there with this product. There are three reasons that I'd like to go over to justify why I am adjusting my original 5 star review down to a 2 star review.

Reason 1: After just a month or two the grinder started making a buzzing noise when plugged in to the wall outlet, but powered off. The buzzing is not obnoxiously loud, but was loud enough to make me wander around my around my apartment searching for where the strange noise was coming from. I contacted OXO about the problem and they acknowledged that there are issues with this model starting to buzz over time. I was assured it would not impact the performance (which is hasn't) and that they would contact me when a replacement was available with the issue resolved. It has been several months and I still have not heard anything from them sadly. For now I just keep it unplugged on my counter and plug it in every time I go to use it.

Reason 2: The grinder now suddenly stops on it's own before the timer is done. In order to resume grinding I need to push down on the bean hopper. When the hopper is locked in place it presses down on a switch (a safety thing I presume) which allows it to start grinding, but even when locked in place the hopper does not sit flush in place and one edge of the hopper is raised up. Now whenever I use this grinder I have to stand over it and push down on the hopper until it is done.

Reason 3: This one is by far my biggest annoyance. The grinder no longer ejects all the ground coffee! If I put in 20g of beans, I will get about 16g ejected into the container. In order to get the remaining 4g of coffee out I have to give the grinder a good shake and run it again. I thought this might be happening due to it being clogged internally, so I pulled things out and cleaned everything very well, but it still happens.

=== ORIGINAL REVIEW ===
First I must say that I am thrilled to be the first reviewer of this product that didn't receive it for free. Well, I'm not thrilled that apparently everyone except me is getting free stuff, but I digress. Anyways due to the overwhelming amount of "received this product for free" reviews I will say that I was very hesitant to purchase this grinder since I was skeptical of fake reviews.

In my case it was finally time to upgrade from my Hario Skerton hand crank grinder (which is awful and never produced a consistent grind. A medium setting would produce fine dust and huge 1/4 pieces of beans. I don't know why people give it so much praise to be honest). I took a look all the big name grinders and a ton of the knockoffs that are available here on Amazon as well. I settled on this one because I have owned a few OXO products in the past and despite them being a little on the pricier side I'm always very happy with their build quality and design.

I'm happy to say that this OXO Conical Burr Coffee Grinder is no exception to that! The quality is fantastic and I knew it was well built the moment I took it out of the box. Setting it up was a breeze and I was pleasantly surprised at how quiet this grinder is. It has a small footprint and fits well on my kitchen counter. The grind it produces is consistent whether you select fine, coarse, or anywhere in between. So far I have made coffee using a French Press, an Aeropress, and my new V60. All three turned out significantly better than the cups I was getting from my old hand grinder. If you're looking for a quality burr grinder that doesn't sound like a shop-vac I would definitely recommend this one.

reviews.reviewTitle: No static and good grind quality
reviews.reviewText:
I've owned two conical burr grinders in the $100 price range and they both make a big mess while grinding because of the static electricity they generate. The designers of the OXO completely eliminated the static problem by incorporating three design features: a metal grounds bin, a grounded power plug, and a lower motor RPM.

There is a little metal tab at the top of the bay that the grounds bin slides into which connects the metal bin to the ground prong on the 3-prong power plug. This grounds the metal bin giving the static electricity a path to dissipate to.

I know the motor speed is slower than my previous grinders because it takes almost 30 seconds to grind the 60 grams of coffee I need to brew a pot. Not only does the lower RPM help to minimize static, but improves the quality of the grind. There are far fewer fines in the medium and coarse grind settings I use. The slower RPM also keeps the metal burrs from heating up as much and it lowers the noise level.

This grinder gets a solid five stars.

UPDATE 9/3/18: I'm still very happy the grind quality. In doing a little more research, I've found that this grinder has 40mm burrs and runs at 400rpm which matches the specs of the highly rated $230 Baratza Virtuoso.

(I am an ex professional barista.)

CONS:

-The grounds container doesn't lock into place and will sometimes vibrate out during grinding. This is the only serious flaw with the product, and I feel it's a minor one. I've gone through many of the reviews and it seems that it's simply a matter of construction inconsistency. Most people's containers "click" into place; a minority do not. I was just unlucky enough to get one of the ones that don't.

-You can't remove the bottom burr to clean it. They really did do their best to make this easy to clean and I appreciate that you don't have to undo a bunch of microscopic screws just to clean your burrs, but I really wish I could remove BOTH burrs to give them a thorough wipe-down. It's difficult to clean the one that's stuck inside the grinder. The other lifts out easily by a cute little handle.

PROS:

-High quality, consistent grind. The brewing methods I use most all hover around the medium grind range, so I haven't really tested the extremes of coarse and fine. Can't speak to those. But as far as the medium ranges, it grinds beautifully and consistently. That's what matters in the end, right?

-The beans feed very well, even for single dosing. Never an issue.

-As mentioned above, the ability to clean the grinder is taken into account in the construction. No need to delicately deconstruct the whole thing and keep track of a bunch of itty bitty screws and springs. The top part of the grinder and the top burr simply turn-and-lift out, and then turn-and-lock back into place. So nice.

-It's aesthetically pleasing and takes up little room on the counter. All the materials have a quality feel.

-It isn't super noisy. All grinders are gonna make noise, to be sure, but as far as grinders go, this one has a pretty gentle sound. I've definitely used my fair share of grinders that made me feel like my brain was going to vibrate out of my skull, and this one has a polite hum by comparison.

-The price for this level of quality is unbeatable. I can't even believe I paid less than one hundred dollars for this. Real talk, folks: these are steel conical burrs. Solid construction. 40+ grind settings. Did I mention steel conical burrs? I never thought I would own something like this for less than $250. You cannot beat this price point/quality intersection. You just can't. This grinder is price-meets-quality king.

USAGE:

You're working with three variables: time, grind, and amount. There are two popular approaches to working out your dose.

Method 1: You leave 'amount' as the open variable. With this method, you dump all your beans in the hopper and store them there. You then adjust grind and time until you're getting the right dose at the right grind level.

Method 2: You leave 'time' as the open variable. With this method, you only deposit the amount of beans you plan to use for each dose, adjust the grind as needed, and let it take whatever amount of time it takes. You're adjusting the amount and the grind, rather than adjusting the grind and the time. (This is called "single dosing.")

Go to any coffee forum, and you'll be pages of debate about which of these methods is superior. Honestly, you should use the method that feels best for YOU.

The reason I bring it up here is because people seem anxious that Method #2 will damage the burrs over time, since you run them all the way to empty every time you grind.

Here's my take: I use Method #2, because I feel that the beans start to taste stale if left in the hopper. (Everyone's tastebuds are different; there's no right or wrong.) This means that I let the burrs run until I hear the sound change from a low growl to a high pitched growl, which indicates that the burrs are grinding empty, and then I manually stop the grind.

I honestly don't see any issue with this, and I don't feel any anxiety about it. Think about it: if you're cleaning the burrs between bean swaps, you're letting them run for several seconds on empty anyway. Even the manufacturer instructions tell you to do this when cleaning the burrs! The only difference here is that instead of intentionally running them on empty for several seconds to clean them, you're running them on empty for one single second every day/dose. I'd never recommend doing that on a fine espresso setting, but as long as you're in the medium-to-coarse range, I don't see any possible ways the burrs could damage each other. There's no way the burrs are touching at that distance, regardless of variables like heat expanding the metal and other things coffee nerds like to debate about.

I hope this review was helpful. I'll update in a year to let you know if this grinder held up through daily use.

I generally find this coffee grinder appealing.
First, the stainless steel cup that locks into place during grinding. My previous grinder's cup would slowly vibrate out, causing ground coffee to fill up behind it, requiring clean up. That was resolved by wrapping a rubber band around the unit to hold the cup in place. No more rubber band with this OXO grinder.
Second, the timer preset is very handy and helps to consistently grinder the desired amount of coffee.
Third, the overall dimensions, look and feel complement our kitchen.

So, with all of this why only three stars? My sole gripe with this unit is I cannot leave it unattended during grinding because it always fails to consistently feed beans down into the grinder. They get hung up for some reason and I have to shake or whack the unity to get the beans to continue to feed. This happens consistently and wasn't a problem with the older Capresso unit it replaced. But, again, I passed on Capresso this time because the cup would not stay in place during grinding.

I'm a coffee lover, and enjoy lighter roast beans with coffee made using French presses. I really enjoy using coffee grinders to get the freshest flavor from my coffee beans.

I considered a number of different grinders, but I went with this one because it seemed simpler to operate, and there were a number of design features that drew me to it. Plus, OXO's older grinder seemed to get decent reviews.

- This grinder is pretty quiet and quick to operate. I use the 12 grind setting, and leave the timer for 7 seconds and I get the perfect amount for 16 oz of water. I've been consistently getting the same amount of grounds every time.

- The construction of the stainless steel removable burr with the plastic seems solid. I've seen other grinders with the burr in plastic housings that seem like they would fall apart after long term use. This grinder seems solid, but time will tell!

- The chute and grounds cup does not leave grounds falling everywhere, nor is there a bunch of static, so I think this part is well-designed.

- The footprint and overall size is pretty compact and the design is pretty clean and should fit in most kitchens.

reviews.reviewTitle: The secret to the great un-clog
reviews.reviewText:
I almost returned this thing after about two days of use; it had completely stopped working due to an internal clog, and the included de-clogging instructions were useless. However, with a little experimentation, I found a method that works reliably, and without as much fuss as I'd expected.

1) Empty any remaining beans from the hopper into another container and set aside. Set the hopper aside as well, but empty; you'll need it again soon. Set aside the grounds bin as well, also empty.

2) Remove the top burr grinder piece (its handle rotates up, and then you can twist it out) and set aside.

3) Dump remaining loose coffee bits from around the burr grinder at the top of the machine into your separate container (just like from the hopper) and set that container aside. You won't need it again until after you're finished de-clogging.

4) UNPLUG the machine. and get ready to make a bit of a mess (these next few steps are worth doing over a sink if you can, in order to reduce clean-up).

5) Using a soft, non-metal utensil so as not to damage the burrs (I had a soft plastic lab pipette nearby which was perfect), gently scrape out any packed coffee grounds from around the bottom burr grinder on top of the machine. You won't get it all on the first attempt, just get what's easy.

6) Using the same or similar utensil, poke up into the chute that coffee grounds normally come out of. Dislodge as much of the packed grounds as you can, then shake gently so that the stragglers will fall out.

7) Taking the grinder back to its usual home, plug it back in and replace the bean hopper and the grounds bin but NOT the top burr grinder piece.

8) Run the grinder like this, in short (5 second) bursts until grinds stop coming out.

9) Remove the hopper and bin, then follow cleaning steps 4-8 once more. By the time you've done that second run, the machine should be mostly de-clogged.

10) Scrape any caked-on coffee grounds from the top bur grinder, and put it back where it belongs (you'll need to remove the hopper to get access).

11) Run one or two 5-second bursts to make sure everything's worked its way out, but your grinder should now be ready to use. Return your container of beans and bits to the hopper and grind away!

How does this thing get clogged in the first place? I was trying to grind enough coffee to fill a container to take to work, and the lid on top of this grinder's grounds bin does not provide a good view into the bin. When the grounds pile up to high, the machine backs up and will just keep compressing grounds together inside until it's totally jammed.

Having learned my lesson, I now take the lid off the grounds bin whenever I need to grind more than a single pot's coffee. This puts me at a slightly higher risk of mess, but the grounds don't shoot out badly and I can see when i need to dump the bin out into another container.

reviews.reviewTitle: Doesn't grind enough beans for a pot of coffee
reviews.reviewText: The grinder only selects grinding based on time - not on the number of desired cups like many grinders. While this is easy to calibrate to your liking, the grinder only grinds to 30 seconds. When we ground coffee, this was only enough for about 6 cups of coffee. So in order to brew a full pot of coffee, we would have to grind the beans, wait, then grind again - to get enough grounds to brew a full pot. Additionally, the hopper on our grinder seemed to slip out of place, even when in use. This problem is exacerbated by the fact that the hopper doesn't need to be in place for grinding to occur. So if the hopper becomes dislodged, the grinder keeps on grinding - all over the counter top.

Update 2: After using this a little longer, and reading reviews on many other grinders (considering replacement), I have decided to restore one star, because other than the failure to feed, which seems to happen with lots of grinders, this grinder really works well. What I started doing is stirring the beans in the hopper with a chopstick as I grind, and that cures the failure to feed, and gives a very consistent 24 grams of (full coarse) grinds on the "10" setting, which is slightly higher than I earlier reported.

Update 1: I have now had consistent problems with the beans feeding, so I am deducting two stars. I think this grinder may be a victim of its own smoothness--they should have built some vibration into the feeder to help the beans go down. I love the grinder operation, but having to push the beans down, and then figure out how much coffee was already ground (because it will often partial grind), is a real pain. Might just give up and go back to hand grinding!

Original Review:

I had previously 'upgraded' from a hand grinder to a cheap electric burr grinder (Bellermain), but was not happy with it--the Bellermain unit was very loud, produced a very inconsistent grind (lots of fine material even on the coarsest setting), and, worst of all, very messy--the design resulted in grounds outside of the cup as well as sticking to the cup and getting all over when poured. I saw this on the "Prime Day Launch" page, and decided to order one, as it appeared to address all my concerns.

I've only been using it for a few days now, but it is very quiet, grinds very consistently, and the grinds pour easily and cleanly from the cup. I have had two occurrences where it failed to grind--the beans were clumped a bit, and failed to feed--I'm currently using the Rwandan blend from the local club warehouse, which is reasonably oily, so this may or may not be an issue with other blends. A quick tap of the unit frees the beans to grind--does not seem to be an issue once it starts feeding--only when first started after sitting. I considered taking off a star for this, and may do that if I continue to have problems.

(This section updated to reflect the slightly increased output I am seeing when stirring the beans to get them to feed.) On full coarse, I am getting about 2.4 grams per 'number' on the dial: dial set to 10 yields about 24 grams, etc. Seems like most recommend 7-10 grams of coffee per 6 ounce of water--I like to make mine at about 8 grams/6 oz, and I make about 18 ounces at a time, so I have the grinder set to 10. An easy way to estimate for your needs is: dial setting x2, plus 20 percent (e.g., dial at 15 x 2 = 30 + 6 = 36 grams)--this is for coarse setting--I have not experimented with the other settings, since I only make French Press.

reviews.reviewTitle: Now worth buying a total waste of money.
reviews.reviewText: I bought this burr grinder August 21 and it now went belly up Nov 21. It just stopped working. I am very upset.

reviews.reviewTitle: Solid build, luxurious feel, quiet operation.
reviews.reviewText:
I am really happy with this purchase. As with all coffee brewing appliances/tools, there are a few important things to consider when purchasing a coffee grinder. This grinder hits many of those important items, and for the price, it's a grinder you will feel good about. I have used many coffee grinders over the years, worked in coffee shops for 8 years, and this one made me smile from the second I unboxed it to when I turned it on.

What you need to know:
Really solid build quality that feels high-end. The conical burrs are powerful (DC) and are a feature found only in the best grinders.
Quiet operation, as far as coffee grinders go. Definitely one of the quietest I have used.
Simple functions that are easy to use. Set your desired grind, set for how long, and push to start. The doubly expensive older brother to this grinder (OXO 8710200 On Conical Burr Coffee Grinder with Integrated Scale) has some additional features, but I don't think they justify the $200 price tag. You can buy a digital scale for less than $10.
Speaking of features, this one has a couple I like - UV protected hopper so you can keep beans up top and overheat protection so as not to burn your beans.

I know this is a new product, of which I would normally be wary, but the solid build and luxurious feel of the grinder along with its quiet operation make me truly happy with this grinder so far.

The reviews suggested this was a very good grinder. Initially it was. But soon the feeding of the beans into the grinder began slowing down and I would need to tap the entire grinder to get it going again. Finally, it simply stopped feeding the beans. Cleaning out coffee beans and grinds did not fix this. Due to Amazon's superb return policy, that is what I did. I did not reorder.

This is a great grinder. I did a lot of research before buying and then this product launched right around the time I was gonna buy one. Has very low static cling and seems to be related to other factors as I had none for the first month. I have disassembled it twice for a deep clean but it’s nt really necessary. I feel that many of you reviewers have unrealistic expectations of a grinder. I was a barista for years and used high end commercial grinders that had the same issues you’re complaining about. This unit is excellent and a great value for $99.

If you’re shopping around just buy this one. Add a decent brush and play around with the grind settings until you find the one you like.
What did I like or dislike? I dislike that it stopped grinding coffee after 30 days. We grind enough for a single pot daily, not exactly heavy use... Hope they don't hassle me on the return.

This is a strange grinder in my opinion.
CON: While it grinds well, deciphering choices is a learning experience - too steep a curve for my patience. Control for SIZE of grind has to be tried a few times to find your preference - not unlike any grinder. But the other control I feel is a very obscure dial for determining how LONG to grind - that is HOW MUCH coffee one wants ground! My other grinder that was too messy has a more sensible control for number of cups. I could easily "gestimate" what amount of water to match to it's cup designation. But now I need to estimate based on how long the machine is on - IN SECONDS? If you want to grind and then measure by scoop what you want, not having a problem of leaving some ground in the container until net time - it might work for you. I want to grind only what I use for the pot of coffee I am about to prepare.
PRO: Other grinders I've used are messy because of static buildup. The ground coffee easily slips out without a mess. This grinder has a nice slim profile on my kitchen appliance crowded counter.

reviews.reviewTitle: clogs up after two weeks, twice
reviews.reviewText: We loved this. It was working wonderfully. Then, the ground coffee stopped flowing. The chute where the coffee comes out is packed with grounds, but they are not getting pushed through. Nothing is falling into the cup. Took it apart cleaned all parts out (lost a lot of coffee in the process), put it back together, plugged it in. Nothing. Amazon customer service is amazing.. they sent me a replacement in 1 day. Same patter. Both are going back and my husband is left with no Christmas gift :( .

This product replaces an old Cuisinart grinder I have been using for many years. I kept it only because I didn't think I could find a better one at a reasonable price. I finally had it with coffee grounds flying all over the place and splurged for the OXO grinder. It is twice the cost of the Cuisinart, but worth every penny. This grinder is so quiet. The grind is so much more consistent. The best part is the stainless steel container. No more dancing coffee grounds. Just grind and dump the ground coffee into the basket with no fear. The unit looks great and fits on the counter as if it belongs there. I have always trusted OXO products and the coffee grinder is no exception.

reviews.reviewTitle: Even after single use, I like this grinder better than Cuisinart DBM-8!
reviews.reviewText:
UPDATE 09/08/2018: After having used this Oxo grinder for a few days now, I love it even more and wanted to add a couple of things to my original review. First, I may have been mistaken when I said the grinds container clicked into place. I think I may not have had the top completely on, and what I heard was the top clicking down. Still, I have not had any trouble with it moving out of place. I did press the little metal tab back, though I did not actually bend it or anything.

Second, I am more impressed with the grind. As I mentioned below, the grind is very uniform and produces MUCH less find powder. This is obvious to me in two ways. The Cuisinart sort of spews the grinds out a vertical opening and into the grinds container through a matching opening in the side of the container. In the process, a large deposit of powder builds up in one corner of the container. The Oxo drops the grinds straight down into the grinds container, seemingly more gently. There is no buildup anywhere and no obvious powder. The other thing I have noticed is that there is VERY little sludge at the bottom of my cup. I make my coffee in re-usable K-cups (I know, I know - Coffee heresy!) These are great, but, unlike paper filters, re-usable filters let through some of the very fine grounds. Coffee ground with the Cuisinart grinder, with its significant amount of powder, would leave a considerable amount of sludge. I would toss out about 1/4" of coffee to avoid drinking it. I have purposely drunk down to the last drop with the new grinder and found only a few drops of sludge.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
I purchased the less expensive Cuisinart just over a year ago as a test to see if I really wanted to grind my own coffee on a regular basis. I have used it regularly ever since but was not entirely happy with it. When this Oxo came out on Prime Day it sounded like just what I wanted, but I waited a couple of months to get some real reviews, which continued to be very positive so I decided to take the leap. Just received it today, but I already like it better than the Cuisinart. It is noticeably quieter, grinds much more consistently, and does not produce powdery "fines" like the Cuisinart. Also, the stainless grounds container does not produce static cling like the Cuisinart's plastic container.
Although at first the grounds container did not seem to click into place as it should, it did after a couple of tries. This failure to lock in seems to be a consistent complaint in reviews of this grinder so I will be keeping an eye on it.

I figure it will take a day or two to dial in just the ground size I like and appropriate grind time for my needs, but those are just a matter of mechanics. I can already tell that I will be able to use a grind finer than I was able to use with the Cuisinart. Because the grind was less consistent the setting I used included everything from chunks to powder. The Oxo produces very consistent size grind.

The Cuisinart was so loud (much louder than I thought a burr grinder should produce) that if I needed to grind in the morning I had to wrap the grinder in a very heavy blanket to cut the noise and avoid waking my wife. I feel pretty sure that the much lower volume level of the Oxo will not require such precautions.

All in all, I consider this a great upgrade from the Cuisinart DBM-8.

update:
Thought I would throw my 2 cents in on a couple of common complaints: 1) Hum when left plugged in. My does not, if your's does, then you have a defect and exchange it. 2) The cup for the grounds does not 'click' into place. I can't replicate that problem, I tried but I can't snug it into position without it locking in. Try removing the cup and then press your thumb against the top of the wall, you should feel a flexible tab, if it doesn't flex (stuck into position) then it may just be a matter of lifting the grinder and visually inspecting and un-stick the tab..

I bought the OXO because it is highly recommended by Consumer Reports. It arrived today and I will primarily use it for espresso. I ran an espresso grind to use this morning and then ran a test run at a medium (Drip) grind. In both cases the grinds were perfectly evenly ground and sized consistent with the settings. It is quite, has a very good quality 'feel' to it, very easy to use with everything working smoothly and as should (no problem 'clicking' the holder in position as some have reported), and is very attractive with a small counter-top footprint. It is a very straightforward efficient design so I see no reason to believe it will not be reliable. It is well worth the $100 price tag, don't waste your time and money buying cheaper brands.

I don't review the Amazon products but I have to review this product for the future development and improvements of Oxo company. Not sure about how the company designs, develops and validates the new product but definitely there is some gap in this product. When I grind coffee beans, coffee grinding mechanism is not reliable and stable in terms of keeping jammed and stuck that every time I have to clean the inside burr and somehow it doesn't give out the grinded coffee due to the pressed coffee attached to the path to output cup (small output but a lot of pressed coffee). It blocks the passage to the output cup. In my opinion, this is design defect. I just asked the refund.

reviews.reviewTitle: Update: Suspicious electrical buzzing noise coming from grinder
reviews.reviewText:
This is the first conical burr grinder I've owned, so don't know how it compares to others. I do really like several things about it:

1. Super easy to use. Load the beans in the top, and turn a dial to select a wide range of grind sizes. Select the number of seconds to grind and press a large button to start.
2. It's fun to watch the beans disappear into the grinder!
3. You can load the bean hopper up with a bunch of beans, but control how many are ground by selecting the time to grind

There's only one thing I don't care for and wish that Oxo would improve: It's quite loud. How about spending a few pennies and adding some sound deadening material to the inside of the unit, Oxo? It's also pricey, considering what it is...just grinding some coffee beans. This replaces a $13 blade grinder I used for years. Yes, I understand the difference in grind consistency with blade grinders vs. conical burr grinders. Time will tell if it holds up and makes it worth the extra cost. For now, I really like it.

UPDATE 10/1/18:
I have been noticing a buzzing noise in the kitchen lately. I traced it to the OXO burr grinder. We have multiple appliances plugged in at all times: a toaster oven, a regular toaster, an electric teapot, a Keurig, and an iCoffee machine (we have a big kitchen and often have guests!), and none of these appliances makes electrical buzzing noises when not in use. Anytime a small simple appliance like this makes a buzzing noise I am very concerned. There shouldn't be any noise coming from it, except when it's in use, and now I'm concerned about the safety. I'm not leaving it plugged in....will plug in when I need to use it until I can get a response from manufacturer, or possibly a replacement.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice grinder, but there is a design flaw.
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this to replace our grinder that finally gave out after three years and three cross country moves. This grinder is looks good, and it offers a very consistent grind. On grind setting one the beans are ground into a near silica like dust for a perfect Turkish style coffee, and at setting 15 it is nice and course for a French press or cold brew. It is extremely quiet as well, at least compared to our old grinder. The hopper feeds the beans consistently, however I have noted that it favors feeding from the back of the hopper, so if you're low on beans in the hopper you may have to make adjustments during the grind.

The issue I have with the grinder is the "L" feed shoot from the burrs to the catch container. When doing fine grind (between 1 and 6) the coffee will pack in there like flour even with routine weekly cleaning. This clogs the feed chute up pretty quickly and results in having to disassemble the unit and shove a flexible plastic straw inside to break the clog apart. I've tried beans with different oils and roast levels (as dark roasts tend to be more oily) and no luck. We live in San Antonio, so it's not overly humid and I buy my beans from a reputable local roasting company. I've never experienced this issue with a coffee grinder before, but I've never seen an almost 90 degree bend in the feed shoot as well. Because of this, we've had to switch from weekly to daily cleaning of the grinder, which is a bit of an added hassle with both of us working, plus two kids and extracurriculars and our normal house work, which is why I'm giving it 2 stars.

reviews.reviewTitle: When the grinder was not in use but still plugged in there was an electrical hum coming from the motor like a transformer hum
reviews.reviewText: I expected and got a reasonably decent burr grinder with one major exception. When the grinder was not in use but still plugged in there was an electrical hum coming from the motor like a transformer hum. It was audible and annoying. I sent it back and bought a Capresso for about the same price. I have had burr grinders of different makes for at least 25 years and never had this problem.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very messy and the noise is horrible.
reviews.reviewText:
I have the Oxo coffee maker so I bought this as a replacement for a Delonghi grinder to compliment the coffee maker. I don't notice any significant difference in the taste of my coffee but the noise that this machine makes is awful first thing in the morning. It is a very high pitched squeal. It also makes such a mess on the counter which I would expect to a certain extent but it's much messier than the delonghi. The grind setting is in seconds rather than cups which takes a bit of getting used to and although the grind seems consistent I wouldn't recommend the product.
Edit; downgraded to 1 star. It keeps getting clogged so I have to empty it out, take it apart and clean the whole unit at least once a week. I really don’t recommend this grinder. I’m annoyed at myself for believing all of the reviews by people who got it for free. Lesson learned.

I've been using this grinder since October 2018.
I also have used the Breville BCG800XL Smart Grinder and the
Capresso 560.01 Infinity Conical Burr.
The OXO is by far the best of the three.
I've had the Breville for several years and the impeller wore out in it. The biggest complaint other than the impeller wearing out, was it clogged up frequently. It ground coffee quite well, and didn't create a big mess.
The Capresso I've had for many years. It's my go to grinder when others fail. All the lettering has wore off but still grinds coffee. My biggest complaint is the mess it makes as coffee goes everywhere because of static it generates when grinding coffee.
The OXO on the other hand, hasn't jammed up once since October. The timer (although not digital) is consistent, just like the Breville's digital timer, and there is not static mess when grinding coffee. I have used the same coffee in all three machines, so the static mess is dependent on the grinder not the coffee.

This seems to be standing up to the test of time. This grinder produces a very consistent grind every single time. The many grind settings will take you from a very very fine powder to very coarse grounds. The small adjustments allows the user to fine tune to thier specific needs. I like that it isn't terribly loud and doesn't take up much counter space.

Update 02-11-19
Well I wrote my initial review too soon. The power button no longer works and if I am able to get it to switch on it will only stay on for a few seconds at a time. I didn't even get a year out of it. Far too expensive for 8 months of use... I will update again If the company resolves it quickly.

Update 04-12-19
I contacted OXO regarding the filing of a warranty claim and while they were willing to help, I was very discouraged by the return process and timeline. I decided to disassemble and clean then using compressed air blow out the button assembly. It seems to work fine now. I think fine powder is building up in the switch assembly and interfering with the contacts. I will see if I can continue to nurse it along this way.

To begin with , It's OXO and I 've never had any problems with their products. This looks good, does the job soooo much better than my spice grinder and is easy to clean. Set the grind, push the button ...done. Good job OXO...
EDIT..After 2-3 uses, timer function has ceased to operate having to hold button in every 2 seconds to get a grind. However, tech support was fabulous with a replacement being sent out. Another "However," is that in the course of looking for a Users Guide, I found the same grinder on another site for $30 less. That's quite a difference Amazon...Addendum..have used the new grinder twice and it has ceased to function. Return is turning out to be hell also...

I did a lot of research before choosing this to replace my old mill grinder. I was a little nervous to spend so much on something that just grinds coffee. I mean... could it really make that much of a difference? Would it be worth it? I was pleasantly surprised! The consistency of the grind for my pour-over was perfect - SO much better than the inconsistant grind I was getting from my old machine. My morning cup of Joe is better than ever!
I was also concerned that it would be noisy, but compared to my old mill grinder, it's really quiet. :-) It's easy to use, too. I simply pour in the amount of beans I want, set the grind # for the kind of coffee I'm preparing, set the timer (it usually takes about 20 seconds for the amount I use) and, voila! It auto-magically appears in the metal cup, which really does help with the static issue so many products have. BTW, inserting the cup doesn't really make a clicking sound. I just gently push it in until it feels snug. And, if I feel that it didn't grind all the beans in the allotted time I just push the timer again until the grinder makes a high-pitched sound, which lets me know all the beans are through.
The quality is great... I feel like it will last a long time. And, it's rather attractive. If machines could talk to one another this one would probably turn some heads: "Hey Yo, OXO! You're the queen of burr... lookin' good!"
All to say, I'm very happy with my purchase. Thanks OXO. You've made my life a little easier!

reviews.reviewTitle: if zero were possible...that is what I would give it.
reviews.reviewText: this piece of crap needs to be cleaned after almost every batch. I have taken it apart to try and find the culpret...only to find a bean where it should not be.. DONE!

I love my other OXO products. However, this coffee grinder is a bummer. Nice looking and well built. However, the beans don't feed evenly, often getting jammed. As such, you have to babysit the grinder while it works, shaking it every time it stops feeding. Moreover, since it doesn't feed consistently, the amount of ground coffee varies from batch to batch. I wish I has sprung for the more expensive grinder with the built in scale. Even with OXO, you get what you pay for.

reviews.reviewTitle: It’s quiet, but it clogs especially in fine grind!
reviews.reviewText: What I like about this grinder is the quiet operation, our last grinder a Cuisinart was so loud that it literally sounded like a jet plane taking off. What I dislike is how often it clogs, especially in fine mode. We’ve pretty much resorted to the largest grind possible because it was literally clogging with each use & what a hassle it was to take the beans out & clean it each time. It still clogs a few times a week on course grind, I guess we will sacrifice that for how quiet the operation is.

reviews.reviewTitle: Virtually perfect in design and functionality.
reviews.reviewText:
Preface: I use the grinder for espresso beans (oily and at the finest grind). Unbelievably easier to clean. Do use aerosol can of pressurized air to clean out the delivery tube from above--can't do it from outside. Timer makes it so easy to multitask. Drawback is cannot grind any large volume of beans at once. Motor is controlled to shut down when overheated as a large volume of beans (very fine grind) is ground. Will restart. Stainless grind receptacle is perfect: no static cling and fine grinds pour out even when using very oily beans. Two corners on cup facilitate pouting into narrow openings for brewing. Two heaping measuring cups of beans uses 75% of time on timer; again at finest grind.
Light weight and easily moved around. Again, compared to the very expensive grinder I've used in the past this is so easy to use and clean.

reviews.reviewTitle: BEWARE! THESE ARE KNOWN TO BE DEFECTIVE!!
reviews.reviewText:
I bought a "used" one from Amazon Warehouse, but it was new with stickers attached and all paperwork etc.
Didn’t look like it had ever been out of the box.

First time I used it there were coffee grounds EVERYWHERE due to static electricity - and that was from just one partial hopper of beans. While emptying the container the grounds "jumped" and stuck to the lid, outside of can, countertop and outside of grinder body. It made a huge mess and I was annoyed. I was ready to send it back after one use but decided to call the company first.

An OXO rep said they didn’t know why some folks experienced this static problem while others did not. She said one employee has the same problem at her house but she remedied the problem by wiping the outside of the grounds container with a paper towel before she used it. They think it may be caused by atmospheric pressure or level of humidity in the air. This explanation sounded like BS to me - only ONE employee has troublesome pressure and/or humidity at their home? Do they live on a mountaintop in Arizona?

Several days later I opened a new bag of coffee just to test the grinder even though I had plenty of ground coffee left. I wiped the outside of the can with a paper towel and wondered how a dry towel could have any affect - seemed like it would make the problem WORSE. It didn’t help.

I called OXO again and was told she THINKS the towel should be damp, but she couldn’t really explain where to use it. Was I supposed to wipe just the inside of the can? Inside & outside? Inside the hopper? Outside of machine? She didn’t know and I wasn’t about to perform the entire ritual before every use!

I used a damp towel on the inside/outside of the container and lid and that seemed to help.
But a new issue arose when I found that the container would not stay in place under the chute and kept sliding toward the front of the machine.

Another call to OXO.
They’re aware of this problem and have designed a new container which is supposed to stay in place. I was asked if I would like one and I replied "absolutely." Well, they don’t have any available and don’t know when they will, but "will send me one when they come in." That was TWO MONTHS AGO and I’ve never received one.

One reviewer claimed this unit has no static problems because the metal cup contacts a metal tab behind the chute which allows static electricity to dissipate out through the grounded cord. That’s completely useless when vibration causes the cup to slide away from the tab after a few seconds.

During that call I mentioned that many reviewers have reported another defect - a humming sound from the unit. The rep said OXO engineers are aware of the issue and have already determined the cause. New units will be manufactured that correct the issue, but no release date had been set.

I asked if I could exchange mine when they come out and was told "yes, as long as I bought my unit new from an OXO distributor." Since my unit was sold as a "used" unit, it would not be eligible for exchange.

I had no choice but to return my unit to Amazon before the return period closed. I was surprised at the amount of coffee trapped in the burrs as I cleaned it before sending back, not sure that’s a problem or not
.
What a waste of time and cause of aggravation this machine was!

On a positive note: It’s fairly heavy and feels rugged.
It’s quieter than my cheap B&D grinder (as it should be for $100!), quiet enough to use at night without fear of disturbing those in neighboring apartments.

reviews.reviewTitle: Spend the extra money! You won't be sorry.
reviews.reviewText: I just received my OXO coffee grinder yesterday. Arrived a day early which was much appreciated....need the coffee every day! I replaced a two year old Cuisinart model that died. With the Cuisinart I was constantly fighting static electricity. I even lined the collection bin with aluminum foil to try to eliminate the static. No luck. The unit did not grind evenly either. There was always significant powdered coffee mixed with my coarse grind that I use for my French Press. Need to either drink the fine powdered coffee or leave the last sip in the coffee mug. I never heard of OXO and was a bit skeptical about spending a hundred bucks for a coffee grinder, but the reviews were good so I bought it. WHAT A DIFFERENCE!!!! No loud noise, no static electricity, all the coffee ground coarsely to perfection. No fine residue requiring cleaning every time. Bottom line, you get a much better product (in this case) when you spend the extra money, Extremely worthwhile as it is something I do first thing in the morning every day. Yet to see how long it will last, but everything about the grinder seems to be very high quality. Spend the extra money and you'll be glad you did.

I’ve had this grinder for 2 weeks and so far it’s been great. I agree with all the good reviews and yes, I had to buy mine too. I’m very impressed with the design and not much mess, which is saying a lot compared to the other 2 grinders I’ve owned. The attached 2 pics is of the informational tag that’s attached to the new grinder which answers some other questions I noticed people have.

I have used this grinder almost daily for the last two months and can definitely say it's the best investment in my coffee-making I've made. The design is sleek and modern. It looks great sitting on a counter in your kitchen. The operation is smooth and very intuitive. Grind size is very consistent and it does both very fine and coarse quite well.

There are two things I would note could be improved here. First, there is a tendency for coffee grinds to collect behind the provided cup beneath the grinding chute. This isn't a big deal, but it does make the operation feel a little less polished. Second, the OXO brand decal on the center of the grind button has started showing signs of wear. This probably wasn't the best placement for a white decal as repeated use wears it down.

Overall, amazing grinder that easily functions better than any I've used for this price range. I wholeheartedly recommend this to the beginner to mid-level coffee enthusiast!

I have used this grinder for a week now and here are my comments.

This is my 3rd bean grinder (actually 4th if you count the hand grinder which was fine for 1 cup of pourover but ridiculous, not to mention hand numbing, to try and grind enough beans for an auto drip coffeemaker). My first purchase was the Cuisinart DBM-8. Nice unit, but ridiculous number of grind settings. You choose the amount by the number of cups (from 4-18). It took a while to get all the settings right but I was happy with it. Although the ground coffee was pretty well contained to the hopper, there was very little on my counter, but when you removed the hopper, there was some left behind on the unit itself, and the grind was not uniform, lots of dust. The biggest problem was static. If you tried to pour out the coffee right after grinding, very little came out. If I let it sit for 15-20 mins some poured out but the bottom 4 corners of the hopper were packed with grounds that had to be removed with a brush. I know the coffee purist adage is to grind the beans just before brewing, but I get up at 4AM and there’s no way I wanted to wait almost half an hour (including brew time) to enjoy a cup of coffee. So I ground the beans the night before and after the static wait and brushing, I put them into a sealed container ready to put in the filter at 4AM. I was happy with that.

After about 3 months, I started looking again and found the Bodum. Their claim was that because they a use borosilicate glass hopper that static was eliminated. Sounded plausible so I tried it. Um, not so fast Bodum. Not only was the static worse, I ended up with ground coffee on my counter. That lasted about 3 days before I sold it on CL for a few bucks less than what I paid to avoid returning it. I made the buyer aware of it’s issues. Back to the Cuisinart for about 2 yrs.

I recently found out that OXO was making a grinder that uses a stainless steel hopper. It has a grounded plug. There is a metal tab that contacts the steel hopper when in place and is supposed to eliminate static. Made sense so I bought it. The unit sells for $99.00 everywhere but when I perused the “more new and used” offers on Amazon, this one was listed as new in original packaging but the packaging was damaged. Knowing how OXO packs their products, I bought it and was not disappointed. The unit was perfect and I saved $16+ in the process.

I unpacked and set it up. I was very skeptical at first. Yes the hopper is stainless but there’s a clear plastic lid that has a very large opening. I thought there was no way grounds wouldn’t fly out but I was wrong. After a week of use, not a speck on the counter. The grind is much more uniform than the Cuisinart and the grind amount is set by time not cups. Much better. There’s still more grind settings that I feel are necessary so I’m still playing around with settings. The static is not totally eliminated but a gentle rap on the hopper lets the grounds pour out after about 5 mins. I will still grind the night before but this one’s a keeper. Good job, OXO. Hope this helps anyone thinking about purchasing it.

reviews.reviewTitle: UPD: Stopped working 5 months (orig: 5 stars, "So far so good")
reviews.reviewText:
easy to use. no problem with the canister staying put as some have mentioned. Really like that you can put in almost 1 lb of coffee beans (it says it holds 3/4 lb). Then grind for about 30 seconds (has a timer; you push and it grinds that long). You can get coffee out using scoop, leaving top of stainless canister on.

Would be nice if it had a top that completely covered the ground coffee canister for storing -- but we use every day so our coffee doesn't sit in it long. Had a small Krups grinder (works just fine) -- but that we're "coffee bean" grinders vs Keurig -- this is much better.

UPDATE 01/19: well---- definitely changed my opinion. HAD loved it. NOW: 5 stars reduced down to 1. It just stopped working, Gets clogged where the ground coffee comes out. Have taken apart unclogged, changed coffee beans (although we have had many many types that were fine), took apart pieces on top. No HELP. I posted on Amazon Community -- and got some good suggestions --- which we had actually already tried --- One said they had same issue and tossed the unit. that's where we are now; it's completely not un-usable. VERY disappointed in the unit -- and with OXO products (which I like). I even emailed OXO (since out of Amazon return period) -- they pretty much said want the community answers said. Got it working a few minutes but button is now not working. B In the meantime, have coffee beans -- but no grinder. Have to start looking again for one.

reviews.reviewTitle: Makes a humming sound when not in use...that's an issue! Look elsewhere for your grinder!
reviews.reviewText: The OXO does a great job grinding coffee beans, seems to work fine, looks nice...BUT after grinding and stopping the OXO emits an electric motor hum after use. This concerned us so we pull the plug after use. I elected to return this unit for a different OXO unit (same model) thinking this was just an issue with this one grinder. WRONG!! The second OXO grinder had the same hum as soon as I plugged it in to electric. Since this one was louder than the first, I returned the second OXO and kept the original OXO, at least for now. We continue to pull the plug when not in use. I would not recommend anyone purchase this product.

Don't buy this it is a piece of junk. I purchased one & it lasted about a month. To thier credit they replaced it but that unit lasted even less time. I use this in my home & it is lightly used. The 4 the time I ground coffee it quit. The same problem... the safety switch quit. Find another product. This one isn't worth the hassle. Save your money.

Got it in Oct 2018, We have a couple of heavy coffee drinkers in the house so we don't grind as needed but we do a couple of 1 quart mason jars at a time. Others have mentioned no static but I find I have to bang the collection cup a few times to get all the coffee unstuck from the sides. Superficial cleaning is easy: remove the bean hopper and pull out the conical burr grinder, clean 'em off and shake out the machine. But it takes considerable effort to get all the packed in grinds and bean pieces out from around the base of the auger which, to the best of my knowledge, is not removable. Finally, after some time, the discharge chute becomes clogged and there is no direct path from the grinding chamber to the outside of the chute to bet a brush or pipe cleaner through there. Consequently, you never get all the debris out and it clogs up faster after that. Now, it's July, 2019 and it's pretty much toast. It dies in the middle of a grind or it just won't start at all. Looking for something more durable though I thought for $100 I was on firm ground(no pun intended). Guess not.

I'm using it for 3 months.
1. The grind is not fine enough for espresso. With some beans you may get lucky, but in general just not good even at finest setting.
2. It accumulates ground coffee somewhere inside. So it may clog completely or just suddenly dump "bonus" stale ground coffee to your bin or counter when it feels like doing this.
3. If you push button while your bin is not completely in you'll have a mess to cleanup.
4. Locking knob for the bean hopper is inside and it is spring loaded. This is what happens when it clogs and you have to remove the hopper - dig through beans inside, find the knob, turn it, it resists, suddenly it gives, spits out bunch of beans out of hopper, at the same time it dumps load of stale ground coffee out of spout and here we are in the decaffeinated morning - cleaning coffee all over counter and kitchen floor.
I think people who designed it drink tea or something else, not coffee - that's for sure.
This thing belongs in recycling.

I have used this grinder in my kitchen at least once a day for over a year. I thought to write a review because I’m about to buy a second one of these for my office.

(And the price dropped from $100 to $80! It was already a good deal before.)

I originally settled on this because I needed to switch to a conical-burr grinder after “burning out” two flat-burr grinders, one Krups and one Capresso. Too much friction over time? Bad luck? Both started to just go bzzzz after 3-6 months.

So I got this Oxo and it has shown zero signs of degradation. Everything I’ve ever owned by Oxo has been a well-built and pleasing-to-use product. I also have two Oxo push-button sealing canisters for storing coffee that are 8+ years old and still work like new.

This grinder has worked great for me, after I figured out the quirks of using it, which took maybe 2 uses. Every grinder is a little different from every other, and they all have quirks.

Quirk 1: when you pour the beans in the hopper, you need to tilt the entire grinder around once or twice to make the beans drop down to the bottom of the funnel. It’s possible I’m not using it exactly as designed - see my note about “single-dosing” and precision below.

Quirk 2: as other reviews have noted, there is an inconsistency in this product manufacturing such that some models randomly have a canister that ‘clicks’ into place and some randomly don’t. Mine doesn’t do the click. =\ but the canister stays in place well enough anyway. Worst-case scenario, you hold it in place for a few seconds while the motor runs. I see a thousand ways the product designers could have more easily solved this problem, but I guess they didn’t ask me.

I “single-dose” my coffee brews, meaning I weigh my beans with a scale, just enough to brew one cup - 22g beans for 350ml water if it’s just me - then dump them in the hopper and grind only that amount per grind. The 22g of beans barely coats the bottom of the hopper; it probably has capacity to hold 300g or more at a time.

If your brewing method is not sensitive to precision, you can ignore this paragraph. Moving on: This grinder has a grind timer, but not a scale. I encourage you to use a kitchen scale alongside this grinder for measuring your beans per each grind. Leaving the hopper always full of beans means relying on this grinder’s timer to measure the quantity of coffee you’re grinding. Think about it: “time duration of beans ground” is more variable than “grams of beans ground,” so if you rely on time rather than weight you will end up grinding too much or too little for how much coffee you plan to make. This is true of any grinder that uses a timer, including this one. And that’s qnot even to mention the freshness factor of storing in hopper vs storing in sealed container. Pre-measuring with a scale, then adding only the measured amount to the hopper for each grind, and letting the timer run its course, removes the imprecision from the equation. As a bonus it gives the burrs a second to self-clean by spinning off the excess chaff once all the beans are done grinding. Amazon sells another pricier Oxo grinder that has a scale attached, but honestly just do yourself a favor and buy a kitchen scale to weigh your beans, because a scale invariably needs cleaning or calibration. And by owning a scale you’ll always make the right amount of spaghetti forever.

This grinder has a 1 to 15 coarseness scale, 15 being the most coarse. I leave it on 11. I am a die-hard paper-filter Chemex user and found that 11 is perfect for me. I have struggled to find a grinder that gets it exactly consistently right day-in day-out, and this one does perfect. I once got a lesson on brewing the perfect cup, from grind to water temp; the 11 setting on this grinder consistently mirrors the grind they demonstrated to me.

So buy this grinder. You owe yourself a good cup of coffee and a bad grinder is too much of an inconvenience to live with.

reviews.reviewTitle: Pretty good, as described...until it died.
reviews.reviewText: Not as quiet as the Capresso 565.05 in zinc body that I gave my brother (quietest I've heard), or the 20+ year old Starbucks Barista (Solis 166), but quieter than the screaming banshee Bodum Antiqua that we also have. This one is very user friendly as described, but a pretty high pitch sound. Static issue seems to be well controlled. I only wish I found out about the $5 paddle wheel fix from Baratza for my old Barista before I ordered this. Had I known how the Baratza company services its products and helped so many people repair their old grinders, I would've ordered a Baratza Encore instead, just to do the right thing. The OXO is fine, but I think the right thing to do is give it away and buy a Baratza just to support the kind of company that deserves our business. I hate tossing out machines just because one part fails and can't be found, and evidently Baratza feels the same way. Update 3/2019: Well, things were going well until yesterday it just wouldn't turn on. Reset everything possible and used a different outlet nothing at all. We did notice it did not grind fine enough for even our Aero Press, so that was a little disappointing.

I upgraded from my previous grinder, which was not conical, to this one because I hate, hate, hated the static buildup and after putting up with it for years because "that would be wasteful", I finally did the research and bought this one. Part of why I got this one was because the reviews were phenomenal but it was cheaper than the others. And while I still haven't tried the others, I feel I made the right decision.

Pros:
- Quiet! After I ran this one, I wished I had done a decibel test on my old one before I gave it away to compare!
- Fast - a single cup of coffee I usually set this to just the 1second grind setting and it's perfect.
- Consistent Grounds - the grind itself (and I do almost exclusively coarse for french press) is very consistent and has way less "dust" than my previous grinder.

Mixed Bag - I was looking forward to the stainless steel stating it had no static. There's still a *tiny* bit of static. I've found if I rinse the canister, just to get some moisture in there, that it reduces the static. And certainly every other grind that seems to be necessary. But it's also mid-winter and the humidity in the house is a little low this time of year. So it's not perfect, but it's a far sight better than the obnoxiousness I was dealing with before!

Overall I love this grinder. It looks good, doesn't take up a ton of space, and grinds a pretty great cup of coffee.

It was more expensive than our older unit, but SO MUCH BETTER. It is so much quieter, built extremely well, sounds smooth when running, grinds excellent without the larger pieces that our Cuisinart DBM-8 Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill used to do, and it looks great! I must say the Cuisinart did last for 5 years, and was less than half the price of the OXO, and was a combination Burr and blade instead of a REAL burr grinder like the OXO, and would by again if I could not afford the OXO, but the difference in OXO quality, the lower sound levels, quality of the grind, smaller footprint & much nicer looker unit are WELL worth the price difference. I recommend this highly.

reviews.reviewTitle: yes, I am happy with this
reviews.reviewText:
I’m only pitting this up against one other coffee grinder. As I have only owned one other coffee grinder. But that will do for this comparison. I will start with the burr itself. My other grinder was a burr, yea. But it was the other type of burr, a plate burr. This one is the conical kind. It is way faster for course grinding. I use this for cold press. So I use the coarsest grind (15).
But here I can answer a question a lot of you probably already know. But some people are here because they need a coffee grinder because they understand that beans keep longer if they are not ground until the last. And they need to know (why a burr)? The choices are a burr, or a blade type grinder. A blade is hit or miss on if it meets a bean. Making for a product that is some ground to a find snuff. And some not ground at all. A burr does not let the bean through until they can fit through the crack. Making for a nice, uniform, end. And this grinder is fast and uniform.
And the burr comes out if you want to clean it. They suggest to just brush the dust off. And to not put it in water. But I won’t tell on you if you do. I did a couple times. Just set it out on a dish towel over night and let it dry. And that is most likely why they say that. People put the burr back wet and cause a short circuit. Or a fire.
But a conical burr (such as this one), is what you want for course or drip medium grind. A plate burr excels at a grind fine for expresso. So, that is most likely the answer to all your questions. This grinder is excellent for course grinding, I can attend to that. I have never tried a finer grind than 9 (smaller is finer). So I can’t answer any questions on that end.
It is well constructed. I am pleased that they did not use cheap, inferior parts that will break easily. I’m not saying you can throw it around like a basketball. But if you knock it over. I think it would survive. I would recommend this to anybody I know in the market for a coffee grinder.
I just had to learn something. And I'll tell you guys, because maybe you will need to know this stuff someday. I tried to grind some beans that I had previously ground in the blender. I didn't do a good job. So I thought it would be a good idea to put them through the real grinder. It didn't work that way. The burr is made for coffee beans. Not ground coffee. It just clogged the exit chute all up. But not completely. Not yet. Five days later the chute stopped 100%. Turns out you clean that chute with a bottle brush. One of those little bitty ones. Or the video suggests a hex driver (Allen wrench). I got a half cup of grounds out. Now it is fast again. wee!!

We were given a low-end espresso machine so we needed a grinder to make it all worthwhile. Found this one on amazon with better than average reviews. Been using it for a month and so far it's been good. We typically leave it at setting 3 for espresso grinds and about 8 seconds on the auto timer for each approx double shot. The timer is very convenient to have. Review say that it's quieter than other grinder, not sure about that as i have nothing to compare it to but its definitely not quiet at 6am in the morning. So far it's been pretty reliable and we are pretty happy with the purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: Buyer beware - stopped working after eight months.
reviews.reviewText:
Update: Grinder stopped working properly after eight months. One day, everything was fine. The next our output was reduced to 1/4 of what it had been. We lost more and more each day until less than a teaspoon was being ejected on a full 40-second cycle. No response from manufacturer, which is disappointing considering the $100 price point.

Update: We’ve been using this grinder for five months now, no issues. Holds our settings and delivers consistent results. Highly recommend.

*****************

We’ve only had this unit for 24 hours. Purchased as a replacement for a Bodum grinder that flakes out after nine months of home use (1-2 minutes per day for those who calculate usage). Bodum would not stand behind their product, so they were removed from consideration in this purchase.

This grinder is solid. It’s taller and heavier than the Bodum, but it’s also quieter and produces a more consistent grind than the Bodum.

The only negative so far is static. Yes, I know that static is present in most burr grinders. But it’s significantly more prevalent in this grinder than the Bodum. Still working around that issue. Otherwise, I’m very happy.

After years of using cheap bladed coffee grinders, I bought my wife one of these for Mother’s Day. I had hoped it would be quieter and provide a nicer overall experience than the very loud cheap grinders we had been using.

I can say the OXO grinder is easier to use and it sure looks nice on the counter, but that’s where the love ends.

It is a little quieter than our cheap grinder, but not by much. It has a reasonably sized hopper for the beans, but it has feed issues and I have to give it a tap or nudge to keep the beans feeding constantly. This also means the timer for how long the grind process runs never produces a consistent amount of coffee grinds.

The stainless steel canister where the grinds land is very nice to look at but there are issues with not all the grinds making it into the canister. It has terrible static issues that cause the grinds to stick to the lip or walls. I can’t help but think this might not be a problem with a container made of glass. We are now constantly having to sweep up coffee grinds from the counter.

If we leave the grinder plugged in while not in use, it produces a noticeable electrical hum. We basically need to unplug it between uses making it considerably less convenient.

Finally, I did reach out to OXO support to see if there were any way to deal with at least the electric hum, and they never responded to my email or messages. I gave them several weeks to respond before I wrote this review. Overall I’m pretty disappointed in them at this moment.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works as I had hoped it would...with some hiccups in performance
reviews.reviewText:
Nothing to complain about here. Grind is super consistent, no noise coming from the grinder while it’s plugged in. Cup that coffee grinds drop into hooks into the unit, so it doesn’t fall/vibrate out. It is slightly loud while grinding, but I didn’t really expect it to be quiet.

So really, a lot of the deficiencies bad reviews talked seemed to have been fixed. Did notice when I got this that it was the 2nd version, so that might be why. Very satisfied as of right now. Only time will of course

Update 1:
After having it for awhile, I’ve decided to add a couple negative experiences I’ve had with it.
1. It has started a very low hum. Having a house with two kids and constant noise, plus the fact that You pretty much have to be Right next to it be able hear the humm, means it really doesn’t bother me all that much. Time will tell whether the humm gets worse or annoys me more.
2. Switched from a medium roast to a french roast, as well as to a grind setting of 7 1/2. Now notice that not all of the grinds Come out, some seeming to get stuck right after grinding. Not all, but enough to be annoying. Makes me wonder how accurate the amount grinder per timed setting is every time.

This also gets annoying while trying to clean it, as I try to do after every bag of coffee goes through. Grinds continuously fall out while brush the inside out. Also notice that, while cleaning it, Some coffee beans are still still on/in burr grinder. They are either partially to fully ungrounded.

Again, all of this is once I switched to a darker roast. Annoying enough to remove a star.

Have gone back to a medium roast, and will update if there are any changes.

Color me impressed. I’m not crazy about oxo because a lot of their products are over engineered household kitchen products and id rather go to a restaurant supply store to get things like a vegetable peeler or thermometer. I wanted an industry grade burr grinder but those prices are not justified by my home coffee consumption (I am a little prissy coffee diva who can’t afford a nice espresso machine at home so I just buy it hah!) so this machine had the highest reviews for my price point. I’ve been using it for a few months and this could not be easier to use.

It’s a sturdy machine and you can feel from it’s heft it won’t crap out on you. At a touch or a button you get perfectly ground coffee and it doesn’t make a mess. The hopper holds exactly one bag of beans. I accidentally dropped the grinder from the top of my fridge fully expecting the plastic hopper to crack and all it did was bounce. The brushed steel keeps it nice and clean looking even after months of use. My boyfriend who was making a huge mess with his small bladed grinder and phobic of all things kitchen has eagerly embraced the product too. The little bladed grinder now is just a spice grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Constantly refuses to grind beans of all types
reviews.reviewText:
I generally have the coarseness set to a medium grind and I use a range of whole beans, from medium roast to a very dark roast. After 3 or 4 days of use, nothing would happen when I pushed the "start/stop" button. Through trial and error I found that I had to clean it every day for it to work properly, and sometimes even one-half way through grinding enough beans for only a 4-cup pot. Yet, other than a few small fragments of bean in the burr area, the grinder is generally quite clean. There is no obvious reason for why it is stopping. If I wiggle the hopper knob, it will often finish grinding. What a pain!
Definitely not ready for Prime Time. But it does produce a uniform grind on the medium setting, in my opinion.

This burr grinder is AMAZING! It has made a WORLD of difference when drinking coffee. I previously bought whole beans from Starbucks and asked them to grind the whole bag for me. It was great, but I couldn't finish the bag quick enough and by about two weeks, I really tasted a difference in the coffee and it was really not as good as when it was first ground. I also bought prepackaged ground beans but I was also not happy with those flavors. After buying this grinder, my coffee has tasted exceptional. I am loving my coffee every time I drink it now. I have not had any issues with static cling as previous reviewers had mentioned. I just knock the metal tin a few times and the grounds come out. Any leftover grounds are insignificant to the actual coffee making process. Every 5 or 6 times I make coffee, I also wash the metal tin to clear all particles from the container. I also tap my burr grinder every now and then to empty any residuals that may have stuck in the grinder. No problems so far and I've had it for about two to three months now.

reviews.reviewTitle: I likes it pretty ok I guess
reviews.reviewText: So this replaces a Cuisinart conical burr grinder I got several years ago. The Cuisinart is now held together by a rubber band, has a bad case of static cling, and racket-wise competes nicely with a 747 testing its engines. But hold it, this review is about the Oxo. Ok, yeah, sorry. The Oxo does a pretty nice job, is two notches less noisy than a 747, and has practically no static-cling. I would rate it higher except for the chinzy timer. Two problems with the timer: one, feels and works cheapo -- I predict that will be the first thing to break. Second, just how many cups is 30 seconds of grind anyway? Little or no guidance from the manufacturer on that score, so it's trial and error for this guy (I don't like to grind in advance...wait, what?). But that's not grounds for rejecting this aburrve average grinder. So I bought two, so what?

NOTE: I have been using this grinder for brewing coffee, if you are using it for espresso my review may not be as relevant for you as others.

There are cheap grinders and expensive grinders, this one lands on the affordable side, but not cheap. What you get for the money is a well designed grinder that does the job well and is decent quality. It has conical burrs which are better than flat burrs and blades for consistency, it is not quiet but not real loud either, and it does a good consistent grind. The burrs are replaceable and the unit is easy to clean, thoroughly, if you are that kind of person. One super thing to note, the anti-static function works! WORKS GREAT! The catch basin is a metal and it is grounded, all static is gone, my last grinder was not like that and I have coffee grounds sticking to my hands and everything else within 6 inches on certain days.

I read a lot of people had issue with the beans getting caught in hopper and not grinding, I think that happens with most grinders, just give the grinder a bump and it resumes grinding. This is also issue when you fill up the hopper or have dark roast coffee with more oils on surface, I recommend keeping the coffee in a separate container and dosing whole beans into hopper for each brew. I have not had the coffee get bound up in there once this way.

Save yourself some money if you are thinking about buying $200-$300 grinder and get this one instead, I doubt you will regret it. Sure it does not have a fancy Italian name on the side, if that is an issue for you then spend the money. For the price this is a great purchase if you are weighing cost vs. quality. If you are thinking about buying a $15 blade grinder understand that they are not great but it will grind your coffee. The $40-$60 burr grinders also work but have their flaws, that is what I had previously and once it died I moved up to this one, good bye and good riddance to that old Cuisinart (to its credit it ground lot of coffee). $100 may seem like a lot to spend for some, but if you use this everyday it is worth it as this will probably last for years.

Easy to use with great, consistent grind from coarse to fine. After about 1mo of use, I am very happy with this product. I had been wanting a conical burr coffee grinder for about 5yrs, and I could never find one that I thought was worth the price for the reviews. The price is right on this one, and I am pleased with its performance. If anything changes down the road, I will update my review. So far, so good!

reviews.reviewTitle: Poor shoot design defies gravity causing coffee to get stuck.
reviews.reviewText: I bought this burr grinder in August 2018. This is my first review. It grinds well except that every time I grind I have to beat on the sides of the grinder to get all the coffee to fall into the dispenser. I do this by turning it back on when it appears to be done and I always find that another 2t come out. Not a great situation. Then today while cleaning it which I do religiously once a month here’s what happened - after brushing, using the air from the grinder end and up the shoot I use “grinds” on it. Then I beat on the sides and more coffee came out! So I added “grinds” 2 more times And still a tsp of coffee came out each time!! I find this to be really unusual. I only grind 2 scoops of coffee weekdays and 4 on Saturday and Sunday. My husband who is a design engineer thinks that because the shoot is a right angle do the coffee catches in places that are hard to reach to clean. I plan to order extra “grinds” today. One other complaint is that for some reason the letters on my start button have rubbed of and I don’t think I’ve ever wiped it. I plan to contact OXO. I’m probably out of warranty but I do want to let them know because generally they make excellent products and I’m sure that the next generation will be better 😊

While it worked it was a great machine!
Quiet for the most part, compact, easy on the eyes. Used it daily to grind about 4 oz of coffee a day for about 5 days until it all went to hell.
First it just stopped reacting to its start button being pushed. I thought, okay I’ll figure this out and eventually got it to come back to life’s with some troubleshooting.
About a minute later while grinding a small amount of coffee on a coarse grind setting it clogs. I figure it’s no big deal and get to work cleaning it out and trying to unclog it. An hour and a half later and it’s STILL clogged.
Found some online forum that has others experience with this and while some were able to fix this using the same methods I had, others like myself were not so lucky. Now I just have a nice piece of plastic to display.
Not sure if I can return it for a refund since it’s been used and I can’t clean it before sending it back as the clog is somewhere unreachable.
It’s a shame, it worked nicely for a few days too.

reviews.reviewTitle: If you want a quality grind, this seems to do the trick
reviews.reviewText:
I can't fault it for being noisy... it isn't the machine, it's the grinding... sounds just like every other bur grinder I've ever heard.
I love the control it gives you over the grind in order to match your way of making coffee. I use an Aeropress at home and a drip coffee maker at work. This can make a better tasting grind than pre-ground Folgers. That may not seem like much, but a blade grinder just won't... to inconsistent of a grind and you're better off buying ground coffee than doing it yourself if you aren't going to do it right.

Takes up more space than a little grinder, but it's powerful and delivers the goods. It is an investment, but at a much better price point than the ones that are several hundred dollars and up. I'd even give this a go if I was running an espresso stand, it has enough capacity for several customers (beans!, I mean coffee beans! Do not use on unruly customers!)
at a time and in 20 seconds you have fresh ground beans.
