UPDATE : I've gotten a french press to try out and using a coarse grind of Nani's San Francisco beans for my first try on 13 setting, I got a very nice cup of coffee. So, I'm happy with it for use with my aeropress and a drip maker and a french press. I am not a coffee snob by any means, but I sure know the difference between swill and a good cup of joe. This lets me make a good cup of joe. I can say that I can now make a better cup of coffee than Folgers or Starbucks without having to cover up the harshness with sugary additives.

So far so good I'm comparing it to a high-end Breville coffee Burr grinder that essentially died after it got a rock in it from Starbuck beans. I'm now paranoid to buy another very expensive conical burr grinder with respect to getting another rock in it and destroying my grinder. After reading several reviews on this item I decided to make my purchase. what I really like about this grinder is that there is absolutely no static created after grinding the beans and therefor no mess. I did get a chance to play around with grind settings and it can grind the beans to very fine powder or dust to dang near gravel size grind (not sure why anybody would want that size but whatever, just putting it out there for you). The grinder is definitely quieter than my previous Breville grinder; however, the bean hopper on top is smaller, but the lid fits very snug to keep your beans fresh. I'm currently on a bag of medium roast beans (not oily at all), and have had no issues with the beans getting stuck to the hopper. My next bag will be a very oily French roast, and will keep everyone posted on how it handles them. Unless you clean your hopper every time you fill it, beans will get stuck with almost all burr grinders I have used. This machine's real estate is smaller than my Breville, and I like that as it leaves more room on my counter top. I was hesitant to buy this brand because I think of OXO as spatulas and potato peelers brand. Like many of my reviews I will keep this updated should anything go wrong or if I should find fault in the product.

i wanna play some trap music and dance this thing is so good. i used an (aaron) burr grinder - manual - and while cutesy and hipster (do people still say that?) cool - like all natural i feel in contact with the beans and such - after a few batches its like duuuuuude this is a lotta work i need my wrists cant get the arthrises just yet - so i reached for the clickety click click on ze amazon and got this badboy cuz OXO does kitchen stuff right! and it is so cool. i use it for my moka pot - still havent perfected it yet - but 5 or 6 on this grind is what seems ok so far. idk i dont do much cafe but i like these toys when i do. toys! fun!

reviews.reviewTitle: Reviews of almost no static buildup were misleading.
reviews.reviewText: All the talk about not building up static on the ground coffee, it wasn't the case when I ground my first and only batch so far. The static was worse than my cheap Mr Coffee burr grinder. The output canister doesn't fit tight, I thought it would snap in place, very loose, would prefer a tighter fit. It is quieter than my older grinder and does grind well. If I had known the static was going to be as bad as it is, I would have bought another brand. The tab that is supposed to prevent the build up of static, doesn't work, makes a mess when trying to transfer to coffee canister. Would not buy again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Clogs contuously and makes a real mess
reviews.reviewText:
We received the grinder on December 31, 2018 and started using it right away. It did a nice grinding job but started to clog up in the discharge chute fairly quickly. It is a real mess to clean and wastes ground coffee in the process. It seems like we can grind only one hopper full before the clogging happens. It is though this chute is too constricted

I called the Amazon chat line to get help since we were past the allowable return date. This was of no help; I was referred to the manufacturer, whom I have e-mailed with my concerns and am awaiting a response. It feels like I will be out my $100

So I have used this for all of 3 days so far, but I am currently in love with it. ***If anything changes, I will update this review, so assume no news is good news!***

I was using a blade grinder for my wide array of coffee making apparatuses. French Press and Siphon are my "go-to's", which isn't all that impressive because course grinds are fairly simple.

Where I am ecstatically impressed with this machine is it's ability to grind turkish level grounds. If you are not familiar, a turkish require coco powder level fineness - and this machine delivers.

Overall, generally quiet performance, good, solid design so far, and impressive range of grinds. I currently grind FP on level 12 (of 15), and turkish on 1.

Again, I will update if I have quality issues, but for now, my first impressions are 100%.

************* 2 month update ********************

Still going strong. Other have complained about beans not feeding down unto the grinder, and I noticed this while grinding a small bag of oily beans to take to work. My normal coffee is a medium roast with no flavor on it, and I have never had an issue outside of the the once with Cameron's Espresso beans fro Costco.

I did notice a nice perk the other day. My wife is a decaf person (I know...I know....), and I was able to remove the entire upper hopper full of beans, pour them into a bowl, and load with decaf bean without any spillage. Very nice that it is possible. I have been using 3-8 times a week, 20 seconds at a time, no issues yet!

Also, the lack of static electricity on the collection cup is 100.

This has got to be the best sub $100 burr coffee grinder out there. No joke y'all. I was scared to spend only a hundred bucks because usually you have to spend a couple hundred or more to get something that doesn't turn out rocks and boulders. As soon as I took it apart to give it a wipedown I noticed how incredibly heavy duty and gigantic burr mechanism is. This thing is so freaking accurate and relatively quiet. I'm extremely impressed and I highly recommend it. Built like a tank, not too big, quiet and fast!

This coffee grinder is a hot mess!! The first one we received did not work at all. Amazon was great in sending us another one and the return process was simple - the only bright spot in this whole ordeal. The second one we received worked perfectly through the first pound of coffee beans but a few weeks later, while trying to grind the second pound, no grounds were coming out when we pushed the start button. We quickly realized it needed to be cleaned so my husband spent 20 minutes cleaning it out. We have had to repeated and thoroughly clean this thing after every pound ground. Today we ground our 6th, and final, pound of coffee in this piece of junk after my husband spent another 30 minutes cleaning it. The picture is our counter top after 30 minutes of cleaning and trying to grind a pound of coffee. We are done. I'll have to check if it is still under warranty so I can send it back, If not, in the trash it goes.

reviews.reviewTitle: This works better than more expensive brands...
reviews.reviewText:
I have found that this grinder works better than more expensive models (which I tried and promptly sent back!), but it's still not great. I have a French Press and just recently bought a Chemex.

Even though I have the setting on 15 (Very Coarse) it is still not quite coarse enough. There is quite a bit of "sludge" left in the bottom of my cup when I use the French Press. I haven't gotten the exact measurements worked out with the Chemex though so I don't use it much.

For the money, the OXO grinder does the job and while some people may find it difficult to clean, I take it out to the garage and use my husband's air compressor to blow out the remaining grounds. I've used this machine three of four times already and have not had a problem with it. It's not overly loud and it works.

Overall it does what it's supposed to do. But there is a huge design flaw that undermines everything. The ground coffee container is not locked in place. It happened twice to me already that it moved half-inch aside so coffee missed the container. Comparing this grinder which is twice more expensive than 5-years old one that's still working makes me doubt if I want to keep it at all

It;s been a month since we received the Oxo Brew conical coffee grinder and we're very pleased with it. The construction is solid, it's easy to use and clean. The noise level is not an issue at all. The settings for fine to course grind is quite adequate for just about any type of bean or maker. We prefer a little on the course side for our drip coffee maker.
Here's a hint: We use a Mr. Coffee drip maker. Pretty basic, right. Well, by accident I forgot to put the pot on the warmer plate under the spout. Luckily, this maker has the feature that stops filling the pot when it is not on the warming plate. So for the 2 minutes or so that the hot water was pouring over the beans but not going into the pot the freshly ground beans had a few moments to "bloom" to their full potential. Very similar to how a Chemex works by slowly going thru the filter. This mistake, plus having the Oxo grinder making freshly ground beans for every pot, has let us enjoy coffee at home better than most "specialty" coffee shops!

We really like this grinder. We switched in 2017 from a cheap (but effective) blade grinder to a Cuisinart DBM-8 (which was terrible), then back to a new cheap blade grinder. The grind from the blade unit was too uneven – there would be fine power and half-beans in the mix, even with shaking and pulsing.
Back on the hunt for a good burr grinder, the reviews on Amazon led me to this unit, the OXO BREW Conical Burr Coffee Grinder. It does the job nicely! Its footprint is small enough to not get in the way. It grinds coffee evenly and consistently. There’s very little powder, regardless of whether we are grinding light roast or oilier dark roast beans. It’s MUCH quieter than the Cuisinart disk burr grinder. I think it’s even quieter than the blade grinder. The static issue is manageable. It’s not completely static free, but the metal container does a very good job of keeping static under control.
We bought this unit in October 2018 and have used it virtually every day since. We have used different grinds for French Press, automatic drip, and pour-over. Not only have the grinds been even, but the adjustments make a noticeable difference. (i.e., Changing it a half “point” in either direction makes a difference, but provides fine enough control for our purposes.) We do not make espresso these days, so I only tried the finest setting once – when I needed a little coffee powder to add to brownie batter. It worked well for that purpose.
This one is a winner. Very happy with this purchase.

I returnef after one day! I set it to 3 for espresso and the chute clogged rigbt away! Tried a couple of more times after I cleaned it! No luck!
I own a Gaggia Classic so the grid has to be fine!

There are two things I like about this coffee grinder. First, the grind is very consistent. I mostly drink coffee from a drip coffee maker. As such consistency is not the most important quality, but it is nice to see coffee that looks like it was ground with one of the big machines at a grocery. I have owned more expensive grinders that don't produce this consistency at the settings for drip coffee. The second thing I'm impressed with is the grounds container. As mentioned I've owned other grinders. They've all had plastic containers. The problem with every one of these I've owned has been static cling - grounds stubbornly stick to the container. Depending on the roast and the weather, getting the grounds from the container to the filter basket almost always makes a mess. The Oxo container is stainless steel - no cling!

A final word about Oxo the company. Their customer service is superb. I bought the grinder in November. In May I noticed it had developed a hum when not running. I called the company on June 3rd and on the 7th FedEx delivered a replacement to my door. Oxo supplied a prepaid label in an email to use for returning the defective machine. I can't speak to the ability of this grinder for espresso nor for French-press, but for a drip coffee maker I highly recommend it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Loved it but it died in 32 days. Replacement on the way!
reviews.reviewText: LOVED this grinder so much right up until it broke 32 days after purchase! Amazon is taking care of me despite being outside the 30 day return window and sending a new one out right away. I will update this review if the new one survives more than a few months. The grinder was quiet, static free and a perfectly uniform grind. It suddenly stopped grinding the beans. The motor ran and the beans jumped around but no grinding occurred and it sounded "stuck." I took it apart and cleaned all the parts that could be cleaned and shook out the half ground beans around the burr twice to no avail. I attempted to contact OXO and did not receive a response within the 24 -48 hour window as promised. Thank goodness for excellent customer service from Amazon as this item was not cheap! Hopefully it was a fluke and the new grinder will have a much longer life!

Grinded coffee great while it worked even though I had the humming when not in use like others described. After about 6 weeks it would only grind without getting jammed if I pushed down real hard on the top of the hopper. I contacted Oxo and after a few emails back and forth they offered an exchange. They recommended that I unplug the unit when not in use to remedy the humming problem. Not a reasonable solution if you ask me. It has now been 7 days since I mailed the unit back and I’m still waiting for a replacement. I’ll probably buy a grinder with a better proven track record. I don’t feel confident in the replacement or the Oxo brand anymore.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sturdy quality at a fair price
reviews.reviewText: My old conical burr grinder finally crapped out. The button broke and fell into the housing, if not for that cheap design it probably would’ve lasted forever. After much research I decided on the Oxo. Simple to use and sturdy construction. Doesn’t seem to have to cheap design of the other brand. Fill the hopper, push and button and grind away. It’s relatively quiet. I’m very pleased with the quality of the grinder and ease of use. The only reason it doesn’t get five stars is the coarse grind is a little inconsistent but not a big deal. It could be that it just needs to be set to the proper setting. It also has a slight hum to it that’s only noticeable if you’re standing next to it in a silent room. Overall it’s a great grinder for a reasonable price that should last a long time.

I really see no problem with this grinder, it’s amazing. Other reviews made me skeptical about buying this but honestly the negative reviews weren’t really legit reasons to give such a negative review. I have absolutely no problem with this grinder, it’s great and easy to use. I grind for pour overs and they’ve been turning out great. I used to buy pre-ground coffee and the difference is huge when you just grind your own beans. I paid about $80 for this thing and did the math....that’s roughly 22 days of my 3.50 coffee that I was buying at my local shop. Less than 1 month of coffee from a shop for the price of this grinder. Make America Brew at Home Again

UPDATE: the grinds get stuck. I didn't realize this was an issue until I bought a scale. You have to bang the grinder on the bottom to get all the beans and grinds out and it's getting super annoying and precision is key. Maybe just spend your money on a good quality hand grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: The cleanest and quietest burr grinder I have owned
reviews.reviewText:
I have had two burr grinders prior to the Oxo. Both were much louder and the last one I bought and dumped in a matter of weeks because of the static electricity mess and the noise.

The Oxo is quiet (for a burr grinder) and the grounded stainless steel grounds bin really does work to eliminate the mess that comes with static electricity build up that can cause grounds to fly everywhere when the bin is removed from the grinder. Not so with the Oxo, the area around the grinder is clean after several ginds.

Another observation: the grounds are extremely uniform in size. With my last grinder, the grounds varied from near powder to course. The ground uniformity from the Oxo caught my eye right away.

I have only had this a few weeks, so if it performs this well for at least a few years it's worth the 5 stars, especially in eliminating the mess that comes with some of the other grinders.

Does it do the job? Yes it does. But can it do it better? Yes it can.

It’s very loud, coffee grinds spray out, the container creates static electricity and the grinds get stuck and it makes a bigger mess. I'd take a hard pass at this model.

Purchased in December 2018, grinder had problems. Contacted OXO Customer Service and was told that they were aware of issues with the machine and would ship a replacement within a few months. They did as they promised and the new machine works perfectly. Very happy with both the grinder and excellent OXO customer service.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use, and static can be avoided!
reviews.reviewText:
First and foremost, if you are having issues with static causing grounds to stick in the container simply grind while you prep your coffee maker so it can sit a moment, but most importantly, tap it on the counter right before you pour. I nearly never have an issue.
The grinder is nice. We have had 2 previous grinders. As a non coffee drinking primary coffee maker in our house, I really like that I can push a button and walk away. And my husband liked that he can really set it to just how he wants his coffee ground. This might seem tedious and time consuming at first, but especially when combining with his technivorm moccamaster machine, he gets a very nice cup of coffee.
As far as noise goes, I find it to be very tolerable. A grinder is not going to be quiet, but it is quieter than our last two, plus being able to walk away makes it even easier to tolerate. I used to put towels under and around our old grinder to lessen the shock of the noise first thing in the morning, but this one really doesnt offend me at all.
Clean up is simple, and I have found that if I empty the hopper out well ( which is quick and easy to do) every other time I fill it I don't run into any issues with a clog or anything like that.
Very happy with the grinder, was pricy for what we are used to paying for coffee accoutrements, but I was splurging on Christmas gifts.

Another great product from the trusted, tried and true OXO. Have many of their kitchen products and they never disappoint. This is very easy to operate, very user friendly, you can even adjust, via dial, how many seconds you want it to grind your coffee beans. I've had this about 1 month, so haven't cleaned the mechanism yet, so can't say, but given their track record, it should be easy enough. I use fresh roasted beans and either a French Press or Pour Over method, and the grind size is a giant horizontal wheel, so easy to move left or right depending on which grind I need at the time. The noise level isn't too bad, and it's very fast. The grind is consistant unlike my little hand held grinder that I replaced it with, great purchase, bought one for my son for his Birthday.

I bought this for use with the Kitchen Aid Cold Brew Maker and both are excellent products that work well together,
.
For use with the Kitchen Aid, I measure 8 ounces (by weight) of coffee beans and they all fit in the Oxo hopper. With the grind on the coarsest setting (15) I set ther time for about 26 seconds. It takes three batches to grind the entire 8 ounces, emptying the ground coffee into the Kitchen Aid brew basket each time.

The grind is uniform, and the unit is quieter than any grinder I've used before. I've experience no issues with failure to feed even somewhat oily beans. Cleanup is simple. So far, I've ground 5 pounds of coffee with this appliance and it reflects the quality I've come to expect from Oxo. Highly recommended.

This was my first burr grinder purchase. I can say that the quality of grind it produces is good. My coffee tasted amazing compared to using a blade grinder.

Unfortunately, I did return this grinder.

The first reason is because it was very messy. I like to place my gold filter directly under where the grounds are coming out. Doing this would cause a "dust" of grounds to go everywhere. I also tried using the container that was provided, but that would not stay in place during grinding. Additionally, after the grinding was done there would be a lot of residual grinds falling out and onto the countertop.

The second reason is because at times the grinder would be on, but was not grinding any beans. They would get stuck in the hopper and I would have to shake the unit or stick something in it to push the beans through.

I will be purchasing the Ariete -Delonghi burr grinder and hopefully I have better luck.

I’ve been using the Oxo Brew conical grinder daily, for a couple of months now and am really happy with it performance. I’d read most of the reviews and questions about this grinder and can say that I haven’t had any issues at all. It’s my first good grinder and I’ve found the grind to be consistent, the noise tolerable (for the 10 seconds it grinding) and the mess non existent.
Some have said the little tab that clicks when the hopper is in place and acts as a static ground stopped working. I haven’t had that issue. There’s really no static and I can always tell that the hopper is where. It’s supposed to be.
I make one cup of immersion pour over using the Bonavita dripper. I set the grind on the Oxo to 10.5 (which approximates a 6 on a commercial grinder) and the timer to about 9 seconds. This yields appx 24 grams of coffee. It’s easy to clean and reassemble as well. For my needs this is a great grinder!

We have been looking around for a conical coffee grinder and we settled on this one. It holds plenty of beans and you will need to experiment a lot to find your proper grind, amount of coffee needed and length of time to grind the beans. Still has a lot of coffee bean dust from the grinding. Our timer does not appear to work properly and the start button does not always work. We have had it too long to exchange. My advice is to keep looking.

About twice a month this grinder will jam up with ground coffee packed into the chamber above the catch container. I have to disassemble the burr apparatus and gouge out all the packed grounds in the chamber. This has become a royal pain, and while I liked the grinder at first, this process has made it unacceptable.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder, but read my review to solve one issue
reviews.reviewText:
This is our first foray into coffee bean grinding with a machine, but so far so good. Certainly beats the hand cranking one we’ve been using every morning. The vast number of settings for how coarse or fine the grounds come out seems like overkill, but maybe for the coffee aficionado it’s a great feature to have.

So the one issue that I had is with the stainless steel cup that catches the grounds. The folks that read instructions will see that there’s supposed to be a “click” sound when you put the cup in the unit. This keeps it in place during the vibration that occurs when the grinder is on. I’ve seen a few people complain that the cup doesn’t click into place and in turn slides out of place when in use. The one fix I tried and worked for me after I exchanged the first unit for the same problem was to bend back that metal trigger thing on the unit that pushes up against the cup. It seems that, out of the box, that piece pushes the cup back out too far so it can’t lock into place. Bending it back slightly fixed that issue. Having said that, I tried to fix the first unit I received and the cup still didn’t seem that secure. In this case, the plastic lid that goes over the cup didn’t have enough of a ridge on it to lock into place properly. For that issue, you can either ask for a replacement unit to get what you paid for, which is a working unit, or you can jerry-rig it with a thick rubber band like I read someone else did.

All in all, I’m happy now that I have a 100% working unit. I thought about knocking the rating down a star for the trouble, but Amazon customer service quickly sent out the replacement with no attitude and only continuous thanks and apologies for the hassle so I can let it slide. Hope this review helps.

We grind a huge amount at once, then store it in a monster sized mason jar in the freezer (plastic lid). That way we don’t have to fuss with it very often. Then we clean it really good. It has a strong tendency to get very clogged with a tablespoon of grounds under the ejection chute. Hubbie created a little metal cleaning rod that has a 90° bend at the end to clean all through the chute into the tiny feed hole.

reviews.reviewTitle: One year on and I still love it!
reviews.reviewText:
I can't believe I didn't review this before but hey, maybe that's good...I'm reviewing after a year of use every single day...I grind for espresso (1-2 setting) in the morning and brew in the afternoon (setting 7). Yes, you do have to make sure you turn the hopper down tight each time you use it...that doesn't bother me...you just push down and turn the little paddle inside. The noise levels are good, the grind is consistent, it's quick, easy to use, there's no static issue. Nothing has fallen apart or off, nothing has worn down or out...and it gets used twice a day and more on the weekends.

I don't know what else to say, I would recommend this OXO grinder to anyone!! and a burr grinder at just under $100 that's excellent quality...

reviews.reviewTitle: I roast coffee for a living.
reviews.reviewText:
I use mainly commercial grinders in my workplace. I've used Braratza and Capresso at home. Have been using the Oxo grinder at home now for several weeks and think it is great. Grind is consistent, and I have no issue with the mess others refer to in their reviews. Coffee grinders tend to get coffee grounds on your counter. I find this one a little less messy than my last Capresso (which still works btw after 4 years of service. The grind dial broke off and I got sick of using a coin to turn the dial.)

So far, I like this grinder for my medium and coarse grind needs. I think the price point is very good for this grinder that rivals its $130 competitors.

I was bullied into getting a burr grinder for our new DeLonghi espresso combo. I was sure that using my bladed steel grinder to pregrind and then put it into the spice grinder with the lower blades would be enough. Husband was sure that it wasn't quite what he wanted, so I researched the Burr Grinders. Chose OXO, as it always has an excellent rating for any product that it brings to market. Boy, is that right. Perfectly ground. Perfectly fine. Perfect for the espresso setting. Easy to change to the drip grind. No static. Easy to wipe clean. Get this one - cheaper too!

Consistent grinds of fine to coarse. Lower speed than most all other grinders which keeps beans cooler through the grind. Next to zero static cling of grinds found on all other units made with plastic containers. Absolutely zero mess left behind after dozens of morning grinds. Ranks up in the best $99 bucks I ever spent. This is a phenomenal buy for the this class of conical burr mill grinder. Easy to setup and absolutely simple and easy and quiet to use.

reviews.reviewTitle: Better than the similar priced Delonghi
reviews.reviewText:
Very nice working burr cone grinder for the price. Non messy and pretty consistent grind. Just beware of finer grind settings. My burrs started to grind into eachother towards the very fine settings. If I wasn't very slowly adjusting it down and listening for it to touch I would have ruined the burrs. That's the main reason I returned my Delonghi grinder.

Other than that and the timer control seeming a bit cheap feeling I'm liking this one quite a bit. Left my timer right where I need it for 16oz of coffee using a ryobi coffee press and it grinds through the perfect amount of beans I need every time. Extra bonus to no static cling in the metal grind holder and extra grounds never fall out when I remove the grinds holder, so no mess.

Best gift I've given myself in a while! Great price. More importantly, works just fine and opens the world of buying all those varieties of whole bean coffee available and keeping it fresh until brewing which makes a taste difference that even I can appreciate! Accurate grind, easy to adjust from drip to french press coarseness, easy to adjust by a little trial and error to grind just enough for your need. Relatively quiet, although I prefer to grind it at bedtime rather than in the AM when my spouse is sleeping.
The fresh ground taste is definitely noticeable and of course the grind is far superior to my old blade chopper, very consistent. One time, a bean got caught down in the burr and had to be removed to run. Otherwise, 3 months of problem-free operation. Recommend!

reviews.reviewTitle: Patience a belief OXO got it right
reviews.reviewText: Our relationship started off a little rocky. Early on I found it difficult to make coffee without making a large groundy mess all over the counter. Also I found the 30 sec setting not quite long enough for a large pot of coffee. After the second week things improved, the process cleaned up and the grind was such where it can do a full pot on 30 secs. I now find it a better grind then my previous burr which was a Cuisinart. So be patient, don't give up on her and hopefully you'll have similar results.

I make 64 ounces of coffee a day, minimum. I make it 16 ounces at a time so I’m grinding 1 ounce of beans 4 different times a day — for either a French press or chemex — and each ounce of beans is a different variety. The Oxo does a great job. It grinds each & every bean each time so no mixing of different varieties occurs. I bought a small wooden serving tray to put it in based on some reviews that said it is messy due to static, but don’t bother — after a month of daily use the wooden tray is still spotless - but it does look nice sitting in it. 😁. Static is almost nonexistent so using a little care will result in no messes. I also do not understand complaints about noise — hey — it’s a grinder that is used to turn roasted coffee cherry pits into ground coffee — there WILL be noise — personally I think it’s a reasonable amount. I can find absolutely nothing to criticize and hope this grinderlasts a long time because it was sure worth the price....!!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great from espresso to french press
reviews.reviewText: This was a pleasant surprise. I had read a lot of reviews of different similar metal burr grinders that complained about mess and static electricity creating problems. No such problems with this one. The grind quality is very consistent, the size of the grind works great for espresso and french press and I have had no problem with static electricity or mess. I really like the convenience of having the coffee beans ready for grinding and find it much more convenient and consistent than the old blade grinder I was using.

I find the oxo burr grinder works well and provides a good range of ground coffee which is consistent within a grind step. I purchased this grinder because it has a metal receptacle for the ground coffee that's grounded. One of the most maddening things about grinding your own coffee with a burr grinder is the static charge imparted on the coffee grounds. There is a grounding tab that touches the metal container, but it only 1/2 works. Not sure if it's due to grounds that get between the tab and the container or something else, but still have some flying grounds after grinding. So only 4 stars. But it is a nice, affordable, grinder if you're seeking a consistent grind and are a coffee lover.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great replacement for my old KitchenAid
reviews.reviewText: Couldn't be more pleased.After years of faithful service my KitchenAid grinder gave up the ghost. My research pointed to this little grinder as the best bang for the buck. That proved to be the case. Before I got this grinder I thought that all coffee grinders were supposed to sound like a rock crusher. This one is quiet and efficient. I set the timer on 30 seconds and that makes the perfect amount of medium ground coffee for eight cups in my Cuisenart drip machine. I also set the grind to the coarsest setting for my cold brew carafe. Again, couldn't be more pleased.

Replaced a dead Cuisinart "burr grinder" that cost about 1/3 the price of the OXO. Worth every penny. The grind is very uniforn, unlike the Cuisinart and makes much less noise. I do not understand reviews that complain about the noise. The stainless steel cup to hold the grind is a huge improvement over the Cuisinart' plastic one with which static covered the sides with grounds, and the timer for the grind means totally consistent quantities, once you decide on the timing, whereas the Cuisinart was inconsistent in amount. How lucky we were that it died

reviews.reviewTitle: will stop grinding and need thorough cleaning
reviews.reviewText:
This is an attractive product that produced excellent results for two months and then stopped grinding. I spent 10 minutes clearing out the bean intake sections, and gave up, posting a one star review. I then went to youTube and searched for more information, which showed me how to remove a part that I hadn't understood was removable, a basket thingy that lifts out. Fixed the problem. So, one star goes to three stars.
The manufacturer needs to explain, PROMINENTLY, that it is a virtual certainty that the thing will stop working, and show how it needs to be fixed.

Love! Love! Love This machine! Well worth the expense. It is a wee bit noisy when it's grinding, but grinding only takes a few seconds. I would say that a blender is louder than this machine. The flavor of the coffee is one thousand % better than coffee beans that are ground with a blade grinder. I could never go back to that type of bitter tasting coffee. The flavor of the coffee with this machine is soooooo Delicioussss with smooth flavor/taste. Yes, it is necessary for you to keep tweaking the control knobs until you find the setting that produces the best coffee for your tastes.

My first step was to use a manual burr grinder. I Loved the flavor of the coffee that was produced by this method. Only thing, it takes quite awhile to grind 3 tablespoons of coffee, and cleaning it is time consuming, plus you need to remember how you took it apart, so you can put it back together successfully. So glad I decided to make the investment, and purchase this electric grinder!

I never knew coffee could taste THIS delicious!

I'll compare this with the Breville BCG800XL burr grinder which I also have:
The OXO grinder appears to grind with the same uniformity as the Breville.
The OXO is quieter.
The controls on the OXO consist of a dial which you set for the number of seconds to grind, a push button to initiate the grind, and a manual turning of the hopper to set the grind from fine to course. The Breville has a button you repeatedly press to select the duration of the grind, and another button to initiate the grind, plus a dial that adjusts the grind from fine to course. The Breville's controls are more electronic but I've never had issues with them.
The Breville generates substantially less static cling to the grounds than the OXO.

Overall, the Breville is a better grinder, but not by much, and the OXO is much less expensive.

Great addition to my kitchen! I grind my beans at the coarses setting for my French Press, I just wish it could be a bit coarser. The fine setting is great for aeropress coffee. As far as noise level, it is grinding coffee beans, I expect it to be loud. It's easy to clean. The coffee does tend to cling to the container after grinding them, but I expect that from all the grinders too.

This works great. Consistent grind quality is the most important thing I want from my coffee grinder. It works fast and efficiently, too. The form factor and contemporary style really looks good on my counter-top. You don't need a fancy built-in scale; a little trial and error and you will find the perfect grind and quantity that you desire.

SO nice to be able to adjust the grind. I like a little coarse and I have a 11 dialed in. Plus I make a 10 cup pot, so by selecting the time you need. just press the button and you get the grind you want and the amount you want. The cup is stainless and so much better than the staticky plastic cups. ...especially in the dry winter. I really had to push myself into spending the money. I am so glad I did . I am very pleased with this unit.

reviews.reviewTitle: Just as good as more expensive brands for it's capabilities
reviews.reviewText: If you're debating between this and ones that are 50 to 100 dollars more expensive, you should buy this one. This is a great all around grinder. I've made drip and espresso from the grinds and they turned out perfectly. Some reviewers on YouTube say you have to buy a pricy grinder to get espresso grounds fine enough. I'm not an expert but this thing makes grounds fine enough for the job, while making grinds very consistent for other styles as well. I def recommend this grinder, don't spend more on something that's going to be doing the same job.

I love this product. It is easy to calibrate and use. It produces perfectly ground coffee, and there is virtually no coffee sawdust around the operation. The lack of sawdust has me in love with this machine. There are other grinders that come highly recommended but at a higher price. I see no reason to spend more on one of them when the OXO works so well. I have only had my OXO for a couple of months so how long it will continue to work well I cannot say. But, I am optimistic I will be a fan of this grinder for a long time to come.

Better than our $250 burr grinder! So we have had 2 burr grinders prior to this one which sell for around $250. Our first lasted 11 years but our 2nd only 4-5 years. After looking at many and reading reviews, we decided to get this and love it! We like it better than the others by far for several reasons: The grind is more uniform and easier to change or adjust, the noise level is a fraction of the others, it's smaller and looks great! I am planning to give these as gifts to everyone who loves coffee in our circle of friends and relatives.
This grinder won't grind coarse enough for french press, cold brew or even pour over. If you're only looking to do espresso then I guess this is a good option.

reviews.reviewTitle: Was great while it lasted <2 months
reviews.reviewText: Easy to set up and use in the beginning. I got this to replace my broken breville. Good grind, not too loud, and I really liked the stainless steel container. It was making an odd, low level grinding sound whenever it wasn't grinding and we would unplug it when it wasn't in use. It suddenly stopped working this morning and wouldn't restart even after I cleaned it out again. Definitely a major disappointment. Would not recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: do you like jam with your coffee?
reviews.reviewText: There is a lot to like about this grinder. The way the ground coffee feeds into the container creates less mess going in and coming out (the container is well designed for either pouring or spooning out the grinds). And it delivers a consistent grind fairly quickly. But the flaw here, relative to our old capresso, is that the coffee jams up in the chute. Which means fairly frequently disassembling the entire things and brushing it out. And then, of course, the grinds get everywhere...

I wouldn't repeat all the great things about this grinder in other reviews (what sold me on this). It's quiet and grinds well - when it works. After about 3 weeks of once a day use, coffee grinds no longer fall down (with motor running, etc). I've taken the thing apart as much as it allows, cleaned the blades, shook it repeatedly and even tried blowing up the chute. Being an engineer myself, I honestly think it's just a bad design with the chute being too narrow allowing the grinds to stick and most importantly it's pretty much impossible to get in there to clean (I even tried going at it with a q-tip (no luck). Returning.

So far excellent product. I have only ground coffee on one setting (course) for French press, and it does consistent job. No mess, and rather quiet. Easy to leave ground coffee in container with lid and use remainder grounds later. The lid has an opening, but it fits tightly under grinder so it feels safe to not cover loose grounds.

I was worried about size but it’s slim and not too tall. Looks good on counter, but will sit nicely in a cabinet without taking up much room. The measuring spool fits in metal container when not in use.

I did not need an abundance of settings, so 15 settings was fine for me. I rated it down 2 stars for value of money because as much as I believe this is a quality grinder, the price point is too high. Nevertheless, I recommend this grinder (based on limited use) and will probably purchase one for my son. I believe those looking for a quality grinder will be happy with this one. I purchased an extended warranty which I seldom do. It did not cost much considering purchase price.

reviews.reviewTitle: More coarse of a grind please
reviews.reviewText: It’s a pretty good grinder. No problems so far. I wish the coarse grind was more coarse. I really got this for cold brew as my manual grinder was a hario skerton pro that wasn’t grinding consistently. This is definitely faster. It’s easy to use. The metal collection bin is nice. Like I said, I wish it grinded coarser as cold brew is the only thing I drink and this is not coarse enough. But overall above average.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fantastic quality, feel and great features
reviews.reviewText: I absolutely love this coffee grinder! I looked way too long and did lots of research - everything from manual grinders to really expensive burr grinders - and decided on this one. I originally bought another grinder and was really disappointed with it's quality, for a few extra dollars I went with the OXO and I'm so happy I did!! The parts all feel well-made, the bean hopper essentially closes so it prevents unused beans spilling out and it isn't overly loud. A definite step up from a blade grinder and so far, I couldn't be happier with the purchase!

So far so good. Very consistent grind, obviously much quicker (and far more consistent) than the 2 hand grinders I had before (Coffee Gator which seized up and Hario Skerton which produced an inconsistent grind and the inner burr was very wobbly relative to the outer). I wouldn't consider it loud, I think it's quieter than inferior blade grinders. Definitely worth the money at $99 given that the aforementioned hand grinders were ~$40 and ~$55 respectively. Oxo has 2 yr warranty and to purchase 4 yrs it's only like $5 so not much risk if it has problems later on down the road.

Replaced a smaller coffee/spice grinder with this unit and it works great. Had to set the grind much coarser than i thought I would to match what we were used to but otherwise very happy. If you get one, start at a courser setting and work backwards to finer, I think it will work better that way. If you like espresso you will have to be patient though - on the finer settings it's not very fast but at our normal setting (4 on the dial) it not bad at all.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wake up and smell the coffee
reviews.reviewText: I’ve been using this grinder for about a month now. I really didn’t know fresh, properly ground coffee tasted so much better. Wow! My biggest issue (after figuring out which grind I like best for different coffees) is where to put it. I HATE appliances on the kitchen counters. But if you drink coffee a couple times a day, you need this grinder within easy reach. So I did a swap-I put a bulky toaster oven that lived on our counter top in a large drawer and put the grinder in its place. Perfect! This grinder takes up very little counter space and it looks totally cool. Now I get the smell of fresh ground coffee every morning easy peasey. Great buy!!!

My wife has noticed an improved flavor since we switched from store ground whole beans to this. Unit is load enough that we grind the night before as to not wake the whole house in the morning. have had a few times (3-4 over 4 months of use) where the beans will lock up and not feed into the hopper but a little shake and occasional cleaning take care of it

After more than 50 years of using already-ground coffee we decided to try a grinder, based on a review we saw online. We cannot believe the difference! Grinding the beans makes your kitchen smell wonderful, and then the coffee tastes so much better. We used the same beans as the ground coffee to compare. It took a bit of experimentation to find the perfect grind and time for us, and now we press the button and fill the water and the pot is ready to brew.

We had the Bodum burr grinder for 7 years, and when it broke I assumed I'd buy it again. However, we took a look at some reviews and ended up with the Oxo. I was immediately impressed by how quiet it was (probably less than half the noise of our Bodum) and continue to enjoy a nice variety of grind settings. Hopper is easy to fill. We are also having less ground coffee mess from static than we did with our prior one. Hopefully this grinder lasts as long as our Bodum and I'll be a happy camper!

reviews.reviewTitle: Must learn more about this unit
reviews.reviewText: I'm very pleased with the appearance and performance of this coffee grinder.. The only thing I'm concerned about this machine has a constant hum when pluged in... Is this normal? That is the only reason I did not give it five stars.. I unplug when not in use, not ideal

reviews.reviewTitle: Great quality and attention on details!
reviews.reviewText:
I'm so glad that I choose this one to replace my old Capresso 560.01 that has the serious static problem.
This is my first time buying products of OXO, and I was amazed by every detail they put attention on. It was well-protected sending in a box of a double-wall box. Every component of the grinder is very well designed.

Overall comments:
- No static problem.
- Super easy to use and clean.
- I won't say it's very quiet, but it's fast enough that you won't care about the ephemeral noise.

Most important of all,
- Grind quality is consistent and perfect!!

It grinds very consistently (although reportedly not so much if you grind it course, but I don't), it's fast, not that loud (no grinder is quiet) and it's actually easier than measuring out pre-ground coffee because the timer is set for a full pot, i push 1 button and 23 seconds later I have just the right amount of coffee which I dump right into the filter basket right before brewing. It has lots of features which I would never want to give up as well. I'll never go back to pre-ground.

We replace a Mr. Coffee grinder with this one. The Mr. Coffee grinder had a plastic chamber to catch the ground coffee and we had to use a small brush to clean it out. The brush helped, but didn't always clean it as well as we would like. The OXO grinder had a metal chamber so coffee never clings to it. We have had the OXO for 6 weeks now and it has held up like a champ. We grind large amounts of coffee twice daily and so far the OXO has been consistent and quick. It is much more quiet that the Mr. Coffee grinder too. Overall a great purchase!

Never had a burr grinder before but my husband loves his coffee so I got this as birthday gift for him. It’s a real upgrade from the blade grinder!
We use a French Press with a coarse grind. This machine takes the guesswork out of it. I love the one touch button timer and the generous hopper. It doesn’t hop around on the counter and it’s FAST! I only grind 1-2 cups at a time so just a few seconds turns out evenly ground coffee. As for noise...well I guess grinding coffee is noisy no matter what. I think it’s quieter than a bald grinder and quieter than my Vitamix.

Replaced a 20-year-old blade grinder with this about a month ago. The coffee actually tastes better, even when brewed exactly the same way. The noise level and coffee grounds on the counter are less than they were with my blade grinder. If you think this machine is loud and messy, you just aren't a coffee lover. Makes a nice consistently sized grind, much improved. I use a medium grind (7) for drip filtered coffee and coarse (13-14) for my French press. Both come out excellently. So far no problems with the electric hum I read about in some reviews. Love this grinder!

reviews.reviewTitle: Fantastic value! High quality grinder for a much lower price
reviews.reviewText: I was initially a little worried about this grinder because when I bought it most of the reviews were from people who had gotten it to review. I was not disappointed at all. I love the grind quality and wide range of grind sizes this machine has. Some machines do not get quite fine enough for espresso machines, however, on this machine I find myself not going below setting 3 for my espresso. The machine is so easy to use, set the grind, press the button and you're done! Holds a full size bag of beans. Really like that the metal container the ground beans drop into has very little static, no need to clean with water since all the grounds come out with a small tap. Highly recommend this product.

This is so far the quietest grinder I've owned with the right price point. Settings are simple and very intuitive.
Ground sizes are consistent per setting with minimal static cling. The only issue I have is the timer knob which seems flimsy and may not last long. Time will tell. I will report back after 12 months.

This coffee grinder is way better than the last 3 similar units I have owned. The stainless steel metal collection chamber greatly reduces static compared to plastic and it's not breakable like glass. Remember I haven't had my coffee yet. I like how the timer is push button and the hopper is yuge. The design seems easier to clean and more durable but time will tell. The others broke after a year or so of heavy use... I really like coffee don't judge me. In fact I'm going to go drink some now.

I'd purchased a different burr grinder (Krups GS5000) and returned it. I needed it to use in my espresso maker. I've been learning to make latte art, and a good layer of crema is important, which means the coffee has to be ground fine enough. The Krups level 1 grind wasn't fine enough. This machine creates a nice espresso grind at a level 2 with the beans I'm using, which thrills me--even as the burrs dull, I should still get a good grind!

So far so good. Kind of pricey. Hope it lasts. Reserving judgment for the 5th star. Nice grind with lots of range, fine to course. I mostly grind for pour overs and for my Aeropress. Sometimes I notice it scatters grounds around a bit. It’s harder to keep the counter around it clean. I’m not sure why, but static electricity seems to build up and hold finer grinds on the walls of the steel container. It’s not easy to clean or take apart, but I haven’t had any problems with it clogging up, so I won’t have to take it apart often. 🤞

I previously owned a Mr. Coffee burr grinder which died after a year and a half after grinding coffee for one mug a day. The old one was loud and the critters got used to it. They were upset with this one being so quiet but have adjusted well. This grinder has no static cling on the grounds container which was a welcome surprise and much tidier.

All together this is a refreshing value of a well made appliance at a reasonable price point. Good job OXO.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not worth it - very uneven grind
reviews.reviewText: The grind is super inconsistent. Even on coarse settings it produces a ton of fines on the side, which clog the basket and cause brewing to take way too long, causing bitter coffee. My $30 Cuisinart was more consistent than this. I usually like oxo products, but this is the worst grinder I've ever used.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not for grinding full bags of coffee
reviews.reviewText: I really wanted to like this coffee maker - it had good reviews, the metal cup meant less static. But it simply didn't work for me. I buy large bags of Starbucks dark roast from Costco and this machine didn't like it. My first experience was grinding beans from an opened bag. Part way through the grinding process, the machine clogged up entirely. I tried everything to clear it but no luck. I had to take everything apart, wash them all, and put it back together. The instructions say that "old beans" might clog the grinder, so i tried a brand new, unopened bag. The unit stopped due to overheating twice and when i had 1/4 of the bag left, clogged up again - no amount of coaxing or prodding could get it to restart. The instructions also say "dark roast" might clog the unit. So i guess to use this, i have to switch to smaller bags and a lighter roast - easier to switch to a different grinder (which i did).

Love this coffee grinder. Coming off the heels of a blade grinder, this conical burr grinder feels like a dream. It’s much quieter, or at least doesn’t make an awful high pitched motor/blade noise. The other major plus is the coffee ground container is made out of stainless steel, which I think must reduce static electricity, because the grounds stay put and fall easily into place when transferred. Not like plastic containers which would literally create a thin layer of coffee dust all around the countertop when trying to get the grinds out. Looks nice and sleek too. Well done OXO.

This grinder is much quieter than my Cuisinart grinder . It grinds coffee without static cling which is a big plus. I would have liked the bean hopper to hold a whole pound of coffee instead of 3/4 lb. The timers longest setting is just barely long enough to do a pot of coffee in my pot which makes two of my 8 ounce cups . all in all this is a very good coffee grinder that grinds coffee to the size you like without all the fine powder grind you get with other grinders.

This is a solid, beautifully-built coffee grinder. It is easy to use, very fast and whisper quiet. The feeder has jammed only once, and that was on one of my first tries. No problems since, and I've been using it for a month. The timer is very consistent in generating the proper amount of grounds once you experiment with it -- within 2 or 3 grams. The timer setting dial could us some more friction, but it works fine.

I highly recommend this grinder!

Is a very good grinder, easy to use. Covers fine to coarse grinds. I use it mainly for our espresso machine. Settings can be adjusted for a french press as well. Works great for both. Turn the hopper to grind setting, set the grind time in seconds, hit the center button, then use. The grind cup is great have not had any static cling with the grinds. When I don't feel like manually grinding for the press, this is a very good alternative. Would recommend.

The beans got clogged in the burr grinder more quickly than I would have hoped. I do espresso (very fine grind) and although it did make a great fine grind, it clogged with chunks of beans in the grinder rather quickly and you had to take it apart to clean it even before it would do a whole hopper full of beans. Too bad.

I have had a number of coffee grinders in the past.this is an outstanding product, by far and away Superior to others I have tried. The grinder runs quietly and smoothly, and produces a very uniform grind. It can be calibrated to produce the exact amount of coffee you need for a pot.the ground coffee dispenses easily and the container does not get caked with fine powder. It does not clog up either. I am super impressed with the quality of this grinder.

I've had several coffee grinders, this one is tops. I don't know how well it will stand up for the long haul, but my out of the box experience was top notch. Once you tune it to your tastes you won't look back.

Static buildup is negligible, and it's pretty quiet by coffee grinder standards.

The gold standard for low speed conical grinders was in the $200 range and I just couldn't make myself do it. I just can't imagine what a $200 coffee grinder could do better.

After a month or so, this is still a honey.

For the price, this is unbeatable. Perfect coffee grind every single time. Been using it for several months now and haven't had any issues with it what so ever. Only nit pick here is that there is a slight drift in the knob used to set the grind duration while the grinder is actually running, caused by the slight vibration of the machine. Make the turning of this knob stiffer and this machine is perfect!

Had this for 9 months, worked great, then suddenly nothing came out of the discharge and the sound changed. I read a review from HedgeMedge (thanks!) that described how to un-clog the grinder. You need to empty the beans, remove the top canister, and then clean the grinds from the conical burr on top and then poke out all the compressed grinds from the discharge. It was amazing how much coffee was clogged inside. Do this over the sink with the grinder unplugged. I used a wooden chopstick so as not to damage anything. Now it works like new!

I don't have problem of beans not going into grinder as others say. The shape of cup is such that it's hard to drop all of the grinds into coffee maker without removing the lid. Thus one star off. Love the push button. A bit hard to set quantity dial to exact amount, once set, I taped the dial to one cup setting so it won't move out of place . Everything else is good. Better than the Capresso it's replacing.

I have only owned this grinder for a month, but so far it has worked well. Quiet, uniform grinds. Timer produced predictable amounts of coffee. I have had to clean the burr from coffee gum once already. In my experience this happens to all coffee grinders, fortunately The Oxo is easy to clean.

reviews.reviewTitle: Won’t find anything better at this price
reviews.reviewText: So happy I bought this one. Unbelievably simple to use. Literally turn the dial and press the button. Disassembling it for cleaning was super simple too. My only gripe is that I was the canister that catches the ground beans was designed differently, but it’s not a big deal. I just have to clean up every 5 or so times I use it. Takes about 30 seconds. Talk about a case of first world problems! I use this for French press and grinding beans for cold brew all the time and highly recommend it. Out of curiosity I set it up to grind very fine one time just to see how well it worked, and it was a VERY fine grind....I’ll probably never use it for that, but you could if you wanted! 5/5

I was very skeptical at first due to the small number of reviews, but I'm very glad I took a chance and ordered this machine. Easy to use. Very quiet. No static buildup to make a mess. I only use this for drip coffee, but the grinds are very consistent. A real bargain compared to some high end grinders. I've only had this a couple of weeks so durability is still an unknown, but so far this seems to be the perfect grinder for me.

I'm really happy that I bought this coffee grinder. I've bee. Using a hand cranked grinder for the past 10 years and though it did a good job, boy was I wrong. Using this grinder really makes my coffee taste so much better. It's quieter then other electric grinders I've had in the past and it doesn't make messes like all the others I've used too. Very clean and so many grind options. No more coffee grounds in my French press coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Powerful, easy to use, and no "static cling!"
reviews.reviewText: Upgraded to this grinder after using an inexpensive Capresso burr grinder for several years. The OXO is faster, FAR quieter, and produces a nice, consistent grind. Like many burr ginders, the Capresso used a clear plastic collection cup which took on a powerful static charge which made it difficult to empty and a pain in the behind to clean every time it was used. In contrast, the OXO has a metal collection cup which empties cleanly. Haven't tried to clean the OXO yet, so I can't speak to that; but apart from that, I'm thrilled with this grinder, especially for the price.

I purchased this in October 2018 and have ground a variety of beans ranging from dark/oily to light and they crank right through. It is easy to break down for cleaning; I would recommend getting a small brush. The manual doesn't tell you how often to clean it but I would sure take a look after every other use or so - old dust and grinds can affect the flavor of your new grind. This thing seems well-built and it has made world of difference in flaver over my old blade grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Soon much better than blade grinders!
reviews.reviewText: Do yourself a favor and get a grinder that will last longer than 5 of those through away 20$ blade grinders and get an even grind on your coffee, stop digging past the blades in the bottom of your machine for the last of the grounds. Quiet. Works well. You'll be glad you bought it.

From the beginning it would add super fine powder to coarse ground beans as well as leak the powder outside the receptacle cup. And now it makes a loud constant humming sound whenever it is plugged in.

UPDATE 9/3/19: As if it wasn't bad enough previously. Now this piece of sh*t will not pass the beans through the grinder at all. I am SO sick off all these junk products poorly made in China guaranteed to break.

We use to have the bodum burr grinder and coffee went everywhere with all the static. I disliked using it since it was so messy so had my coffee ground at the store. Finally the bodum broke and my husband like to grind his coffee fresh so after some research we purchased the oxo grinder. Can't be happier. Not too messy at all and different grind sizes come out great for our espresso vs our cold brew coffee.!

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder quit after one month of normal household use
reviews.reviewText: When I got this grinder I was very pleased. But a month later it doesn't work so it's going into the trash. It's clogged up inside and there's no easy way to access the clogged part. And yes, I followed the instructions faithfully. This was a replacement for a cheaper Cuisinart grinder that lasted just shy of two years. How much do I have to spend to get one that works and doesn't quit? If there's a way to contact Oxo and discuss it with them I was unable to find it. I do not recommend this grinder.

The first one had a constant electrical hum / buzz when plugged in, unlike any other appliance we have (but similar to the fluorescent lights). Thinking it might be a defective unit, I got a second one from Amazon. Same thing. Hope it's not a sign that there's something wrong with the electronics. Otherwise it works well.

This grinder from OXO is new. It's $100 cheaper than their $199 model with an integrated scale. Frankly,for the $100 difference I'd go with this one. You know it's the real deal based on the packaging alone. The owners manual is one of the best I've seen in a long time. As far as the product; I've only had it for a week, but so far so good. A HUGE upgrade from my old Cuisinart which died after a decade. I've made coffee on two of the 15 settings and both times the coffee was ground on the money. I think OXO has hit a home run with this grinder!

reviews.reviewTitle: A coffee snob will like it.
reviews.reviewText: Nothing to complain about. The coffee grouds are consistant, the noise level is much quieter than others i had bought. Best part is the stainless steel container. Most others have plastic ground containers that crack over time. I would buy this again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grind, but too many jams!
reviews.reviewText: I really like the way this OXO grinder delivers a perfect grind. The machine is relatively quiet, produces very few fines, and holds a lot of beans in the big hopper. It's easy to take apart, too, which is fortunate, because it doesn't want to process my French and Italian roast beans without jamming. Too bad, because you have to empty the hopper and take apart the grinder to clear the jam. Drier beans run well, but I like the big taste of the oily roasts. Perfection may be out there, but this isn't it!

reviews.reviewTitle: My second one. Hope this one works.
reviews.reviewText: The first one stopped in less than a month. Instead of doing warrant, I returned it, but then the price went up $20 to replace it. There are many things I like about it. Hopper holds a lot, no static cling, sounds nice, nice grind options, but I just hope it holds up better than the first. Keep your receipts and warranty info. Deducted a star because of history.

So nice how relatively quiet this machine is vs the Cuisinart burr grinder I had been using! Got clogged once in the 3-4 months I've had it, but probably only because I hadn't cleaned it. Also, I use dark roasts, which clog more easily, I read. Very happy with it!

I'm very happy overall with this grinder. The only issue I've had, and it's minor, is that some of the coffee as it is ground slides between the holding cup and the grinder body. I've made sure that the cup is inserted correctly and as snugly as possible, but still some grounds end up on the counter.

reviews.reviewTitle: Everything you'd expect from an Oxo product
reviews.reviewText: In the last 30 years I've managed to wear out three coffee grinders. Two Braun, good grind but a little messy and loud. One highly recommended Cuisinart, messy as anything, terrible grind and sounded like the tarmac at O'Hare (absolutely awful). Saw the brand and bought this one without ever reading the ratings. I was not disappointed. This is hands down the best coffee grinder I have ever owned. Not messy, the grind is excellent and it's remarkably quiet. You should probably buy one.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works OK if you have an air compressor
reviews.reviewText:
I have owned this for almost a year and am quite disappointed, particularly because of the price. I replaced a much less expensive Krups burr grinder simply because a plastic guard piece had broken and it would not operate without holding down the hopper.

It consistently clogs and will not produce more than a tablespoon of grounds without having to empty the hopper, disassemble and dislodge compacted grounds from accessible places. This typically occurs on busy mornings while trying to kids fed and out the door.

I used the air compressor that came with my nail gun to blow out the grinder, and that helped for a little while, but it needs to be done again soon.

Poor value at $100.

reviews.reviewTitle: I really like this coffee grinder
reviews.reviewText: I really like this coffee grinder. Our coffee tastes great and smoother than ever. It is very convenient to prefill the beans for the week. You set the amount and fineness of ground coffee to be dispensed and leave it at that setting. Just push a button and that exact amount will dispense each time, or you can adjust is based on how much coffee you are making.

Grinder produces very even sized grind for my French press, and nearly no fines, which I always had a problem with from my last grinder. Haven't had to clean it yet, but provided instructions seem simple enough. I'm glad I purchased this model over the less expensive ones. I've purchased quite a few Oxo products in recent years, and I when I shop for something, I always look to see if Oxo has the type of product I need. That says I've been happy with most of the items made by Oxo.
Amazon had to send me a replacement because the coffee grounds cup would not lock into place. My replacement workers like it should.

reviews.reviewTitle: Even grind, durable, nice build quality, and easy to clean
reviews.reviewText:
PROS
Simple, easy to use, gives nice even grind, and easy to clean.
The antistatic metal bin proved to be effective and prevents the coffee ground from sticking.

CON
A bit loud especially when I don't want to wake other people up early in the morning or late night.
The bin doesn't hold in place tight enough, it leaves a traces of ground on and around the unit over time.

The only thing I wish OXO would come up with is that the coffee bean container would have an optional divider /selector mechanism so that we can easily grind half-caf or full caffeinated beans or all decaf on the fly.
I'd pay money for that.

We had the Bodum Bistro Burr grinder (for our office) for 2 years. I always thought it did a good job (until the day it just stopped). UNTIL we got this grinder! Mind you, its only been a couple weeks. BUT it is WAY quieter. The FINE is twice as fine and the Bodum Fine. The ground coffee stays much more contained. The top hopper sort of clicks in place so i feel okay leaving a bunch of beans in there - rather than the Bodum which the cap just basically laid in place. AND its easier to clean. The Bodum looked cool but the rubber exterior was hard to get clean completely, i haven't cleaned the interior yet. Fingers crossed that it continues to work well!!!
The best by far. Rarely free spins, simple to use. No one wants to look at a computer screen at 5:30 in the morning. Great control of the grind and quiet. Go OXO or go home.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds well, isn’t nearly as loud as I anticipated.
reviews.reviewText: I’d been hand grinding my beans for years because I lived in a condo and didn’t want to use something crazy noisy when I make my coffee at 5 AM. So when I bought a house, this was one of the first appliances I treated myself to. It does a great job of grinding the beans and it’s nowhere near as loud as the electric grinders I’ve used occasionally in the past. I probably could have gotten away with using this in my old condo after all.

reviews.reviewTitle: Awesome machine. Performs like machines 3x the price.
reviews.reviewText: Worth every penny. Especially if you’re like me and grind 10oz at a time for cold brewing. Static is definitely reduced with this machine from smaller units. Wash the metal cup with soap and water before grinding to almost remove static when dumping the grinds into your coffee bin.

Once you get it dialed in for your preference of grind and amount then it doesn't get any easier and perfect. It grinds beans the best way (not a blade/chopper). Not sure what others are complaining about. This is a solid grinder. It's quiet. It's fast. It's easy to clean up. It's super easy to use. It looks good. The only aspect I don't know about it is longevity. I guess we'll see in time.

reviews.reviewTitle: Looks good but that is about all.
reviews.reviewText: This grinder has been a disappointment since I purchased it less than 2 months ago. While the grind setting dial moves it really doesn't seem to change the grind. It all looks fine grind, and I prefer a coarser grind. The feed is not always consistent. And to top all that off it stopped working less than 2 months after I bought it. The only thing that was as advertised is, that it was almost static free.

The burr grinder I had before this was much quieter (forgot the brand) but it also clogged. I was pretty shocked and annoyed at how loud this was the first time I tried it. Then , after a few weeks, it started to clog up also. However, this machine is very easy and quick to take apart and clean out the congestion.

reviews.reviewTitle: Better than the one I replaced that cost twice as much
reviews.reviewText: I replace a much more expensive coffee grinder that had basically “worn out“ after 10 years of use - this One was far less expensive in does the job beautifully with a very consistent grind plus I love the fact the container is actually UV protected so if you leave a few coffee beans and there you don’t have to worry

My 'top rated' $35 coffee grinder finally died - I never liked it, but didn't realise how much until I decided to spend a bit more on it's replacement and get what looked to be a better machine. So happy I did - such a better mornining experience: quite, clean, even grind, accurate measurement, easy controls!

reviews.reviewTitle: Just a push of the button
reviews.reviewText: After hand-grinding my beans for more than a year, this thing is a delight to use. With a little experimenting I found the ideal setting for a cup o' french press. If I need two servings, I just punch the button twice and use the larger press that I have. I like that the reservoir can be removed while still containing beans.

Updated 11/4. After a length chat and back and forth Amazon service provided an acceptable option for us. Upgrading the rating to 4 starts, 5 on service, 4 on grinder as we just got it.

We have a custom cabinet and measured the opening in the cabinet and were expecting this product to be 11.8" high as listed in the description on 11/2/19. It is not, it measures almost an inch higher. This seems like a small error, but was very inconvenient as it does not fit our custom cabinet shelf. We do like the grinder, and were willing to accept it and modify the cabinet. Unfortunatly, amazon customer service did not offer a concession that was acceptable given our required changes.

Consistently creates the grind you want, but unless you use the same coffee over and over, dialing in for weights can take a little bit depending on how oily your beans are. The timer though not completely free floating is easy to bump. I would rather have a knob with a small amount of resistance so it would glide instead of fly when turning the timer set. The size set is really nice, in fact if is my favorite part of this grinder. You have a very fine tunable grind sizing system that really makes the grind controllable. The hopper holds a sizable amount of beans. Over all I would tell everyone to buy this grinder for their home.

Revision wise, work on the timer knob!!!

So far I really love this thing. Didn’t give 5 stars because I haven’t used it for that long so not sure how it holds up. Metal bin really helps reduce static. The bin has a lid so much less ground coffee flying everywhere. Seats in place better than my previous one so coffee doesn’t get behind the bin. Nice, even grind. Great so far!
Clogs all the time. Horrible product. Working with amazon to return. Do not buy unless you want to spend 5 minutes jamming a fork into the chute unclogging it every time you want to use it.

Love this grinder! It works well, has an ok noise level and easy to maintain. The grind is perfect and even every time and our coffee has never tasted better. I put the beans in the grinder, set my time to grind and push the start button. Don't really have to do anything else but brew coffee afterwards. Fantastic product, very pricey but if you care about getting an even and consistent grind from your beans, invest in this.

This grinder has nice features, including having a hopper to hold beans making it easy to grind enough beans for each day's coffee. I have owned about 5 grinders and this one is definitely the most quiet when in use. I also like the stainless collector cup that the coffee falls into.

I love this grinder! Used it for the first time today and couldn't believe the difference from previous burr grinders that I have owned! It's quiet, grinds perfectly and doesn't stick to the stainless steel cup!

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to operate, the stainless steel container is the best
reviews.reviewText:
After reading reviews from many websites, I chose this because of the stainless steel container, and because the steel
conical burr grinder instead of ceramic. For me, it's not that loud when grinding, and you get a fine ground of coffee
even when you set it at medium. The timer is a real help, so you don't have to hold any buttons down, just touch and
it will shut of automatic. I have had no issue with grounds flying outside of container. Cleaning is not a real problem,
just turn the center burr grinder and pull it out and with the proper brush you clean off any build up in seconds. I recommend to anyone this product.

Like pretty much everything about this product so far. Very consistent grind. Not as noisy as my blade grinder. The coffee is much better with the conical burr, not nearly as acidic as my blade grinder. Love my coffee again. If you want coffee house quality do your research and get this grinder if your on a budget and you want great coffee without the high price tag.

reviews.reviewTitle: Probably the best conical grinder for under $100.
reviews.reviewText:
A lot of people complained about a mess...
Just tap the side lightly before pulling out the grounds cup = Never a mess.

Some people complained about the grounds not coming out right...
We've had no issues with this.

Some people complained about clean up...
The thing comes apart and is cleaned quickly and easily.

reviews.reviewTitle: Makes a great Grind, easy to clean, high quality.
reviews.reviewText: This has the heavy duty CONICAL BURR type grinder which is the one you want for a even grind. This grinder makes a wonderful even grind (see picture) effortlessly. The unit comes apart for cleaning and has a real heavy duty heft and build quality to it with nice stainless accents.

So easy to use; looks great on the counter. Took a couple of tries to get the grind size right for French press, but I love this machine. The canister collects all the grinds and I either put them directly into an airtight container or right into the French press. It's a little noisy, but you only have it on for seconds, so not an issue.
this is my first burr grinder. I am very impressed with how easy it is to use and how perfectly the coffee beans grind. Wish I had bought it years ago.

reviews.reviewTitle: Can't set it and forget it. Bad design.
reviews.reviewText: I bought this for convenience. Before this I used a blade grinder that required me to physically operate the machine while it was in operation. The goal with this machine was to be able to turn it on and let it run. This is impossible. If you turn the machine on and walk away, the container that catches the grounds falls out and grounds go everywhere!! You have to physically hold the container in the whole time it's running.

I love this coffee grinder! I replaced a 15 year old grinder that broke. The Oxo brand has rapidly become my go to brand for all things kitchen. This grinder was costlier than others but it’s worth every cent! I hope to have a very long relationship with it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not all coffee grinders are created equal
reviews.reviewText: I owned a Mr Coffee grinder prior to purchasing the OXO coffee grinder. The investment of a little more money was well worth it, which I think every time I use it! It is easy to use, much more quiet than the previous grinder, and yields a perfect ground coffee. There are multiple settings to choose from, and the grounds are well contained within the grounds container. I highly recommend!

reviews.reviewTitle: Quality is commensurate with price - not cheapest, not most expensive. Am pleased overall.
reviews.reviewText: This is quite easy to use, and I'm happy with the grind. Cleaning is a piece of cake, although I use compressed air to blow the parts clean - a procedure that I highly recommend.
