I leave it unplugged between uses, and so I can't comment on one complaint that I've read about it making an internal buzzing noise after awhile. Mine hasn't.

I was looking for a burr grinder for a while. Limited counter space and budget were limiting factors. Being clumsy I didn't want to fidget with a manual grinder first thing in the morning.

This grinder was a little quieter than my small blade grinder (can't hear it in the bedroom) which was a pleasant surprise.

Overall, the grind is consistent and I'm slowly experimenting with different sizes.

BONUS: The packaging for this product was fantastic and almost completely recyclable. There was the least amount of plastic film for a small appliance that I recall buying (one or so pieces) and were clearly marked with their plastic type.

The machine is a lot quieter than the old cheap grinder we used to have. It takes a large quantity of beans as well which is nice. The problem is that the SECOND time we used it, it worked for about one minute. Then it stopped grinding although the machine is still whirling. We tried to clean the machine the best we can but it did not help. Oh well.... returned to Amazon and shop for another one.

reviews.reviewTitle: My first burr grinder. Very impressed.
reviews.reviewText: This is my first burr grinder and I'm satisfied overall. It works well, provides an even grind, is reasonably quiet and looks good. My only knock is that the grinds container does not "click" into place like it should. Hasn't been a problem so far since I usually just grind directly into the coffee basket anyways. Oxo has another solid product in my book.

reviews.reviewTitle: Would stop grinding after a few seconds
reviews.reviewText:
It would stop griding after a few seconds after almost a year of use. It's a bit hard to clean (the residues inside the grinder) and the noise is quite high but overall it is really easy to use.

I messaged customer support about possibly looking into a replacement but haven't heard back from them.

We bought this for use with our Aeropress after trying a hand burr grinder. This is great. Super fast, easy, surprising how long the hopper lasts without needing refill. Coffee tastes good :)

Update: still working great for our home daily use. It’s been maybe 6 months and we have no complaints.

I've been putting off purchasing an electric grinder. I have only used manual ones, but it was time. Read a lot of reviews and thought I'd give this one a go. I like its size in that it is not huge. It grinds consistently. The container still has some static though. I'm happy with it. Will update as time goes by.

A long delayed upgrade from my previous low end burr grinder. Provides a consistently sized grind for my drip coffee maker and is relatively quiet. Easy to detach bean canister and top grinding element makes cleaning quick and painless with a brush. Stainless steel canister for grounds minimizes static attachment. Overall, a great design.

reviews.reviewTitle: From blade to burr -- this grinder is great!
reviews.reviewText: We were using a blade grinder and decided to go with this one after reading reviews. This grinder is awesome! Very uniform grind. The "anti-static" feature was the one surprise feature I didn't think I would like! It absolutely works! But the #1 feature from my perspective is the timed grind. I have dialed in the timed grind for my normal brewing amount (9 cups) and it is a great time saver: just push the button and walk away!

Very satisfied with this purchase. It consistently grinds the same amount of coffee and makes it easy to get a pot going each morning. Have run beans through it from different parts of the world and from different suppliers and it is all good.

I had a good Cuisinart flat burr grinder which worked ok but wanted to try one with a conical burr set and Oxo makes top quality stuff. Even tho the Oxo was more than 2X the price of the Cuisinart....I'm very satisfied. The Oxo is much better and worth every cent. Great grinder.

Our previous grinder had plastic receptacles, and grounds flew everywhere. This has stainless steel, and the grounds stay where they're supposed to be. We haven't tried different grinds yet, but are happy with the filter grind we're using.

Purchased this as a replacement for a Cuisinart (non conical) grinder which died. This grinder seems to grind coffee better, is very quiet, and the coffee brewed seems to taste richer/better. Also like that the conical grinder parts are made out of stainless steel and can be partially removed for cleaning.

JB

reviews.reviewTitle: Idle humming noise is annoying issue
reviews.reviewText: Humming noise device creates when idle, forces me to keep it unplugged when not used. Grinding itself doesn't have noise issues. So savings on transformer design (?) spoil this device.

It clogs badly after very few beans. I use Costco's Kirkland Colombian Supremo. Unfortunately the Kirkland Costco's grinders were out of service, so I purchased this unit Clogged up? :>) We tried every thing including cleaning the burrs with a toothbrush, but we gave up. It's being returned Monday. If it didn't clog up it is a great grinder.

I've been using the grinder for couple of weeks and it works great! It is so much easier compared to my manual Burr grinder and the consistency of the ground coffee is also good. I have no problems with clogging the machine or having beans stuck inside. But I'm always grinding beans only for one cup.

After having a blade grinder for almost 17 years, this is a major upgrade. I used to have to move to another room to grind coffee early in the morning, but this is relatively quiet in comparison to other grinders. My wife loves it!

reviews.reviewTitle: For perfectly brewed coffee, this is the one.
reviews.reviewText: I love how after only three days of adjusting the time and the grind, I now have the best coffee that I have ever had. I had balked at the price of burr grinders, but bit the bullet knowing I could return it should it not meet my expectations. Now I have to kick myself every day for waiting so long.

reviews.reviewTitle: Solidly built and consistent grounds every time.
reviews.reviewText: 2 weeks in and I am loving this machine. Comparatively quiet considering what it is doing. It does have some static cling issues around the rim with some grounds sticking to the exit container but not worth complaining about. Solid feel and very very even grounds. I have found 11 setting works best for my drip coffee maker needs just FYI.

I got this on sale a little while ago and it may be one of my favorite recent purchases. Quiet, consistent grind, no dust, and the anti-static grounding feature is so appreciated. I use a french press (and sometimes make cold brew) and this has been nothing but consistent every time. Highly recommended! The only drawback is figuring out the ideal time setting for your coffee device and preferences (yes I could weigh the beans every time, but really who has time or inclination to do that?). But other than that, this is great.

I needed to replace my Capresso connical burr grinder that I had for 8 years. This was a great product in regards to durability and consistent quality for size of grounds. I tried to buy again but Amazon states that there is a couple month delay. So I needed to find a replacement. I bought the OXO product for about the same price and have found that it is much faster, easier to clean, and the consistency of the grounds is just as good. Very impressed with this product and think it is a good value for the price for a connical burr design.

ZERO STARS. This product broke after 2 and a half months. I have tried to get customer support to no avail. No response to emails. I used it to grind beans once a day for 30 seconds only. It has never overheated. I cleaned it after every use. I never left beans in the hopper. The cord is not frayed. The product was plugged in when I tried to use it and it will not turn on. All the parts are securely fastened and put back together correctly. Do not buy this product. It is a waste of $100+ unless you don't mind grinding money away after 2 months.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not small enough grind for an espresso machine
reviews.reviewText: OXO, I have LOVED your products in the past. You have the NICEST design in the burr grinder market- solid, tidy, clear,... without the doofy weirdness of other burr grinders. Just as you have done these many years with simple kitchen gadgets, you created something that I WANTED to have on my counter....But your "fine" grind, is WAY too large for an espresso machine. Water pours through. Can't make a good cup of espresso with that large of a grind (and on the 1 too). PLEASE REMEDY THIS because I love your products and I'd buy a revised version, where the fine grind was made for an espresso machine!!

reviews.reviewTitle: OXO does not back their products - Used this once a day for 6 months and now it's worthless
reviews.reviewText: I like the grinder just fine until it stopped working. We used it once a day to grind enough coffee for one pot. Then, it stopped grinding and no matter how many times I took it apart and cleaned it, it wouldn't grind. I emailed OXO customer support twice with no response. Spent $100 on a coffee grinder that lasted only 6 months. Oi!!

Really good grinder for excellent tasting coffee. Experimented with the grind settings before settling on a more coarse grind, even for my drip coffee. Now, it's just a button push to get exactly the coffee i want.

Two down sides: it's loud and it's more messy than expected.

I don't know if this grinder is louder than others, but it's not quieter than my last two. The mess left from grinding is curious, with some grounds falling on the countertop. Every few days I give a quick wipe and it's fine, but wish I didn't have to. Still really good overall, though.

Excellent connical grinder. I have used this for about 6 months to grind fine coffee for espresso and coarse coffee for cold brew. If I have any complaint it's that it grinds much finer than I expected and it took a while to dial it in.

reviews.reviewTitle: grinds ok, but too small capacity and messy
reviews.reviewText: We need to run this 2x to get enough grounds to make a pot of coffee. Running for the full 30 seconds only makes enough grounds for about 7 cups of coffee. We had to always run twice in a row (40 seconds total) to make a 10 cup pot of coffee. This also spews grounds when you take out the grind holder. The grind is kind of uneven between desired grind and a fine powder.

An excellent grinder for coffee beans. Grounds are consistent, easy to use, and adjusting the grind level is simple. It is important to keep the metal cup in place or the grinds will fly all over the place.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Burr Coffee Grinder for the price.
reviews.reviewText: I was disappointed in the Cook’s highly rated coffee grinder so I found this OXO. What a difference! The grind is more consistent and the static electricity is almost (not 100%, but close) nonexistent. The OXO is much quieter, faster, and better.
Bought this as a Father's Day gift for my husband after almost 20 years of using a traditional grinder with blades and he was thrilled. It's so much quieter, easy to use, and makes a perfectly grind.

bought about a month ago, so far it's great. grinds fine enough for my la pavoni lever espresso maker, as well as medium for the french press. less expensive than the fancier bandsaw nd seems to do the same thing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Don’t buy this grinder if you want a life
reviews.reviewText: I could not hate this product more if you like dark oily beans don’t even think about buying this it stops working after even one time clogs clogs clogs . sorry life is too short to spend it cleaning a grinder i’m sending it back

It worked great at first, but this morning the grounds stopped flowing into the container even though the motor was running. I cleaned it out, made sure there were no blockages and then found that the lower burr was not spinning. The screw that you see sitting on top of the burr spins when plugged in and one of safety tabs depressed, but the burr itself doesn't spin. Apparently something must have broke in the shaft . Its one week past the date to return it back to amazon. I'll see if oxo warranty will replace it, but just thought I would post this now as a heads up to others.

We had a Cuisinart burr grinder for a few years, and I hated it. It made a terrible noise, and the plastic receptacle had terrible static which meant a daily battle with coffee grounds flying all over the kitchen. Happily, it broke down and I bought this Oxo product instead. It's quiet and sleek, and the stainless steel receptacle for the grounds pours cleanly, with no mess.

When I first got it, the grinder would not run all of the time when I pressed the button. Then it stopped working altogether. I tried cleaning it but still same result. What I’ve learned is I have to hold down on the hopper to get it run. Seems like bad product design.

It is quieter than the Mr. Coffee I had, but seems ridiculous to have to stand there and hold down on the hopper.

First, we’ve owned this grinder for a few months now. We have two other coffee grinders, one is a Bodum burr grinder and the other just a cuisine art, but this by far is the best! The ground wire along with the stainless steel container has kept the grinds from clinging, which is caused by the static, and in turn keeps it much cleaner. As for the grounds, they are more consistent and much finer than the other machines I’ve owned. Also, doesn’t spit out grinds all over outlet counter top! I highly recommend this grinder!
Very quiet, grinds very consistent. Doesn't make a mess like the other grinders I've owned. Very little static electricity. By far the best grinder I've ever owned.

Been using this to grind for cold brew and for my wife's reusable pods. I have ran about 8 bags of beans thru it so far. Her grind is a medium and mine is course so far it works perfect with zero issues.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder giving the grind size you want from espresso to French press!
reviews.reviewText: Great grinder. Allows for a full range of grind size and I love that you can just set it once for grind time and all you do in the morning is push a button. Perfect amount every time. Looks good on the counter next to my French press. Also cleans easily. Thumbs up!

reviews.reviewTitle: Improved the quality of our brew immediately!
reviews.reviewText: My wife and I had been using a small single pot grinder for years. We thought the coffee was good as it was always freshly ground, but the taste was inconsistent. Being able to set the grind and set the quantity allowed us to zero in on the best flavor and produce it consistently.

I bought this to replace an over $250 grinder that stopped. This one is quieter and grinds just as good. There is virtually no static buildup due to metal container so no mess on counter, I live in dry climate so welcome the lack of static. I use it daily. It did develop a hum as other reviewers mentioned. OXO replaced it with an updated model.
I LOVE this grinder! Easy to use and I love the adjustability of the grind. It’s a little noisy, but not too bad.

reviews.reviewTitle: Simple to use and outstanding customer service
reviews.reviewText: Relatively quiet, simple to use. Easy to disassemble and clean. The grind is spot on and very quick. Couldn't ask for more. Customer service was also very helpful in helping me to secure replacement parts so that I can have two hoppers.

I spoke with Oxo this morning and let them know what was going on with this grinder. The customer service was superb. They are sending me a new grinder. Yeah!!! Happy. Cause I really like this grinder. It is very quiet and I like the availability of fine tuning my grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worth Every Penny - Especially for Cold Brewers
reviews.reviewText: I make homemade cold brew every week. This is perfect. So much less time spent with stupid electrical grinders that grind too fine, or hand grinders that take too long. Money machine.

reviews.reviewTitle: Comes apart for easy cleaning, not much mess, easy to use.
reviews.reviewText: This grinder works efficiently and with minimal noise or mess. The parts come apart easily for cleaning. It is relatively tall but the design is sleek, modern. My only complaint is the maximum coffee grind is for 30 seconds, I have to grind twice to produce enough grounds for an 8-cup coffee machine.

Impressed by how heavy duty it is. Easy to use. Run time setting vs number of cups requires that you experiment a bit. 6 seconds is enoughfor 2 mugs of coffee. Unit is tall but but top continer can be removed easily for cabinet storage. When you undo the top container it also closes off the bottom so the beans don't pour out whch is a nice touch. Placing the grounds cup and out is surisingly easy. i.e. no fiddling around or having to place it in carefully yet it holds well.

reviews.reviewTitle: Oxo Brew Conical Brew coffee grinder
reviews.reviewText: This is an appliance that takes convience to the next level. You don't have to be a rocket scientist to understand the instruction book, the machine is easy break down and clean between grinds. It works very well grinding beans well enough to use in my reuseable coffee pods.

I was skeptical about the reviews, but I have to say, it's a great investment. Works as advertised, my coffee tastes great, it's easy to clean, and it's not too noisy. A must buy for ppl getting into coffee. My first one had some issues with connectivity, but got a replacement and it works great.

Pluses:
- Works great, no problem with beans getting stuck, nice looks
- Anti-static feature on the cup really does work well

Minus:
- Wish the timer had settings higher than 30 seconds, I usually need more for two big morning cups of coffee

reviews.reviewTitle: One year in..beans don't feed well into the grinder
reviews.reviewText: I've owned my grinder for a year now and have to say I love everything about it except that the beans now don't feed well into the grinder. The timer is set at 25 seconds and still won't grind enough beans for a full French press.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use and works great
reviews.reviewText: Replaces the capresso burr grinder of the same cost. That one is a ridiculous product by comparison. The Oxo has a nice timer to preset, just push button to start. Even better not a single coffee ground anywhere on the countertop, ever. Nice to see a product that some thought went into.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great coffee grinder for pour over!
reviews.reviewText: Love this coffee grinder. The hopper at the top is so convenient. Fill it up and set it and push the button and you have freshly ground coffee. I use for my pour over each day and it’s so great.
I like it a lot. It might be a little more heavy duty than I actually needed. But it a quality machine. Keeps most bean mess to a minimum, catches about 95 percent grounds. I like it.

The only downside I note for this grinder is the fact that it's loud. We would prefer to grind the coffee right before brewing. But if you get up early, before the rest of the family is awake this grinder is loud enough to wake people up. But, honestly, I think this is true for most grinders. The quality is great and it fits nicely on the counter.

This is my 1st grinder so I have no comparison. But it definitely works great. Relatively easy to clean. I imagine all grinders are noisy, no way around that. This seems to keep the noise at a very tolerable level. It has moderate noise pitch that isn't too bad. Meaning it's not a super high pitch noise that makes you cringe. It's more moderate, on par with a quality blender full of liquid.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good grinder but can set to # of cups wanted
reviews.reviewText: My last grinder you set to how many cups you wanted this one goes by seconds and if you want to brew a full pot you will need to run 2 cycles. I feel like I wate coffee because I throw away remaining grinds to ensure freshness

I use this grinder for my morning espresso at the fine setting as well as for its coarse setting for my French press. Does an excellent job across both settings. Like a couple of other reviewers my machine makes a low humming noise which is bothersome to me. I reached out to Customer Service and they confirmed that the machine is totally safe and that they were aware of complaints on some machines of the noise. They are addressing with future productions. Appreciated their responsiveness to my query and great that they are addressing.
This is a very good grinder. My coffee tastes better then it did w my other grinder. This one has many levels of grind and now I use less coffee for a perfect cup.
Absolutely the worst product ever. I followed every direction, but it keeps clogging up and not grinding coffee beans. It should not be this difficult.

Our first grinder in over 25 years because all we remembered was the chain saw noise from our previous one and it was horrible. Well, it’s not whisper quiet but it’s very tolerable and easy to use. And the coffee is SO much better when freshly grinding your beans. We just returned from Italy and can almost replicate the outstanding coffee we had. Very nice grinder and it’s highly rated by a consumer organization.

reviews.reviewTitle: Strong motor, cleaning due to build up a pain
reviews.reviewText: Works very well until it gets blocked up with grinds. Takes some digging around with a thin, bendable brush to get up clean so it will grind again. Love the large variety of grind sizes available

Finally upgraded! I did a lot of research on grinders and I’m so glad I got this grinder. I love how easy it is to clean. I also love how easy it is to adjust the grind. This grinder is so user friendly, twist how long you want the beans to grind push the button and pour into drip basket. The only thing I would like more a lot this grinder is if it was just a little bit quieter.

I bought this about six months ago and mostly I love it. It grinds perfectly and quickly with very little mess. It is a bit quirky though sometimes it won’t grind for the full time you set it and you have to restart it a couple of times. It’s easy to clean but kind of a pain.
All in all I would buy it again .

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder but not for espresso
reviews.reviewText: Very consistent and nice grinder. However, it doesn't grind fine enough for espresso. I grind at lowest settings (1) with fresh roasted coffee and its still doesnt generate enough pressure with 18 grams for double shot.

It has jammed on me 3 times. My son who is studying engineering has been able to get it going again. I never would have been able to. Everything else about it I really like about it. For the money spent I would never buy this grinder again.
We have a baby in the house and my husband runs this at 4am and it doesn't wake the baby. That's a BIG deal! He also says the coffee grounds come out perfect, so bonus - it does it's job! ;)

Seems like a finely built product. Love the cleanliness of a static-free grind. Can't speak to durability.

After a week of trying, can't get the grind fine enough to make decent espresso. No matter how tightly packed, the shot is depleted after 5-7 seconds and tastes weak. We can pull better shots with our spice grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works only when I shake it
reviews.reviewText: This wouldn't grind the beans unless I physically picked up the unit and shook it while the grinder was running. My guess is that gravity alone isn't sufficient to feed the beans down to the grinding burrs. I tried two different kinds of beans, one of which was exceptionally dry, not a sticky French roast which can get stuck in any grinder

reviews.reviewTitle: Look forward to coffee each morning.
reviews.reviewText: I first experienced using this coffee grinder at my son and daughter in law’s home. I ordered one before we returned home. I’ve heard people say, “If only coffee tastes like it smells.” Well with this grinder I can say it tastes like it smells! Great! I also like the versatility in making cappuccino and espresso blends. There is nothing like grinding your own coffee beans. There is nothing like having a really good cup of coffee!

Really easy to use, and well designed so that you don’t have to think (just dump the coffee and push a button!).
I was skeptical of the silhouette but it looks and fits in well with the rest of the kitchen, doesn’t occupy too much of the counter space, and is fairly easy to clean.
Simple to operate and no problems with clogging. Not much to clean since everything is enclosed. No regrets on this purchase. I paid full price and did not write this review as part of a promotion.

reviews.reviewTitle: Consistent grind size, can prepare coffee for many applications
reviews.reviewText: This product is relatively quiet compared to others I've used, and it gives a consistent grind size. I love the coffee made from the grounds it produces. Great product and so far it's durable (~6 months of almost daily use).
Works great. My only compaint is that there isn't a longer grind time. 30 seconds is good for a few scoops, but we like to grind for a few days at a time.

This burr grinder is being used at least three times a day and has been working like a champ, grinding out fresh roasted beans for espresso, drip and French press brews. I’m very happy with this product and would definitely purchase again. We looked at all of the burr grinders currently on the market and the OXO cleanly wins with exceptional performance for the price.
Quiet, easy to use, grinds coffee very well. So happy not to be annoyed by static cling and grounds everywhere of all my previous grinders!

This OXO brew grinder is incredibly easy to use and clean. However, you need to know one trick to securely attach the grinds bin to the grinder. Lift the bin up slightly (against the grinder) as you slide the bin in. This allows the latch pin to engage and click in place securely. Also, just remember that the time setting sets the amount of grinds.

reviews.reviewTitle: Almost perfect.... except the buzzing noise
reviews.reviewText: Unit was fine until a buzzing noise started a few months ago. Been using it for over 6 months with my pour over setup. For what it is, it's pretty good. Now I have to have to plug it in each morning so it doesn't buzz all night. It make me wonder if there's something faulty inside and if it'll cause a larger issue if electricity is being passed through. Not a huge deal but definitely an annoyance.
Easy to use, quality product, very quiet when grinding beans. Really makes a morning pot of coffee better, smoother, with a fuller flavor.

This grinder gives a nice consistent grind. I am still figuring out the timer and how long to grind for my pot of coffee. It's not too noisy compared to my previous burr grinders. I especially like the stainless steel cup that is meant to minimize static. It works well and there is not coffee all over the counter.

reviews.reviewTitle: Solid grinder for a good price.
reviews.reviewText: Have used this on a nearly daily basis since purchase. It's great. Gives an even grind, and I love being able to adjust the amount to what I need for my stove-top maker.

Have had two previous grinders and like this one the best. Reasonably quiet, nice features and static to the ground coffee and plastic container is minimal. It may be a bit more expensive but was worth it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best decision i've made in a long time
reviews.reviewText: I was a skeptic, and ground my beans by hand in one of those silver rod shaped conical grinders. This thing is awesome. Much quieter than blade grinders. Very easy + accurate coarseness selector. Mess and static cling is whatever (definitely not a deal breaker). Been using it daily for a few months now and still love it.
The high reviews were right on. This is not perfect, but it's FAR better than the three others I've used over the years. Unless noise is a problem, GET IT. You won't be disappointed.

I thought my old Cuisinart burr grinder was much better, and was 1/3 the price. With this one, I have to hold the cup in place or it moves out and stops before the coffee is done grinding. Very annoying.
Love this! It is very good quality, professional, and the sound is smooth and quiet. My old one was a Braun and was extremely loud. It also very consistent with the amount you t grinds.

Absolutely does what it's supposed to.
Most of the negative reviews I read are completely ridiculous.

This grinder not only delivers perfectly ground coffee every time, it is very quiet and easy to clean. No static build up, coffee grounds go from the container to my French press without any spills. I highly recommend this grinder. It's wort every penny.
This is easy to use and gives you lots of flexibility. Grinds beans evenly and very quickly. Cleaning is simple. Ts as good as coffee mills for twice the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use - good grind selection.
reviews.reviewText: A bit on noisy side. But it lasts for just a few seconds while grinding. I can deal with it. Easy to adjust grind to the fineness you want.
Perfect. No flying coffee grounds to wipe up after removing the metal container with freshly ground beans.. Quiet, very easy to use, stylish.

I love this grinder. Definitely upped my coffee game! Only needed a few test grinds to find the perfect coarse grind setting for my French press. Love the stainless steel base cup - reduces static and is easy to keep clean. Definitely recommend.

I've tried a number of grinders, some at higher prices than this one. They all have plastic bins and thus all create static electricity. This one has a stainless steel bin and does not do so. It takes all the cleanup hassle out of grinding coffee. The grind adjustment and timer also work well. This is a superior product.
Made my espresso making life so much easier! Very consistent, not too loud. Love it!
I really am happy with this purchase it grinds the coffee very nicely very even grind every time also very easy to use and it’s not to loud I would recommend this product to anyone

We love to make French Press coffee each day. This OXO grinder has brought our morning coffee to a higher level. The machine grinds only the amount we have set the machine for. After the first setting, no more thinking is needed. Quality is always the same - perfect!

Item came extremely well packaged. First impression was that this product was very well designed and manufactured . Operating couldn’t have been easier. If this product holds up as well as it looks, it will definitely be 5 star ++. Love the looks and it is quieter than the one I was using before.
A simple and powerful grinder that provides a very consistent grind. The grinder is relatively quiet and fast - two and a half tablespoons of beans take less than ten seconds to grind
I love how conveniently it allows you set up everything and holds 3/4lbs of coffee beans, so all you have to do is press a button each time you want a freshly ground cup of coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good but clogs up every handful of months.
reviews.reviewText:
All good, not as even a grind as I'd hoped, but it is solid.

#1 complaint I have is that it here's clogged.

has it all- grind size adjustment, amount adjustment, storage hopper, and burr grinder so no heat
No static build up. And is much quieter than a blade grinder so others can sleep

reviews.reviewTitle: solid, simple and not as messy
reviews.reviewText: The metal cup is so much better than plastic common in other models as it minimizes the static mess issue. Don't know why other brands use plastic.

It seemed to work fine at first but I have found that it frequently clogs up with grounds. The manual says this can happen so I follow the process to unclog it, but this is happening nearly every time I use it, and it makes a tremendous mess unclogging it, which defeats the purpose of having a coffee grinder!

reviews.reviewTitle: Gets the job done at a good price
reviews.reviewText: I cannot think of a dislike for this product. Gets the job done. Grind size is consistent, and very easy to adjust. It is easy to clean, and a good price.
I’m assuming the durability is good as we’ve have it a couple of months and it hasn’t broken. Definitely easy to clean. Grinds fine for espresso perfectly.

I use this grinder every day for making different types of coffee drinks. Easy to clean and adjust. Really happy that I made this investment that enables me to get the freshest coffee at home every day.

reviews.reviewTitle: Switch up your brewing method with the turn of a dial!
reviews.reviewText: I can't believe that I haven't had a grinder like this before. Love it and the versatile grinding options are wonderful.

Upgraded from the Cuisinart burr grinder which was super loud and inconsistent. This is not top shelf grinder, but it does a fantastic job and the grind settings are easy.

The timed grinding control isn't ideal, but you get used to it.

No mess on the cup since it's metal - no static!
Strong and grinds great
Bought it for my sisters birthday. She loves it and loves how simple it is to get fresh ground coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder! Grounds container could be better...
reviews.reviewText: It quiet (for a grinder), it's fast (but not too fast), and it has pretty good grind consistency. I haven't had any feeding problems, as other reviewers have. However, the grounds container to not click into place. Otherwise I'd give this grinder 5 stars.
Disappointed by the very inconsistent grind size. Large chunks of bean make it through on the finest setting.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good grinder needs a slight improvement.
reviews.reviewText: Quite and grinds well. Timer switch needs improvement moves out of position easily. Other then that good quality and nice grinder.
Nothing but clogs every single time we have tried it. Different amounts of beans, different roasts, different settings between fine and coarse. Has clogged every single time.

reviews.reviewTitle: works really well, much better than the blade types
reviews.reviewText: Doesn't add much time to my morning coffee preparation and I think the coffee tastes better when I grind the beans myself.

I get coffee grounds all over the place with this grinder. The cup is shaped in a way that it is ready for the cap the become twisted. If this happens it doesn't for into the grinder right and coffee will be all over the pressure of the cup.
disclaimer - it's my first burr coffee grinder, so no much comparison, but love it! saves me time every morning, and great even grind.
It is much quieter than my other, it looks great, grinds evenly, it is grounded and has a metal receiving cup. No more mess with flyaway grindings!
Tried few including the fancy brands and this one is definitely cleaner and easier to use. The tray is metal and dumps right in without much mess.
It is quiet, grinds well. But it is messy!! Grounds get all over the place. I will kepp it but I would not buy again.

I got this for my husband for a gift. He immediately started showing me the benefits of how easy it is to clean and how consistent it was on the grind. We went off the recommendation of where to set the settings but it was a bit strong for me so we adjusted but it was nice to know where to start. I would recommend this grinder!
Its quiet easy to adjust amount and ground coffee doesnt stick to container like we used own cuisinart.

My grinder of many years finally gave up the ghost. Did lots of research before choosing this one. Very upscale look and works great, no matter what grind you prefer. I'm really picky. I like things that last.

After reading many reviews on Amazon for this coffee grinder I decided to go for it. This purchase was to replace a "BODUM" burr grinder. The Bodum lasted only about 5 years of daily use . The motor froze.
So far I love the OXO! It feels very powerful. Easy to use. And appears to be made well! I totally recommend this grinder for home use!

Very good grinder overall. Very even and repeatable grind. A little noisy on a quiet Sunday morning before the rest of the family wakes up, but much quieter than the jet plane roar of a blade grinder. Very little static generated with just a few grounds clinging to the cup. Easy to shake them loose. Not to difficult to take apart and clean. Worth the purchase.
Great coffee grinder! Grinds coffee beans perfectly for your specifications! Very easy to operate and cleanup is a breeze!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great product. Easy to use. Minimal learning curve.
reviews.reviewText: I've only used this on coarse mode and it does a great job. Not too difficult to learn how to remove the pieces with the included instructions. It's a bit difficult to clean the main housing unit of coffee grind, but with a soft brush, it works pretty well. Best to clean it after every use to keep from any build-up.

Had it for a month, don't understand the complaints. Quick, not excessively loud. Nice even grind (very adjustable). Already had a cooking scale, sits on the counter next to the grinder. Hasn't jammed once. Timer will run out on a large grind, so you will have to hit the button twice. Great purchase.
Does a good job grinding. The timer is a little tricky to get right. Noise is better than a blade style grinder, but it's still pretty loud.
I really like this grinder. It may not be as heavy duty as other more expensive grinders, but it does a very consistent job and seems to be a good value for the money. Hoping it lasts!
Not my first attempt at obtaining a grinder capable of coarse French press coffee but it will be my last... No need to look further, this one is it... Awesome!!
I love the ease of use. It is a breeze to change your grind size and the stainless steel canister makes clean up simple.

reviews.reviewTitle: It is very easy to operate.
reviews.reviewText: It grinds to any specific grinding that one would like, you set it and forget it. An excellent product.

reviews.reviewTitle: The best grinder we've ever owned.
reviews.reviewText:
Our third Cuisinart burr grinder gave up the ghost and instead of replacing it again, I read the reviews and decided to try the OXO. It was more expensive, but my husband tells me every morning "I love this grinder!"

So far we haven't found a con.
Nothing bad to say!!! It’s beautiful in design, easy to use, quiet and makes the smoothest, most delicious coffee!!! Noticeably better than our non-conical burr grinder which was more expensive!

Pricey upgrade to replace my old one. The metal canister is great, because it dissipates static. So now I can grind and brew right away, rather than having to wait, or worse, stir my grounds with a metal utensil.

The hopper is plenty big.
The chute opens straight down into the canister, so no need to tap it to get the last bit of grounds to fall.
The timer stays put, and you press the button to grind. So you don't have to mess with it every day to get a consistent grind.

The only, minor, downside so far is that the timer doesn't quite go long enough for me. So when I want a full pot of strong coffee, I have to run twice at 20. When turned all the way up to 30, the canister is only about half full, so there's room for longer grinds. The dial just doesn't go high enough...

But I'm happy, and wouldn't choose anything else out there at this price...

This is the first burr grinder we've bought, but it's 1000% better than the blade grinder we've been using for years. Seems quiet to us, feels very well made, churns out nicely ground coffee as much or little as we need. Also looks spiffy on the counter and doesn't take up too much room. The price seems good for the apparent quality - we'll be surprised if it doesn't last us years.

I don't fill the hopper because I like to vary the type of bean I use from time to time, and instead want to grind only as much as I need at a time. The problem is that once you press the button, it runs for 1-2 seconds and then stops (update again because people seem to think that I don't know there's a timer: this happens with all timer settings - even to the max time). This continues until it gets a nice groove going and finally grinds all the beans. I'm happy with the grind size, but, for ~$100, I'd think OXO could do better.

Update: The problem with it not grinding through the whole time is getting worse. Even more, it doesn't respond to the first 2-3 button presses to start grinding (and this is with a good amount of beans in the hopper). Likely to return (perhaps mine is a dud?) as there are grinders that can do the same job at this price range.

reviews.reviewTitle: Review of noise, grind time, static, etc.
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this for a couple months now and I used it several times a week. I've had no issues with it, and I feel like it does a great job grinding.

Noise: It does make some noise, but no more than I anticipated. It's not obnoxious or anything- its maybe slitghtly more noisy than my blade grinder was.

Ease of use: Very easy to use--you choose your grind size and time and push the button. I've read about people having issues with the container coming out as it grinds, but I haven't had that issue. I do press it snugly in place. There isn't an actual 'click.' the container is metal, and there's a little metal bar that senses the containers place. The click is really just the sound of the two pieces of metal touching. It did take me a couple of days to figure out how many seconds I needed to grind for the amount of coffee I'm making. On my grinder it seems that it's about 4 to 5 seconds per cup of coffee.

Static: there is a little static, but not anymore than I anticipated. I never have coffee grounds all over the counter, but they will cling to the inside of the canister. I usually let it sit for a couple seconds after grinding and I don't have any issues.

Overall I'm very pleased. It's what I expected from a mid-range grinder. A lot nicer than the crappy $30 ones you can buy, but maybe not as fancy as something that cost twice as much. I'm very happy with it and I highly recommend it!

reviews.reviewTitle: unground beans and ground coffee left inside grinder
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this grinder from Amazon via a different listing that included a sample package of coffee. The grinder works, but not as well as the reviews appear to indicate.

First, no matter how long you run the grinder, a few whole beans are left just above the grinder mechanism (hidden, you can't see them in the hopper). Second, some ground coffee is left inside the grinder---it falls out if you lift the whole thing up and slam it down several times on the counter, but otherwise it stays until the next use.

The net result is that when you grind coffee, it includes some stale material from the previous use. This is particularly a problem if you are grinding a small amount every day, say 2 cups, because the percentage of stale material is large.

reviews.reviewTitle: I'm impressed and always love OXO's attention to detail and quality!
reviews.reviewText:
I received this as an early birthday gift yesterday. I've been using a small Krups blade grinder for years. About a year ago I tried replacing it with a capresso infinity that out of the box did not want to register adjustments in grind size. So back to the Krups I went.

I've been in search of the perfect burr grinder for a while now. As I'm sure you've noticed, there is no perfect grinder. They all have their quirks, drawbacks and issues. Being that the OXO just came out recently, I'll admit I was a tad skeptical. But I had seen others in the coffee industry comparing it and really talking up its quality and ability to kick It with some of the more expensive grinders out there.

Now, if you're accustom to using a blade grinder and pulsing the blade, this will be much much different. There is a bit of a learning curve and adjustment period to dial in the proper grind size and timing the grind for the amount you need for each brew. I'd recommend using a cheaper coffee to go trough the initial setup process for the sake of not burning through a bag of specialty coffee.

**When initially adjusting, you can dial in the grind size with no coffee in the hopper. Once coffee is in the hopper make sure to only adjust the grind size when you are grinding to prevent jamming the burrs!

For me, the perfect grind setting for a chemex/pourover brew is one tick over 11 between medium and coarse. I have a 10 cup chemex and typically brew about 24oz of coffee at a time. So I use approximately 42.5g off coffee which with the oxo is about a 13 second grind. Without getting too into the process I use 730g of water, with your typical 30-45 second bloom time and about a 4 to 4 1/2 minute brew time. You'll certainly be able to tell the difference in taste, consistency and brew time over a blade grinder.

For those asking or wondering if it's good for espresso, I have not tried this yet. I may not try it because I have another grinder specifically for espresso that works well enough for me not to fuss with adjusting the oxo to do the same.

One thing I will note about the "anti static" stainless container. It's certainly not anti static so to speak, but it is less static then plastic grind bins. If you let the ground coffee sit for a minute or two and give it a few taps it all mostly settles and pours out clean. Directly after a grind there are fines that cling to the sides and lid, but are not all that difficult to pour out with some patience.

As with most burr grinders there is some retention of beans in the shoot that don't make their way out. So you may have to give it a little tap to get all of your grounds out into the bin. Otherwise, they may end up on your counter. I'm not talking copious amounts of coffee will come pouring out. It's probably just a gram or two at best.

The OXO is also fairly quiet. I have no way of measuring the decibels. However, in comparison to a magic bullet blender, this thing whispers.

Overall I'm impressed, it delivers where I really need it to. My primary intended use will be with pourovers like the chemex, and my aeropress. If I discover anything out of the ordinary or perhaps end up trying it out for espresso, I'll update my review!

*Always make sure not to use over roasted, old or oily beans. They just don't do well with burr grinders. Much less, that's typically a sign that the coffee is bad. Shoot for matte beans that are as fresh as possible to avoid clogging the grinder and shoot!

For a while now, I've wanted to try to make my own cold brew coffee at home. But in order to do so, you need coarsely ground coffee which is nearly impossible to achieve using one of those ubiqitous mini-grinders. I currently have two (Braun and Kitchenaid) and have had no luck regulating the type of grind. Not to mention that they only grind a small amount of coffee at a time, making the whole process extremely labor intensive. My local Stop n Shop used to have a large grinder for whole bean coffee, but they removed it ages ago (probably over sanitary and/or safety concerns). So it looks like my dreams of cold brewing at home are fading.

Then I was offered the opportunity to try this OXO Conical Burr Coffee Grinder.

This is extremely intuitive and easy to use. I didn't even have to read the instructions. The clear plastic reservoir holds an entire 12 oz bag of coffee beans (the standard size sold by Starbucks, Eight O'Clock, Dunkin Donuts, etc.) and can grind the entire thing in no time. It can create anything from Coarse to Fine simply by turning a dial located directly beneath the reservoir of whole beans. You can set the grind time from one to thirty seconds after which it automatically shuts off. About eight thirty second increments will grind an entire bag. The stainless steel cup that catches the ground coffee needs to be emptied about halfway through the process.

It's very sleek and attractive and while it isn't absolutely enormous (only slightly narrower than a standard auto-drip coffee maker) it does take up counter space. Since it's not a gadget I'll be using everyday, I intend to stow it out of sight.

But most importantly of all, the flavor of coffee made from freshly ground beans is phenomenal. Both my husband and I can really taste the difference. I can't wait to make my own cold brew.

reviews.reviewTitle: I changed from a Cuisinart to this machine.
reviews.reviewText:
The Cuisinart machine had one big problem: STATIC. when I would open the plactic bin the grinds would fly all over the place and stick to anything that was charged: (mostly me). It would stick on the plastic bin until I'd tap it and the grinds would go even farther... the floor, the counter, me..
But this machine doesn't have that problem. When I pour the grinds into my coffee maker the grinds just slide out. !!
I LOVE THIS !!!
The other machine I had for a few years got clogged finally (I had changed to an oily roast of starbucks). and I didn't know what was wrong. So for all you people? your grinder WILL CLOG !! (esp if you have an oily roast). I"m pretty sure they all do this.
I like this machine better for two other reasons:
1. It's much quieter.
2. The size of the coffee grind is consistant (much more than the Cuisinart grinder. (It was a disk grinder, not a conical grinder)
I've only had this for a week so it hasn't had time to break or get clogged. so that's my disclaimer.

Coffee is serious business in this household. Until purchasing this unit, I had been using a manual hand turned grinder every day because I found the process to be cathartic. Those days are over.

I brew my coffee with a french press and notice big differences when making the most subtle changes to the grind size and amount used. This unit allows me to make very small changes to the coarseness settings and dial in the exact taste I want (the pictures show my perfect french press settings). The product has been very well thought out and works perfectly.

Initially I wasn't sure how many seconds worth of coffee I needed so I took the amount I would normally use to brew a pot in the french press and dumped it into an empty hopper and timed how long the unit took to grind the entire amount. Turned out to be 13 seconds so that's what I set the timer to. Now I dump a full pound of coffee into the hopper and whenever I press the grind button I get the perfect amount. Since I go through about a pound a week I don't worry about storing the beans in the hopper since I use them quickly. You shouldn't store coffee in the unit for long periods because it is said it can affect the taste especially if it is exposed to sunlight. A week has been perfectly fine.

Next I experimented with the coarseness and found just under a 14 setting to be the best for full flavor without bitterness when using my french press. Check the instructions if you are using other methods. I think this will be the correct setting for Chemex too. I haven't bothered inspecting the grinds for size consistency. To me, taste and consistency is what counts and this produces both.

I don't bother cleaning my unit at all since I use it every day. Since the collection cup is made of stainless, static isn't an issue. I just give the cup a couple of taps and 99% of the grinds come out, or you can just give it a quick rinse after use. I don't bother and can't taste the difference.

While there are cheaper units available, I wanted something that was quality since I use it every day. I rationalize spending a little more by saying it's something I use every day. I'm 100% pleased with my purchase.

I had a cheap black and decker burr grinder and thought I was okay. What a difference the correct grind is to have make your coffee. The OXO burr grinder is sweet. It produces a fine grind for my aeropress and course grind for my french press. It is relatively quiet and couldn't be simpler to use. The only problem might occur is to change the grind settings is a little stiff. Cleaning is easy as the coffee bin is easy to remove. There is very little static but there is a little cling at the very bottom of the cup that can be shaken/tapped to removed. I do like it and would recommend it. The coffee bin is large enough to fit one bag of coffee perfectly. It is a well thought out product and think I made a great choice here.

reviews.reviewTitle: Most Disappointing Coffee Product I Have Ever Purchased
reviews.reviewText:
To be as blunt and simple as possible, the OXO BREW Conical Burr Grinder is the worst product I have ever purchased online through Amazon. Furthermore, my wife has been in contact via email with OXO's customer support team about the poor quality of this product, and their support team refuses to either refund or replace the product. We have provided them with both videos and photos showing that the unit functions either very poorly or does not function at all without lots of troubleshooting. Yet, their engineers have responded saying that the unit appears to be functioning "normally" in the videos (one of which I will attach to this review). However, at this point the unit does not work without quite a bit of frustration--plugging and unplugging multiple times or sweeping out the burrs multiple times just to grind enough beans for a pour over coffee. Even though I have only owned this unit for one month, I see no other solution than to place this unit in the trash and buy a more expensive unit from another manufacturer. I am an avid home coffee brewer, and I have owned other coffee products from Bonavita, Hario, Mr. Coffee, Cuisinart, and OXO. I can say unequivocally, this OXO burr grinder is the worst coffee product I have ever owned or purchased. I will attach video and photographic proof that the unit does not work correctly and will explain further below the problems with the unit.

Initially, the unit worked great. For the first week, the unit produced a reliable and consistent grind of Trader Joe's Ethiopian beans (~$8.99 a bag). Then, the trouble started the second week when I began grinding Stumptown Hair Bender beans (~$15.99 a bag). The unit jammed mid-cycle for the first time. The button on the front of the unit would not start the motor so I tried troubleshooting the unit in multiple ways, following the instructions in the owner's manual. I unplugged it and plugged it back in--start button still did not work. I opened the bean hopper and nothing appeared jammed. So finally I opened up the burrs and swept them out. When I put the unit back together, it worked, and I thought the problem was solved. However, over the next week, the unit kept jamming every time I used it with the Stumptown beans. Sometimes it would jam multiple times in a row. Each time I had to open the unit and sweep out the burrs to get it to work. This process, while being extremely frustrating and time-consuming, also caused the unit to produce an inconsistent grind size. I've attached a picture showing that I get chunks of beans in my pour over because I have to play an elaborate game with the machine just to get it to function. For a unit that regularly retails for around $100, this is absolutely unacceptable for a new product. Furthermore, if a $100 burr grinder cannot be used on a premium product like Stumptown, then that grinder is entirely worthless to coffee enthusiasts.

After I finished the bag of Stumptown coffee, I tried the grinder again on the Trader Joe's beans (since those beans had initially worked well with the unit). Now, I began experiencing the same problems with Trader Joe's. In order to grind 5 scoops of beans for one large pour over coffee, I had to either: (1) Open and sweep the burrs multiple times or (2) Plug and unplug the unit multiple times because it grinds for about 3 seconds before jamming even when the timer is set on 30 seconds. I have attached a video showing the unit functioning in this way. In the video, you will see the game I have to play just to grind beans using a unit that was purchased only 3 weeks prior.

Here's my personal thought regarding the performance issues of the machine. I assume the motor has a fail-safe feature designed to stop the motor in event that it becomes clogged. This would prevent the motor from being damaged if a very small stone or an extremely hard bean got stuck in the burrs (which can happen on a rare occasion). My guess is that this setting isn't quite right in my unit and that the unit stops every time there is the tiniest bit of resistance on the motor. This would explain why I have to unplug the unit multiple times just to completely grind a cup of beans. Either way, it is entirely unreasonable for OXO to expect users to have to troubleshoot a new unit with such frequency as a part of the unit's "normal" functioning.

Currently, OXO does not want to address my concerns with this unit so I have decided to place this negative review. I've never felt compelled before to write a negative review on Amazon. Hopefully, they will decide to improve the product and respond to customer concerns. At this point, I cannot recommend this product to any other buyer, and I will no longer purchase any kitchen or coffee products manufactured by OXO. Finally, I've decided I don't even want a replacement for this unit. Even if OXO offered to replace it, I would refuse. That alone shows my level of disappointment with the product. The overall build quality feels cheap to me, especially the timer and start button on the front. I owned an entry-level Mr. Coffee burr grinder (~$30) for 7 years that "felt" better--button quality, weight of product, sound of motor, etc. If OXO decides to respond to my concerns, I will only accept a full refund for the purchase price of the product so that I can purchase another unit from a different manufacturer.

UPDATE: OXO finally agreed to refund us the purchase price of the unit after I posted this negative review and video on Amazon. The refund process took some time, but we did eventually get a check in the mail for the full purchase price of the unit. We will explore other options for a replacement unit.

Good price, not too loud. I bought this grinder to replace my Cuisinart. It's a clear improvement from that machine. I balked at paying $200+ for a conical burr grinder, so was happy to find this more reasonably priced OXO model. It has a small footprint and isn't very loud.

Just OK:
The grind range seems to be good. I use it primarily for french press, pour over, and drip machine, so haven't tested it at the smaller grind settings. The grind consistency isn't great but isn't bad either. You can see in the image that the grinder is less consistent at larger grind settings.

Cons:
Not as easy to use as advertised and rather messy. There are three things I dislike about this machine: grind capacity, static cling, and spitting grounds out.

In terms of ease of use, OXO claims it has a "One-touch start timer" and "Grounds container accommodates up to 110 grams (enough for 12 cups)." While you can certainly turn the grinder on with one touch, it isn't possible to grind at or near maximum capacity with just one touch. You have to push the button twice because the longest grind duration of 30 seconds is insufficient. I can usually get 60-75g per button push at a medium grind (obviously this will vary some with bean type and grind size). This means I can't just turn the machine on and walk away while it grinds.

It's a messy grinder. The stainless steel receptacle doesn't sit flush with the machine. Even if you push the container back as far as possible, there's a gap where the grinder spits out grounds, making for a messy counter and wasted coffee beans.

Static cling: The stainless steel container/plastic lid combo creates static cling (despite OXO's claims to the contrary). This is the most frustrating part of this machine. The coffee grounds cling to the container, especially to the curved lip. The static cling is so bad that you can't just pour out the ground coffee onto a scale or into a brewing device, as I used to do with my previous grinder. I have to use a scoop to transfer ground coffee to a scale if I want to weigh out the right amount. Keeping the plastic lid on or taking it off doesn't make much of a difference. If I want to fill a pour over filter with ground coffee, I have to scoop the grounds a couple of times then tap the stainless steel cup to release the static cling and get the rest of the grounds to fall to the bottom of the container. This is a pain.

All in all, this grinder is a clear improvement on cheaper models but not nearly the level of performance I expected at this price point.

I'm a big fan of OXO products. Overall I find them solidly built, thoughtful, and functional. This grinder is no exception. My only gripe is that the grounds container doesn't always stay put when grinding. It's a little finicky. Maybe I got an odd one? If not OXO should work on the design of that part a bit.

Other than that, I'm happy. Not too loud for an electric grinder, and whatever anti-static measures they've taken seem to work well. Very few grounds stick to the cup and what does is probably more moisture related than anything.

Fresh ground coffee with the consistent sized grind of a conical burr is one of the best things you can do for your coffee. I'm using the same approximate amounts I was when using a whirling blade grinder, but my coffee is so much better, and no sludge. If the goal is "wet sand" the whirling blade grinder would give me a mix of powder and boulders. With this grinder everything is the same size, so I don't have some that's so fine it gets through the filter, or some that's so large it isn't extracted well. Even the crema looks better.

I finally replaced my junky Cuisinart DBM-8 with this OXO grinder. MAN what a difference! I've always been happy with OXO products, they seem to always have a higher level of quality than the rest of the mainstream consumer grade products. True to OXO, this is a quality product. Don't listen to the reviews that complain about only having a time setting for the grinder instead of an amount. Once you dial it in for your particular beans and pot, it's just a touch of one button. I literally hated the DBM-8, which is NOT a conical burr grinder. Instead, it uses 2 flat grinding wheels which are screwed into cheap plastic that will eventually break rendering the grinder useless. It also had a terrible problem with static in the coffee grounds making cleanup a major task. This OXO grinder has none of those problems and it's a joy to use. There is literally almost zero cleanup required. I also noticed a lot of people complained about the beans needing to be "stirred" to go through the grinder. That may be a problem with some of the super oily beans you get from like Costco, etc., but I don't use oily beans and haven't had this problem. I use a variety of beans, but mostly Trader Joe's French Roast as a daily go-to.

I use an Aero Press and my recipe for that is: grind for 21 seconds on #5, 2 paper filters in the Aero Press pre-wetted, 75 ml water off-boil to bloom the grounds, then 250 ml water off-boil for 1 minute 30 seconds brew time, then 75 ml bypass water. Sounds complicated, but it's actually very easy. I did all the weighing of grounds/water early on, then just converted it so I don't have to weigh every time, which is a real pain.

I saved some old beans so I could dial in the grind size and time and it only took about 2 attempts to get a nice medium fine grind for pour-overs at about 30 grams. It has all the features I wanted (timed grind, big hopper, nice metal grinds bin) and the price isn't bad. I upgraded from my baratza encore, which I loved just because the burrs are starting to dull and it's a few years old at this point. I've also had the rancillio rocky but it drove me nuts as it retained a ton of coffee in the chute. I feel like the overall components seem to be better quality than my old baratza. The disassembly is much simpler and I feel like the plastic parts surrounding the burrs are better quality so I'm happy. Another pretty cool thing to note is that my large beehouse dripper fits inside the grind chute so I can just hit the pre-timed button and it goes directly into my cone - pretty nice to not have to do everything twice. I'll update this review if anything changes after a few weeks of use

UPDATE April 16 2019: I'm still very happy overall with the grind and use but I will say that my grinds bin doesn't stay in place like it should. It's not the end of the world to hold it in while grinding but the directions clearly state that you should be able to slide the bin in until you hear a "click" and it should remain in place...I can tell you that it doesn't so unless you want coffee everywhere, you need to hold it in. Otherwise, the grind is fantastic and consistent.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice consistent grinder with a couple small issues
reviews.reviewText: I have had this grinder for a couple of months now and it really does a good job of producing a consistent grind and is pretty quiet. Two issues. To remove the hopper, which I need to do every day to get it to fit in the cupboard, you need to remove the top of the hopper and fish through the beans to find the shaft that must be turned to remove it. The lock should be outside the hopper but short of that it should be longer so it is not buried in the beans when the hopper is full. With smaller beans, they can get lodged in the gates that close to seal the bottom when removing the hopper. Second is the timer. It turns freely with no detents to ensure it does not move when handling. I need to ensure it is set to the same time each use. It should have detents on the seconds so that at least it clicks into place and stays where you set it. Doesn't seem that a digital timer would have been a cost prohibitive feature on such a solid grinder. That said, at this price point it is a solid grinder that I would recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is essential for using whole beans
reviews.reviewText:
Update: Been using this grinder for almost 2 months now, everyday, and I love it more and more. No it’s not perfect, yes beans will get stuck from time to time but I love it. I clean the lower and upper burr once a week, sometimes more using a bristle brush and gently tapping the whole grinder out over the sink. I stopped washing the the grounds container out each time with soap and water though, all I do is wipe it out with dry hands over the sink, it is silky smooth in design and there’s just no need to wash it after each use. Just dry wipe and you’re done. Fantastic buy.

I have been making French press coffee for a few years now, and all the while using a standard blade grinder despite everything I’ve read about the importance of grinding the beans. I just used this machine for the first time this morning and WOW. The ground beans looked COMPLETELY different then in my little blade grinder, and I thought I had that down to a science. I used a 13 on the course setting for 10 seconds and then manually ran it for another 2-3 seconds since all the beans had not been ground. I am completely embarrassed to say that the cup of coffee I had this morning was better then any cup I’d had since I started using French press. I then added cream and sugar to another cup and even that tasted SO much smoother. I cannot believe how much better burr grinding is. As far as cleaning, and this is big for me with 5 kids running around, the parts are super easy to pop off. I will buy some small, soft bristle brushes for the burr areas though because The cleaning instruction recommend only cleaning them that way AND because I don’t think there is a need to be getting the upper burr wet after each use. So basically those areas are super easy to clean because the bottom burr you can just run the machine with no beans and it really sweeps all the excess out and the upper burr cleaned with a small bristle brush over the sink or garbage is like new. To be honest I just gently tapped out the bean hopper because it doesn’t get real dirty at all, maybe if you were grinding a ton of beans it would but I don’t need much for French press so I’ll deep clean that as needed. So all that’s left is the grounds container and lid and that is so easy, I just rinse it with hot water & dish soap and set it to dry. My blade grinder I needed to clean pretty deep after each use so even though this has more parts it’s actually way easier to clean if you ask me. As far as durability the burrs seem very durable, the whole machine seems quite sturdy, especially the bean hopper. The grounds container is light and the top just lightly clips on so that is probably the flimsiest thing that comes with this but I like it because it’s light and super easy to clean.

reviews.reviewTitle: Consistent grinding, easy to use/clean. Never had a clog
reviews.reviewText:
I am more than a casual coffee drinker. So I am hoping to provide a review that will help both the casual java drinker and those of us who bleed coffee.
Did the research, returned two other brands and I settled on this one minus the integrated scale.One month in and its still going great. Grind size is very consistent.
Lattes cappuccinos espressos: For a double espresso I use 10 grams (1 and 1/4 full of included spoon approx) of beans on 3.5 grind size for 10~12 seconds. Give a small tap to chute area (just because) and that fills my double shot portafilter. I do not grind more than I need nor do i store my beans in hopper.
Cleaning so far: i use a straw brush once a week to remove any coffee beans or grinds i see on the burr. I haven’t yet dismantled the burr itself. I brush away the debris then run a 5 second grind . I clean the chute similarly upside down. I believe a weekly routine will help avoid any clogging is troubles. I haven’t had the need to grind large amounts of coffee for a whole pot. My preference is small servings of my java.

French Press: I am still working thru the ideal coffee to water ratio and ideal grind size.
Pour over: grind size that works for me is 7
Moka pot: grind size I have used is 6

Overall a decent functional machine that looks aesthetically pleasing, is efficient, not too loud, compact, works seamlessly so far and is worth the 100$ i paid Nov 2018.

reviews.reviewTitle: Highly recommended to complement a good brewer like Technivorm Moccamaster
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using Technovorm Moccamaster for 6 years now, almost everyday. One problem I had was the bean. I do not like to hand grind every morning - who has that time? So I switched backed and forth between grinding beans in batch and buying ground bag of beans. Ground beans can't really compete with beans that are freshly ground just before brewing. I specifically searched products that are not going to break after a couple months use (one brand product went out of the picture even though I liked that design very much), and has a feature to preset grind amount. I normally brew same amount of coffee so when I get the water from the faucet, I can do it even without looking at it. Coffee amount is a different matter. Sometimes I scoop more, sometimes less. Sometimes I just pour from the bag and can't totally measure the amount. I wanted a machine that grinds a specific amount I preset. With one touch.

There are several products that do this, and OXO is in the middle of the pack in terms of price. I think other more expensive products have more delicate design to work with espresso portafilters. I don't have that need. This product's build quality and design really does not hurt the aesthetic landscape of my kitchen, and it does not take much space either.

Now this is what I set for my use.
grind time = 10 seconds (for 2 full mug cups of coffee, with my coffee maker water line to 5).
grind setting = 10 (right side of medium)

Yes, it wasn't the 6 year old brewer. Now the coffee it makes comes with aroma. Now I can have it every morning at one touch. I can just empty the entire container once that 10 sec grind is finished into the filter and know it's a good amount (at least better than my eye measurement).

Yup, just as some other reviews said, this definitely hums when plugged in. It's annoying enough in a quiet room that I had to leave it unplugged except when in use. I'm not sure how I feel about keeping it. A humming coffee grinder does not sound normal to me.

Other than the hum - the grinder is very easy to set up and use. I had a Breville SmartGrinder Pro that died after about 3 years - impeller wore out and there's no way to replace it - and while I liked it when it worked, it had really was a bit much for my needs (I pretty much only make drip coffee). This grinder feels more reasonable; set grind size time, figure out how many seconds give you the appropriate amount for brew. Done. The stainless steel canister is also quite nice.

Oh, but the hum...

Oxo - is it possible to replace these machines with ones that don't hum?

I bought this grinder about two weeks ago to replace a Bodium Bistro, that I'd had for nearly 10 years, that had finally just stopped working. I love that it's quieter than the Bodium and produces a more consistent grind. My favorite feature is the grounded grounds container. Not a single piece of coffee has escaped in the 2 weeks I've had it so far. Very clean! My only complaint is the sticking beans in the hopper. All of the beans I grind are kind of oily and get hung up in the hopper. My solution has been to just pour in a little more beans than I want to grind. During the grinding, I usually have to stick in the provided scoop 2-3 times and stir the beans around to get them moving again. It seems to need less stirring as time goes by, though, as if the beans are lubing up the inside of the hopper and allowing for smoother movement. Ha! The Bodium was the same. When I first got it, it would hardly work at all with my oily beans. Eventually, it worked perfectly with them. I'm assuming this grinder will do the same.

Just FYI, I set the grinder to the number 10 setting for a Moccamaster KBG coffee maker.

I highly recommend this grinder! It's worth the price.

I'm very happy with my grinder. Switched from a manual handground to this because I like to make large batches of cold brew and finally got sick and tired of the manual labor. There are a lot of unwanted fines in the course grind. I think that's a problem for all grinders though. I had the same issue with my handground, although I think this oxo has more. I started sifting out the fines with a strainer - I probably lose about 1/2 Oz of coffee for every 4 I grind, but the taste is fantastic!

Other than the compliments other reviews gave about the consistency of course grinds, all the other positive comments are true. Easy to operate, clean, empty, etc. Looks good, too. Glad I got it.

Produces very inconsistent grinds at the medium-coarse levels. I've been using a manual hand grinder for years because I haven't found a decent electric conical burr grinder for under $100 that would create a coarse enough grind for a french press. This grinder is no different: selecting the coarsest grind option, it produces a mix of fine powder and small chunks that is unsuitable for a french press (or any other brew method). I was surprised that the grind was as inconsistent as an electric push top blade grinder. If it was only a little too fine, I wouldn't mind using this for pour overs, but unfortunately all the grind options, unless on the very fine end, are completely inconsistent. Additionally, the bottom canister does not really lock or 'click' in as they claim and you will likely loose some coffee if you do not hold it for the entire duration of the grind. Returning item after first day, do not be fooled by the freebie reviews.

The grinder has worked flawless for the last month since I received it. I unfortunately had to pay for mine -_- but it is well worth the price thus far. I’ve read other reviews about the unit jamming but i haven’t experienced any problems at all with that. Maybe the ones jamming dont have the hopper installed correctly. The instructions do say if the hopper has beans in it, to adjust grind size while it is on or jamming can occur. Or if hopper is empty then grind size can be adjusted with the unit off. Maybe thats the problem people are having. Either way I havnt had any problems and it has been great. Happy grinding!

I purchased this after hand grinding my coffee for two years. Great time saver, and it produces a good quality grind. It grinds 45g of coffee beans in about 15 seconds. I do not use the timer feature since I weigh my coffee out each day and put it into the hopper, but the unit does auto-shutoff when the coffee is done grinding, even with the timer set to 30 seconds.

I removed one star from my rating due to the very annoying electric hum the unit makes when not in use. It's not necessarily loud, but I can hear it if I am withing 5' of the grinder and everything else is quiet. I am in the habit of unplugging it when not in use because the hum was annoying enough while I sit and drink my coffee. I don't know what causes this, but I've read other reviews that mention the same thing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great product but had to knock off one star...
reviews.reviewText:
I love OXO products and this move to larger kitchen appliances seems new to me but is entirely welcome. Unlike many I didn't really worry about the free product reviews (although I question their value aside from a very general trend prediction), as I would simply return it if it wasn't any good.

But this grinder turned out to be great. Just started using it so I don't know about durability and the like but bet it will be great. The only knocks I have are:

1. The little collection cup is supposed to click in and stay in, but it doesn't (which is where I dropped a star). So you have to hold it in while the beans are grinding, but who wants to walk away when you are grinding coffee beans anyway?? It is a minor annoyance, but still an annoyance so can't give it five stars.

2. The grinder grinds relatively finely, just as a recommendation to those other coffee fanatics. Easy to spot when you test the first grind. But my fine setting at the grocery grinders is about 11 out of 15 on this one. Not a big deal since it does grind the way I want it, but if you like it super coarse, this might not work as well.

Enough about the negatives. This thing is sleek and feels well built and it doesn't take up much counter real estate, so you can likely leave it out and not have to pull it out each time you use it. It can grind to order or grind a few days worth at a time which is very nice. It also cleans easily. The hopper needs almost nothing and a quick tap of the collection cup clears most of the coffee out due to some sort of anti static coating. I really like this little gadget.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds are not as uniform as advertised (especially for coarser grind)
reviews.reviewText: Specifically bought this to grind large amounts of coffee at a time for cold brew, which requires very coarse grounds, but even on the coarsest grind setting, it still produces very fine grounds that become muddy and clog my OXO cold brew system.

reviews.reviewTitle: Much better than my last grinder, a definite step up
reviews.reviewText:
Ok, I just got this grinder today, so these are first impressions. I can't speak to durability. Like many of you, I used to own a Cusinart DLC-8.
