I have basically decided that it was a piece of junk and I never knew it. The Coffee that came out off the grinder was all different sizes, it probably ground too fast for a small burr grinder. I bought one back in 2006, and again around 2013, and this year it just quit. So it was time to buy another. Or was it?

I didn't see why a coffee grinder should go bad so often. I was not using it past its duty cycle, it never got hot. My routine is that every couple of days I grind about 150 grams pic coffee, fine, to make 2 liters of cold brew coffee. I weigh the coffee, use ceramic pots with permanent filters, and give it overnight, stirring after at least an hour and perhaps as long as 3 hours.

The bin on the Cusinart held just enough for two pots. So I'd grind until the bin was full and then start weighing coffee.

The coffee I make at home is smooth, deep, strong, and far far better than any coffee I can buy at any shop. The Starbucks Nitro has some of the same characteristics but I would rather have what I make....because it just tastes better. I usually drink it black and iced, without sweetener or flavoring.

But I thought that coffee was supposed to be broken up buy a home grinder, and that the inconsistent grind was what I had to put up with to get a fresh grind.

Wow. I cleaned the new grinder, looked at how easy it was to disassemble, loaded it with beans, set it to fine and hit the button.

The ground coffee was all in the bin. It waa all uniform. ALL THE COFFEE WAS FINELY GROUND. There were no hunks, there was no powder. The grinder was just quieter. It sounded like an ordinary kitchen appliance rather than an airplane launching from the counter.

I realized, at that moment, that I had been using what was an inconsistent machine. This was the grinder I had always wanted. Other reviews had talked about getting better coffee because the coffee is not being heated so much. I can't speak to that. My coffee from the DLC-8 was good. I think it was way harder to deal with because out was so inconsistent.

Right now I'm ecstatic. If anything changes, I will post an update.

I will say one thing. People are irritated because the grinder is not marked in cups. I ground some coffee on fine, it produced about 10 grams of fine coffee in 15 sec. When I changed it to medium coarse and ground for the same time, it produced a totally different amount of coffee. So it does not make any sense to make coffee that way. You need to calibrate your coffee and your fine or coarse grind to the number of seconds of grind you need. It seemed to be linear.

And there are multiple warnings not to overkill the hopper. That is a real problem, but I am willing to watch the hopper so as not mess it up.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love it, glad I finally bought it
reviews.reviewText:
We like to grind our own coffee beans at home. We had been using a hand crank coffee grinder because we hadn't found an electronic grinder with enough positive reviews that produced a consistent grind. We found this one and we are so glad we bought it. What used to take 10 minutes now takes about 10 seconds. We use it nearly every day. Easy to fill, quick to set the grind size and run time. The hopper design ensures no beans are left in the top.

Make sure you give the top a tap with your hand before you pull out the canister of grinds - sometimes there are some grinds left in the chute that will consequently fall after you pull out the canister if you don't give it a little tap.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love it so Much I Bought ANOTHER for DECAF
reviews.reviewText:
Great VALUE
Have used one for Months, and I JUST bought a SECOND one.
For DECAF Beans :)

imho, there is NO Better Review than THAT

The Steel Bin and way it stops Coffee Grinds from sticking is SMART
Ground connection and Slow Grind.

When It gets stuck on a Grind, I just Shake
OR pick up and and DROP about 3 inches high and it STARTS AGAIN.... SIMPLE

I ALSO, DO NOT change GRIND settings when the BIN is FULL
I have moved mine to about 6

The TIMER is PERFECT to tweek to get JUST enough for your Coffee maker

My coffee maker can only do 2 Espresso shots at a Time, and my Coffee Mix is 4 Shots...
So, this Grinder is such a TIME SAVER
and is LESS of a Mess.

I am REALLY Happy I found this Grinder thru the REVIEWS of Others
SO, I am Posting MIine to HELP other Decide
YOU will NOT regret this Purchase

My only neg,
Wish there was a way to SEAL the Hopper automatically.
Yes, I know the Grinder part is Open

The little container that catches the grinds is really flimsy, thin stainless steel, which and itself is probably good because it reduces the static that plastic containers have. But it doesn't have the quality I would expect from $100 grinder. Also, it's plastic cover as well as the cover on top of the machine, are just a bit difficult to place, but come off really easy. It should be the opposite. I didn't even grind beans, because I wanted Amazon to be able to sell it as new, since I knew I wasn't going to keep it. I was SOLD a promo copy, but that's something I can live with. I already have the capresso cone burr grinder, that I bought maybe 10 years ago, and is still available. It is great! I just wanted to try a new grinder and ended up purchasing the very simple and effective Krups blade grinder https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B00004SPEU?psc=1&ref=yo_pop_mb_yo_pop_mb_pd_t2
If you shake it like a cocktail shaker while grinding the coffee, which is really easy because of its design, I got perfectly even grind for a Melitta filter. The coffee tasted great, less bitter than the coffee brewd using the medium fine ground coffee prepared with the Capresso burr grinder, richer and more flavorful, but more bitter. of course the Capresso produces better evenly growned course coffee for French press, or extra fine grinds, vor Espresso. Still, the simple little Krups machine is really nice and well worth buying for $20. But if you're going to spend $100, get the fantastic and durable and well-designed Capresso cone grinder.

I did some researching before purchasing this grinder. The inspiration was my friend gifted me a very nice bag of coffee for the holidays, but of course it was whole bean (which is the best, but I hadn't gotten around to getting the system set up). I had a hand grinder that I used and enjoyed, but I decided it was time to treat myself to a nice grinder. I'm so glad I did. It's a complete game changer and has really opened up my morning coffee routine.

So to sum up my thoughts on this grinder: I'm so glad I picked this one. I think it's the most attractive visually, I love the satin finish, and I think aesthetically it looks like something 3x the price. I love the variety of the grind and the ease of use. And while it's not sneak past your toddler in a small home quiet, it is very reasonable. If I were to do this whole process over again, I would probably buy the Oxo version with the scale. I really thought I would never use a scale and thats just completely more than I would ever need (and I don't know, maybe it's not worth the extra $100) but I also didn't realize how many more new coffees I would be trying now that they all taste so much better! I would keep a little note pad with my favorite roasts and their best amounts used. I have not needed to clean the burrs on this grinder yet so I don't have an opinion on that specifically but it's easy to clean the grinds off otherwise. And I really like that it's a no spill hopper. The top is easy to take off. I suggest getting a bristle coffee grounds brush to help keep the machine clean.

So, the cons. There's not very many of them but if I could change anything about this grinder, I would make it so the grounds catcher snaps in better. Sometimes it vibrates outwards when grinding so I have to hold it to keep it in place. I noticed the other Oxo grinder seems to have a better grounds catcher - it grinds into the middle instead of the side, further removing the possibility of your grinds falling outside of the catcher. And while on the subject of the grounds catcher, they could have chosen a nicer top for it (they appear to have done so on the scale version). I dropped mine the other day and worried it was going to snap when falling four feet. Lastly, the hopper only holds .75 a pound of coffee. I don't understand why they didn't make it so it just holds a pound? It's minor, but a 1 lb bag of coffee is probably the most common and I would like to store the entire bag in the hopper at once to try and keep it freshest.

But as far as functionality this grinder is excellent. It's solid, it doesn't feel cheap, it's not too loud. it grinds great coffee. The hopper even has a UV tint to help protect the beans. I don't know that the more expensive coffee grinders have anything on this one, besides a few quirks I mentioned above. If you're thinking of treating yourself to a nice coffee grinder, I think that this is a great entry level one and you will probably not ever need anything more. Consider splurging on the scale version if you think you will be varying the roasts or value real consistency though.

reviews.reviewTitle: The Gateway to Every Good Cup
reviews.reviewText:
My life in home-brewed coffee has had serious ups and downs for years. I've gone through percolators and french presses and pour overs and automatic espresso machines in search of a cup that meets my two criteria for great weekend coffee; easy and delicious. I've come to one conclusion... it's all in the grinder.

People go on and on about pour over this and paper filter that, and inverted boiling systems, and temperature controlled units... that's great if you're a professional barista, for the rest of us, just trying to relax on a lazy Sunday, it doesn't matter, or at least it doesn't matter half as much as you've been led to believe. The number one thing standing between you and a great cup of coffee is your grind. Study it, experiment with it, get to know it and then make adjustments when you need to. The right grind can alter the flavor of your brew from sour and weak to rich and flavorful whether your beans cost $5 or $20. The trick is finding the best grind that works for you. This is the perfect entry level machine to that goal. It can't make terrible beans taste great, but it can make them the best that they can be.

My advice is take a couple weeks to dial it in. Buy a bag of roast that you like and drink only that roast for a couple weeks. Brew it using the same method every-time altering only the grind quality and try to make observations about what changed. Not every roast requires the same grind to shine, but little changes can sometimes go a very long way. It's an interesting way to study coffee, and to get great brews with relatively limited effort... or you know, just stick it on 6 and hope for the best.

After a year of ownership, it still does the job like the day I got it. This is the machine you want; conical burr, slow grind rate, consistent as a swiss clock. The only thing that would make it better is ceramic burrs (supposedly), this one uses metal... I'll hold my breath.

Grinds from this machine go into a cheap auto-drip every Saturday/Sunday and the coffee that comes out is consistently great despite that. The grinder itself is reasonably well built and handsome but there are some short comings.

The buttons aren't satisfying to press and OXO used surprisingly cheap plastics in places that you're routinely in contact with; on the start button, on the front face plate. That said, for $100 you're getting a machine that's reliable, consistent, and not too bulky or shabby looking. On too early Sundays, with upset children blaring demands at me like they're at a metal concert, it's exactly what I need to start my day.

A couple weeks in: very fast & consistant grind.

The timer button is electronic and precise.

No problems with beans sticking/clogging and I have it set just under the “4” mark...on the course side of fine...almost fine enough for an expresso machine.

Saw another review that said “quiet” and I AGREE; quieter than the average for sure.

I like it...allot.

************************

First impression “out of the box”, initial grind:

Great grinder.

Quiet.

Fast.

Pretty.

Solidly built.

Good grind quality & consistency.

Coffee drain is straight down, so you could catch it with an espresso portafilter if you want.

Only one (minor) complaint: It needs a true “momentey on” button; to grind as long as you hold it.

Thumbs up to Amazons speedy shipping. I tried to change my mind, as my family bought a grinder from Walmart (didn’t tell me) and this was on order for a few hours...tried to cancel...but that puppy was SHIPPED. Now...I’m keeping this one...beats the walmart Krupps grinder nicely!

Will update review after I put some real time on it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use; grinds really fine for espressos
reviews.reviewText: I wish it came with an extra lid for the bottom container to store the ground coffee beans. Instead you need to transfer the ground coffee to another container to preserve and store. Otherwise, this is a good value for the quality. I've only used it on setting 3 because I just make espressos. The numbers change based on what you are using the coffee for; french press, (1-5) espresso, percolator or pour over etc. It has clear instructions and comes well packaged. The coffee comes out really fine. Would definitely recommend!

reviews.reviewTitle: Save your money and get a Baratza
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this Oxo coffee grinder after the 20 year old Starbucks branded Barazta stopped working.

At first it worked great. 3-4 months of no maintenance and it ground effortlessly. Than it started clogging which required frequent cleanings and spending hard earned money on those coffee grinder cleaning tabs.

I thought it was the brand of coffee i was using, so I gave it a good cleaning and switched to beans that were less oily looking.

That didn't work and now it gets clogged after a couple of hopper full of any type of coffee beans.

While it worked well for the first two months, It's now frankly far too much work and far too messy to grind coffee using this.

Anyone looking at this should just save their money and get a Baratza...they seem to be the best out there in terms of longevity.

My bad for not noticing it wasn't ceramic. Time will tell if it holds up. Cracks me up that the feature it keeps touting is "one button operation". How many buttons should it take to operate? As far as quiet, well compared to a jet engine it is quiet. Compared to anything else, it is not. It does do a very nice consistent job of grinding and that is what is most important, thus the five stars.

For the record, I actually bought this thing, so I'm not reviewing with free rose-colored glasses.

Fundamentally, this is a good grinder. The coarseness settings work well, and I'd argue the coarsest setting is perfect if you're using this grinder with Oxo's own (excellent) cold brew machine. It is quiet and, importantly, holds just enough beans to do a full cold brew batch - 284 grams of beans fit into the hopper with just a touch of room to spare. There is also considerably less static contributing to grounds flyaway versus competing grinders.

There are a couple issues, though. First, if you want to grind the entire hopper at once because you're following Oxo's cold brew recipe, you'll have to punch the button at least 4 times. Second, if you're doing that, you'll either need to empty the container after each grind, resulting in an increase in static and associated flyaway mess, or rig something that allows you to grind directly into your vessel of choice. For me, that vessel is Oxo's own cold brew carafe. The carafe is far too large to fit under the grinder, so I'm forced to prop the grinder atop some tupperware and use a flexible cutting board to funnel the grounds into the carafe. Functional, but certainly not elegant.

It's a bummer that Oxo's products don't interface well with each other, even though they're almost universally excellent standalone tools.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Burr Grinder for the Semi-Enthusiast
reviews.reviewText:
I've had my eye on a burr grinder for a couple years. I have an OXO 9-Cup coffee maker, which brews a delicious pot of coffee, but I've always used a $20 Cuisinart grinder for my beans. I hated how irregular the grind was -- some parts were fine like espresso, but mixed in with pea-sized half-pulverized beans. The coffee was thus pretty inconsistent in taste. At times it was over-extracted and bitter, other times watery and weak.

I jumped on the OXO when I saw it on sale. Wirecutter recommended it, and after using it for a couple weeks now I can see why. It's dead simple to set up and use. The first time you do it you should weigh your beans before and after you grind because you have to turn a dial to indicate how many seconds you want the grind to be. I wasn't sure if 10 seconds = 6 cups of coffee or 2 cups of coffee, and there's no way to really tell. I found 10 seconds at medium grind (5 out of 10) perfect for my 20 oz. coffee every morning. On weekends I increase it if I have more than 1 cup.

Overall if you're even a little bit interested in having "good" coffee in the morning rather than just instant/cheap drip coffee, this is something you should seriously consider. Why waste money on a coffee maker and good beans if you're going to grind it poorly?

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent, accurate, quiet, well made grinder.
reviews.reviewText:
I used a popular hand conical burr grinder for years. I only brewed with coarse grind, so the difficulties of adjusting the grind was not an issue. Recently I got very involved with coffee, which meant using different grinds for different coffees and brews. The hand grinder just wasn't accurate when changing grinds, and difficult to change.

I did serious research on electric conical burr grinders and finally settled on two. This one and one other. I got my first choice, but was VERY disappointed in its inability to come close to a coarse grind, and sent it back.

This grinder was my second choice; not because I didn't think it would be as good as the first, but it was $40 more expensive. Well, as usual, I found that you get what you pay for. This grinder is everything I had hoped for and more. It grinds coarse and ever "super" course. For cold brew coffee this one can not be beat. Medium is medium, medium-fine is fine, fine is fine, and the in between settings are accurate and easily reproducible. All of my grinds have been very uniform.

There is minimal static stick, and what there is can be removed with a sharp wrap on the counter once the grind is gone. Static is NOT a problem! The noise level is very low and grinding speed is fast. Fit and finish are excellent. I have absolutely no complaints about this grinder.

I know there are more expensive grinders, and MUCH more expensive grinders on the market, but I can't believe more money would give me an any better grinder than this one. Very highly recommended.

BTW, I paid full price for the grinder on Amazon and have no connection with OXO or the seller. This is an honest review.

This is a great grinder. I think burr grinders are the only way to go. This one is not too loud but, then again, it is only running for very short periods of time. I grind only enough for one espresso at a time. I have not had the problems with it gumming up a some have noted and I use Starbuck's French Roast that is kind of oily. I have not had to clean it yet, so I cannot speak to that aspect. The range of the size to grind is vast. Both the size of the grind and the length of time to grind takes some time and lots of tiny adjustments to fit your needs. However, once it is dialed in, it works well with a slight variation of the quantity of the grind even when the time is the same. Overall, I really like it and would buy it again when this one wears out, which I hope will be several years from now.

We've owned the Mr Coffee & Cuisanart burr grinders at about $40 each. This Oxo grinder has multiple features that make it worth the added price.
First, it is quiet. It's much lower pitched sound is about as low as the dishwasher running.
2nd. The increased use of metal parts makes us think it will be more durable, and the stainless grounds container has less static to attract the grounds, so it empties without needing to be wiped out.
3rd. The parts that need regular cleaning can disassemble easily without having to empty the bean hopper first.
Somebody who actually uses a grinder designed this.
This is a marked improvement over lesser grinders without costing hundreds.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great! But grind time too easily changed. And no idiot-proofing?
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using this grinder for two months, and I mostly love it. The anti-static steel container works well. It's quieter and cleaner than my last grinder, which was a no-frills Black & Decker. I use it exclusively for French press (very coarse grind), and it does that job great.

I have one persistent complaint, and one maybe-not-persistent complaint. The first is that the dial to set the grind time is too loose, mechanically. Since it is located immediately surrounding the grind button, it's extremely easy to change the grind time accidentally. Then I grind my next batch and get a completely unexpected amount. I've learned to be cautious, but this is a small design flaw.

The other is what just happened to me for the first time. I assumed that, like most grinders, it would refuse to grind if the receptacle is not securely in place. Mine was completely missing (because I hadn't had my coffee yet), and the grinder happily dumped a full load all over my counter. I can't tell from the description here or from the manual whether this safety feature is supposed to be there, so I don't know if this was a malfunction. Is there an OXO rep that would care to comment?

Yes, it's a luxury novelty and it's expensive... however, if you have the money to spend and drink as much coffee as my wife and I do, then this is an awesome purchase.

We previously used a cheap blade grinder and it actually worked decently, but it was difficult to clean and was heading towards it's final days. After upgrading to the conical Burr grinder, it's hard to imagine going back.

Aside from a noticeablely upgraded flavor profile from the same beans we were using with the blade grinder, it's so convenient to have the bean storage on the machine. Simply press the button, and the perfect amount of grounds come out now that we have the timer adjusted to what we want.

This is an expensive item for what is purely a luxury, but it is well worth it in my opinion.

Bought this to replace a SB (you know who) model, and this is a major upgrade to my home coffee experience. For one thing, the stainless steel cup doesn't seem to have the irritating static electricity issues of plastic -- the grounds go where I want them, not everywhere they want to go. Really like the convenient timer being separate from the "start" button -- ensures consistent easy measuring. Nice-looking unit, with OXO build quality apparent. Can't swear it's reliable yet, but I'm betting I will be using this one a lot longer than the little plasticky predecessor.

We had a capresso coffee grinder from Costco before this and let me tell you it was such an unbelievable pain every time we used it because the coffee grounds would just spill everywhere because there was no way to take out the grounds without making a giant mess and the static issue made the whole situation worse!!!! It was such a waste of time trying to clean up all the wasted coffee grounds!!! Oxo has barely any static, it is significantly less messy, and the timer on this grinder is so helpful!! Exactly one minute of grinding fills it up!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: This is by far the best grinder I have owned
reviews.reviewText: This is by far the best grinder I have owned. It is a conical burr grinder that is not excessively noisy and it produces a very uniform ground in the stainless steel catch cup. The grounds do not stick to the cup like the plastic catch cups. I have gone through 3 Cuisinart grinders that last not much more than 6 months. I have had this one for 3 months so we will see how durable it will be. Since all aspects seem to be will engineered I am hoping I will get at least a few years of service from it. I recommend it if you prefer fresh ground coffee in the morning.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great consistent grind for high crema espresso shots
reviews.reviewText: I use setting 2 or 3 depending on the bean to grind for espresso. It works brilliantly for that purpose. The ability to set the timer allows me to grind the perfect amount for a shot of espresso every single time - and I don't have to slave away at a manual burr grinder for 5 minutes. My morning routine will go much more quickly with this, and since I get a more consistent grind than the manual burr grinder can achieve, my shots of espresso have more crema, more flavor, and are in general smoother than they were previously. Well worth the $100. My one complaint is when you grind finely for espresso, there definitely is some static electricity buildup in the beans, causing them to stick to the stainless steel can which the grinds drop into.

I got this just a few days ago. It was super easy to get setup and going; the controls are intuitive and it is a sleek and compact package on my counter. My first run through I was impressed with how quiet it was, how even the grind was and everything else.

I later decided to grind a pound of coffee for my Toddy. Turns out that the anti static canister is still pretty static, the grounds clung to the rim and inside with tenacity. Also during one grinding cycle, the canister popped out a bit and it kept grinding. It actually didn't make as big of a mess as I expected, but grounds are still clinging to the front of my machine.

This all said, it is far more quiet that my previous model; it grinds beautifully and evenly, unlike my other experiences; the hopper makes grinding a lot of coffee very easy; and it doesn't take up much counter space.

I will update this review as my opinion changes.

reviews.reviewTitle: Frequently clogs and won't grind--look elsewhere
reviews.reviewText:
We've had this grinder for about 4 months. At first it seemed good; grinder gave a consistent grind and it looks nice in our kitchen. After about 3 weeks it stopped grinding. It would make a sound like it was grinding, but higher pitched and no grinds were produced. I realized it was clogged with ground coffee just below the burr grinder where it passes through a small opening to get to the basket. I took off the hopper and the removable part of the burr grinder and cleaned it out and it worked great again.

I thought at first if this happened every few weeks, it's not so bad to clean out the grinder now and then. Unfortunately it started happening more often. Recently it was every week, and finally today I am unable to get it to work---it clogs immediately even after I clean all the grinds out. I am beyond frustrated and will be contacting OXO on Monday (we are past the Amazon return window).

Save yourself the headache and get something else. We had a Kitchenaid conical burr grinder for 7 years before this, and it never clogged. Finally the motor seemed to die, so we purchased the OXO grinder. Should have stuck with the Kitchenaid (there was one small annoyance with Kitchenaid due to how the coffee grind basket locked into the machine, which made us consider switching to something else).

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds well, compact, quiet, easy to use
reviews.reviewText: This is the best coffee grinder I have ever used, especially considering the price. It makes very consistent coffee, and with no muddy residue common to blade grinders. It does not take up a lot of counter space, is reasonably quiet, very easy to use and grinds perfectly and consistently. The bean storage compartment has a reasonably tight fitting lid to help keep the coffee beans fresh. Like all coffee grinders, static causes some of the grounds to stick to the dispensing cup, but the grounded metal cup minimizes this problem greatly compared to other grinders with a plastic cup. I like the ease of adjustment for the grind coarseness and the grinding timer that determines the amount of coffee that you grind. Both controls are simple, intuitive, and easy to set. My only minor complaint is the grind time adjustment knob turns too easily and thus is easy to accidentally change if you bump it. I would prefer a control knob that has detents or more friction so that it takes more deliberate action to turn it.

I've had this grinder for a bit now, I just wanted something easy to use to grind coffee beans...something that worked well and is durable.... I'm thankful I chose this one ... It does what I need it to do, and well, not one time have I had to stir the beans because any got stuck...not once ! the beans just go down as they grind so smoothly. I looked first at the OXO Brand first ,because I like the quality of other of their products I have bought,....I've never had a hand held can opener that opens cans as easily and smoothly as theirs.... which makes a great gift for soon to be brides ,and happy campers :), not to mention in your own kitchens. So too I'm happy with this coffee grinder.

I have had a number of coffee grinders over time. Most have done the job well. OXO does not have a fancy Italian name and the vanity part in me thought about that...but really glad I went with this one. It is very quiet (relative to others I have had) is incredibly easy to use (to adjust coarseness, set amount you want to grind) and has a very large reservoir up top to hold beans. This may seem trivial, but it has saved a ton of mess on my counter...the bin that it grinds into has an opening on the top, so you can just pour what you need into the French press...or whatever you are using. Previous grinders had a lid I would have to take off to pour the ground coffee...and bean dust (yah, I am sure there is a better word for it) would go all over the counter. So, in summary, this machine is quiet, solid, grinds well, is clean and very well priced given its quality.

After many hours of internet research, I settled on this item and couldn't be happier. A longtime coffee snob and daily home brewer, I wanted to get this right. I have a great brewer and buy expensive beans. This grinder does the rest proud. It's half as noisy as the Cuisinart that died on me, and provides more detailed customization (size and duration) than I've ever had, which is fun. The best part might be the lack of static in the cup, which gives me a grin every morning. A total winner against others at 3 times the price.

OXO has a reputation for well-designed, well-built products, and that reputation is one reason I decided to take a chance on this relatively new OXO product, versus a number of other coffee grinders out there with 4+ star ratings.

I've had the unit a little over a month, having ground about 2 pounds of coffee thus far. I use a French press, so I grind on medium-coarse, about 11-12 on the product's dial. The machine has worked flawlessly, and a relative remarked that it was noticeably quieter than his unit from another well-known brand (which isn't to say that it is whisper-quiet; it definitely makes noise).

The grinder simply works as you'd expect; no surprises. It looks nice and the metal collection cup is a nice touch (it still gets a tiny amount of particles on the side, but not as much as the typical plastic cup). Easy to use, adjust, and clean.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice upgrade from one of those spinning blade grinders
reviews.reviewText: We had one of those spinning blade grinders for years and it broke. We were generally happy with it and I was inclined to buy a $25 replacement, but I researched blade vs burr grinders, decided to buy this one and have been very happy. Some things I like about this over the blade grinder: 1) We brew coffee 2 different ways in our house - with a blade, you just have 1 grind, now we can grind for the method and it does definitely make a difference in taste. 2) I love how you can just pour a whole bag of beans into the unit and not have to worry about it for a week or two - during that time, you just press a button to grind the amount that you need. Also, there are many other much more expensive burr grinders out there - we're not coffee aficionados and didn't want to pay a premium for features that we may not appreciate. Bottom line - this was reasonably priced upgrade from a blade grinder and the improvement in taste and ease of use was definitely worth it.

Initially it did not work out of the box. I made several attempts to run the grinder, and while I could hear the electrical motor running, the lower burr was not moving. I subsequently discovered that the coupling between the motor and the lower burr was disengaged. Moving the motor higher, and manually rotating its body to lock its position, addressed this issue.
The lowest setting grinds were initially larger than what my manual Hario mill produces, but undoing a little the screw holding the lower burr addressed, I think, this issue, by allowing the two burrs to get closer together. That managed to improve grind size and uniformity, which is now slightly better than my old Hario.
To sum up, decent results, but only after addressing the issues mentioned. After approximately two weeks of everyday use, the results are satisfactory, and the timer feature is extremely useful, allowing to grind just enough coffee every time. The machine is relatively clean to operate, not too noisy, and doesn't seem to generate a lot of static charge. I feel however, that the grinder should provide finer grinds, and incorporate maybe a way to finely calibrate the low end of the grind size.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nearly silent, I just wish the coarsest setting was more coarse.
reviews.reviewText: It's a burr-style grinder, which is so much better than a blade grinder. With a burr grinder, one can get much better consistency than blade grinders. Another good point is that it's nigh-on silent. You won't wake up loved ones with this grinder. Cleaning is easy, as it can be taken apart without tools to be washed. The only issue I have with this OXO grinder, I can't get the really coarse coffee I need for my French press. The coarsest setting is still just a bit too fine for me.

I had a Capresso grinder, which was similar but crapped out eventually after about 12 years of constant use. I debated getting another Capresso, it worked really well, came highly recommended, and I had no negatives about it. In fact, the eventual failure was my own fault for putting it back together wrong after cleaning it. However, I decided to take a risk on this one and try it. I actually like it much better. The hopper holds more and we can fill it once and grind for a week before having to fill it again. The dial for adjusting the amount is really nice and then you just push the button, unlike the Capresso which was activated by a timer that you turned and then ticked back to zero kind of like an egg timer. This has highly adjustable grind settings, no complaints there. And finally, the grounds-holder cup is steel which generates less static, less mess, with a nicely removable lid and its really easy to clean the "perch" where the cup sits. Overall, this is a great grinder!

When my 10 year old Cuisinart grinder died recently I almost ordered the same one but decided to read a little bit further. I'm so glad I did!! My wife and I drink lattes every day and I always wondered what Starbucks did SO differently than I did to make theirs taste so much better. I use a 1990's espresso machine but I didn't feel like that was the issue. I bought a coffee tamper and the OXO BREW Conical Burr Coffee Grinder and holy smokes!!!! I actually like the ones i'm making now better than Starbucks!! (and my 1990's Krup's is still going strong!)

I noticed that when I first plugged it in it hummed. It worked fine--I didn't grind a lot of coffee with it--but I realized that it was also generating a "hot electrical device" smell. Others have noted the hum, and the hum/smell combination convinced me that, at best, the grinder might have a shortened life, and at worst, it might catch fire. I returned it and bought a different brand.

This worked like a dream the first couple times. I make cold brew batches so I don’t use it daily. But once I got past (by a day or two) my 30 day return, I set it for 30 seconds, it runs for 1-2 seconds the either stops or sounds like it’s out of beans, when the hopper is full! I jiggle it and sometimes it starts back up, sometimes not. I clean it after every use, so I don’t know why this is happening. The shoot is clear, the grinder is clean.

Update: OK, so it wasn’t really clean. I found that if I run a small brush under the rim where the grinder sits in the machine, there is a lot of debris that hides under there. Now, I do a full cleaning every time I make a double batch of cold brew, and the thing works like a champ! I’d give it 5 stars, but I wished it grinded just a little more coarse. Overall pretty happy.

I had a 10+ YO Solaris bean grinder that was always staticky and did not have much variation of grind. This has no static and has a great variation of grind. While the OXO 9-cup Barista Brain coffee maker has some shortcomings, the time must be reset 2-3 X a week because of a known issue they are not going to correct, you also have to wait for the brew cycle to complete before pouring a cup. It also does not keep heat very well after an hour. Luckily I have a Nissan stainless coffee carafe/thermos that I use when brewing 9 cups. Great combination despite the minor issues!

So, in a attempt to save money on K-cups, I decided to start seriously using my single use Solo-cup for my Keurig. I've had the Solo-cup for a few years but have never been able to create a decent cup of joe with it. If you use pre-ground, the cup ends up weak and lame...super watered down. Not good. So, I've always just purchased the incredibly overpriced cups. Eventually, I read that then problem was a grind issue. Regular drip coffee grind was just too course. So I tried to use my blade grinder to find the right consistency for my whole beans. I was never able to get it right until I splurged and purchase this grinder. The price was pretty spot-on for what I needed it for. However, a hundred bucks is a lot of money to me so it was kind of a leap of faith. But it was an absolute game-changer! I've only had this unit for a few weeks, but it works beautifully!!! Once you get your settings right for your preferences, it make all the difference. Not only that, but I have perfected my French Press coffee routine! This grinder was worth every penny and I pray it holds up for years to come!!! I am a burr grinder believer!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinder works well with a good design, but feels a little chintzy.
reviews.reviewText: This burr grinder works well and produces a consistent grind with an excellent design, however, some of the tactile aspects of this grinder leave something to be desired. The grind container feels a bit cheap as you snap it in below the spout with a barely detectable detente. It leaves you wondering if it's in or not. And the grind duration timer is pretty loosey goosey with a fair amount of play, although it does seem to stay in place. A premium grinder should feel premium. This doesn't quite get there.

I've owned this grinder for about 4 months. I also own the Kitchenaid and Bodum Bistro grinders. Each has it's pluses and minuses, but the Oxo is the best of them. My wife and I switch between different coffees for each cup, so we add enough beans to the hopper for one cup of coffee at a time. Frequently, all beans don't go through the grinding mechanism unless we give the grinder a shake or sharp rap. My wife weighs the beans and ground coffee to make sure everything has gone through the grinder, but this shouldn't be necessary. We probably do about 3 or 4 cups a day, and the Oxo label on the push button is already warn off.

reviews.reviewTitle: A dramatic improvement from my old grinder
reviews.reviewText: This is a great coffee grinder, better than the one it replaced, which died after 20 years of use. The old one, sold at Starbucks stores at one time, was louder, less easy to adjust for grind fineness, dirtier (the plastic container which held grounds was constantly sliding out, I had to hold it in with my thumb to prevent a mess). It was also harder to adjust the amount of coffee to grind each time. The Oxo took care of all those problems, quieter, more adjustable for grind & for quantity, much cleaner. It also takes up less space on the counter so I use it conveniently every day, just grinding enough for each pot. I think this device is a great value.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great easy to use coffee grinder.
reviews.reviewText: This is a great coffee grinder. Solid quality. I used to have a Kitchen Aid grinder. I would put the number of scoops in and grind. With the Oxo, it holds coffee beans in a hopper. You select the number of seconds you want it to grind. Then you press the button and the perfect amount grinds every time. After a little experimenting with how coarse or fine you want the grind setting and how many seconds to set the grinder to run to get your desired amount of coffee to grind per cup, you are ready to grind with one push of the button. It could not be easier. Great moderate priced grinder with the great Oxo name. I highly recommend this product.

I've been using this grinder for about a month and have definitely noticed an improvement in the flavor of the brewed coffee. I even had a dark roast that I had to mix with different beans to remove some bitterness because I didn't want to throw the whole bag out. I tried a pot with just the dark roasted beans and it tasted great. The bitterness was gone. I was reluctant to pay so much for a coffee grinder, but if this gives me a few years of service, I'll be glad I got it.

I'm a big fan of OXO products generally. I wanted to love this coffee grinder.

It looks great. It works great. But it's messy.

I don't know if its the static or what but grounds fall between the catcher and the grinder, so every time you remove the catcher, grounds get on your counter. Emptying the catcher into your brew basket is also messy, likely due to static, and it's impossible to get all the grounds out of the catcher unless you're knocking them out in the sink (wasted coffee, not much, but still).

So now I've got coffee grounds on my counter, on my coffee maker, and in my sink. I don't remember having this problem with my cheap Mr. Coffee burr grinder.

I don't recommend this grinder. OXO can do better.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Looks, Consistent Performance, Very Happy With It
reviews.reviewText: It looks great, Operates great. Does a great job of grinding coffee beans to different requirements. Typically using it for French Press Cold Brew & Bialetti Pot. Prepares fresh, different grind for each type every time. Is consistent & very easy to operate. The steel container is definitely a high point as you don't face the frustrating static problems encountered with plastic containers.

My kitchen is basically an Oxo showroom. I have probably 35 different Oxo products, so I was expecting the coffee grinder to be good. It is. I've been using it for 5 months and haven't had a single problem. Minimal static electricity, which I know is a problem with some grinders.

I'm not a heavy coffee drinker, I use it once a day, so I can't speak to how it would hold up under much heavier usage. But, it works for me.

Update: Since my glowing review the grinder has developed a major problem. It now only grinds fine. It doesn't matter what setting I change it to, the grind is the same. I often like to make cold brew, which calls for a coarse grind. Now when I make cold brew I end up with quite a bit of sludge at the bottom of the jar.

Nice burr grinder, the only thing is that the beans get stuck all the time and we have to keep pushing them down. Out of that problem the grind is good enough for our espresso machine and drip coffee.

I have been using a hand grinder for years. However, it is always a problem when we have a few people over and I have to stand there for 3 minutes per person grinding coffee. I expected to still use the hand grinder some but I havent used it since the Oxo got here.

I like good fresh ground coffee but don't feel the need to spend crazy amounts of money on a grinder. I would rather spend the money on the beans. I have used the grinder for a fine grind and medium grind. The consistency for both of these was great.

The coffee comes right out of the canister without any issues with static.

I typically have a couple of different beans. So I love being able to lock the hopper and pull it off to change beans. A small amount of beans remain but they are easily poured off.

The timer produces very consistent amounts of coffee. I expected to just put what I wanted to grind in each time but the consistency was so good I just poured a day or two of coffee beans into the hopper.

Bought as an upgrade to a cheaper grinder. This one is quiet enough that I don't have to take it out into the garage to use it to keep from waking up someone still asleep. Timer is great so that after a few uses, I'm able to grind the proper amount with just a press of a button. Best thing is that I don't have grounds all over the counter like the previous burr grinder. I only use a French press, so I can't speak to how well it does with finer grinds.

reviews.reviewTitle: TERRIBLE. Gets Clogged Easily and Wastes Tons of Coffee Grounds
reviews.reviewText: This is a horrible coffee grinder! I bought it because it was quieter than the Cuisinart grinder I had before, but here's the thing: the Cuisinart lasted for 10+ YEARS. This OXO grinder has jammed at least 20 times since I bought it 4 weeks ago. Every time this happens you have to spend 10 min banging on it to get all the grounds out. The grounds go EVERYWHERE and waste TONS of coffee. And even when it is not jammed, this grinder has static electricity issues and wastes grounds that way too! I'm going back to the old grinder even if it is noisy. At least it WORKED. Steer clear of this grinder!

reviews.reviewTitle: An expensive unrepairable piece of junk
reviews.reviewText: I just threw this out as it stopped grinding and the burr outer ring handle broke when I tried to remove it to clean the unit again. The burr outer ring cannot be replaced. The grinder worked fine for 3 months and then started clogging and the beans would not go down. I cleaned the grinder four times according to the instructions and it still did not work properly. This device has turned out to be just another expensive piece of junk that cannot be repaired and must be replaced. Do not waste your money, the Capresso grinders are much better made.

Just came from a Hario Skerton hand-grinder that I've been using for years and I am never looking back, this thing is amazing! I have been using it for months, several times a day, and it has been operating flawlessly. I use it for my Keurig with reusable cups and I get the best tasting grounds between a 9 and 10 grind size. It's not too messy in use but every few days I notice some coffee grounds around the grinder so I wipe the area around it every week or so.

The only part I was not a fan of was the original box that holds the grounds because it is difficult to pour out of, grounds tended to stick to it due to static charge, and there was no sealed lid to keep the grounds fresh. However I swapped to my hario hand-grinder container and it has worked great to hold and dispense the coffee grounds.

This product is good as are most OXO products but also as with their other products they cut weird corners. For instance the button feels super cheap like I might break it with normal use. The white numbers and letters and icons they use for the lock and unlock pieces the button and grind indicators wear off with normal washing just Ike my cold brew and measuring cups and spoons made by them. Also the cup doesn’t lock though the instructions state it should click. The only thing I can think they are talking about is the flimsy metal tab touching the back of the cup. Not a click, just plain confusing. Other than for what I just stated it’s a good grinder for the money just needs some improvements.

reviews.reviewTitle: Makes a faint subtle humming sound all. the. time.
reviews.reviewText: Look, this is a really solid unit. It grinds beans. I then drink the coffee that I make from said ground beans. I am then caffeinated and happy. No complaints there. What I will say is that when it is plugged in (and decidedly not grinding) it makes a humming noise. I don't have like super amazing hearing or anything but it is audible and if you are sensitive to that sort of thing you might want to take the pro-lifehack step of unplugging it when not in use.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder holds a pound of beans
reviews.reviewText:
My husband and teenaged daughter have recently begun experimenting with different types of coffee beans, and our tiny hand-cranked grinder wasn’t up to challenge.

My daughter can set this to a fine grind for her single-serving espressos, while my husband likes being able to set it to medium-coarse for his drip coffee maker, and grinding a pound of beans in roughly 90 seconds.

It’s easy to take apart and clean, but I find myself wishing for a bristle brush to get down in the burrs, which cannot be washed.

This is our third coffee grinder in the last few years and I really like it... when it works. Our previous grinder from Capresso ground the beans too finely, even on the highest setting and left coffee dust all over the counter. It was a mess. This OXO grinder does not have this issue! The larger grind settings work great and there is no dust. The only issue that I'm having is that sometimes I hit the grind button and it makes noise and turns off... and there are no grounds! I have to give it a shake to loosen things up and then try again. Super annoying!

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great for course grind French Press
reviews.reviewText:
I will have to restate what others are saying:
- Consistent grind at any setting
- Easy to use
- Static free
- Easy to clean.

I'm very happy with this for use with my French Press. I add a couple of scoops of coffee, run it for a 10 second time, and empty the bin into the press. It's that easy. And the images and videos don't lie, the grind is very consistent.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love the Simplicity and Ease of Use! 5 Stars.
reviews.reviewText:
Don’t understand any of the Negative reviews. The simplicity and ease of use is a real joy. The coffee is better than the Krups I used for Coarse Grind. All I do is measure 26 grams of coffee beans and put it in set it to 15 and grind it.

Static Free and weight wise the grind is the same weight as what I put in. No mess at all.

This has changed the whole morning rhythm of grinding coffees. Couldn’t stand the hand burr grinders and Krups was a little bit of work timing 5 secs for coarse grind which was not consistent or completely ground.

That being said- for the price the Krups is a pretty amazing grinder if you can zero it in. You just don’t get the consistency or the Elegant work flow as you do with the Oxo.

reviews.reviewTitle: Well built and easy to use
reviews.reviewText: I recently purchased this grinder for use with pour over coffee. I had previously used a manual grinder which worked well but was a lot of work. I am impressed with the size (not too big for countertop and a reasonable smoke colored bean storage area). Very easy to use and I like the timer feature that controls how much coffee to grind. I have not had any problems with the stainless steel grounds cup not locking into place not have I had any issue with coffee sticking to the grounds container. I have only had this for less than a week but have been happy with it so far. I will report back if I run into any issues down the road. All in all a good product so far.

reviews.reviewTitle: The splurge appears to be worth it.
reviews.reviewText: We’ve used it for a few weeks. It replaced a less expensive worn out bur grinder. I hesitated to spend more but given the last one lasted a decade my thoughts were it’s just a few cups of Starbucks a year. I’m glad I did. The grind is way more consistent and the grounds don’t fly everywhere and stick to everything when I measure the coffee. We’ve also found the coffee is now less bitter. Time will tell if this one will last as long as our last.

This grinder looks great on the counter and produces a nice consistent grind. Right now we mostly use Aeropress and I'm using setting "7". I took a picture of the stainless grinds container just after tapping out the grounds to show that it really doesn't have a problem with static clinging on to the grinds. I don't think the description mentioned the clear top to the stainless jar either, which is a nice touch. I Also took a picture of the inside of the hopper to show that there is a large plastic handle in the middle of it for removing the hopper. Great unit, would buy again!

I would have given this grinder 5 stars only if the timer setting knob stays put. It feels so loose. I secure it with Scotch tape to its max clockwise. My main complaint is It does not dispense all the beans poured in the hopper even if you shake and bang on it while it is grinding at the longest timer setting. I poured in 25 grams of coffee beans and gets only 23-24.4 grams out. I always have to run it twice to get 25 grams. I have cleaned it thoroughly short of disassembling it. I believed it is trapping a few beans in there somewhere. Buy it at your own risk.

My old coffee grinder was a mess! I was initially looking for something that wouldn't be so messy, but decided that if I was going to find a replacement I should make sure I would also be getting a good grind. After doing quite a lot of research and seeing the oxo brew conical burr grinder on multiple sites and video comparisons as being a top notch grinder I decided to buy it. The reviews are all correct! The grind is all beautifully uniform and thus makes a wonderful tasting cup of coffee. It's worth paying a little extra!
I like the way this looks and works but the grind cup never fully locks in place and vibrates out during use. I have to hold it in place or clean up a big mess.

I tried others before this one. The cap didnt seal well making a mess. The motor overheated and had to wait 30 minutes to resume grinding. Revolving blades were too high for a fine powder.

This one works well for coffee, herbs, spices and tablet medicine. The top burr part is removable; ensure it is put back in correctly. In fact, remove the top burr part periodically to clear particles.

The first one had to be replaced because the top burr part became stuck and grinding would not commence.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Grinder. Bargain At This Price.
reviews.reviewText: Bought to grind coffee for my Keurig instead of using K cups. Works well, easy to use. Had some trouble trying to clean burrs and chute as I didn't have a brush that would work. Then I thought of using the canned air that I use to clean my computer. That works perfectly. All in all, I'm highly satisfied with this grinder and consider it a bargain for the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good grinding results, except the sound
reviews.reviewText:
The espresso to medium grind are very uniform and provide a good gradient. The course setting could be chunkier. It works fast and consistently.

The sound of the device could be improved. While it's not obnoxiously loud like previously owned blade or disk-based burr grinders, the motor or internal gearing choice emits a high pitch sound reminiscent of a subtle drill or blender. One can still have a conversation. This is in compared to a bodum conical grinder that has lower pitch, but only has a short duty cycle and plastic internals around the grinder.

Metal collector is nice, keeps machine and area neat and doesn't collect many particles due to static. However I tried collecting directly into an espresso head and experienced a bit of dusting.

It's a nice grinder.

Good consistent grind. Noisy? Maybe, but not sure grinding coffee can be done silently. Not overly loud. Works great for drip or french press settings, for me. So far, so good. UPDATE: Still producing a good grind for french press and drip. I use setting 7 for drip and 13 for french press. I did notice that when plugged in and not in use, there is a humming noise produced. Not very loud, but it must be using electricity even when not grinding. Likely not using much energy, but I just unplug it when not in use. Conserve where you can!

We've been using this grinder for almost three months and are very pleased with it. Our last burr grinder was a very expensive, very large beast that was noisy and fussy about jamming and hard to clean. This grinder is none of those things. The grind is consistent, it's not unreasonably loud and it doesn't take up much space on the counter. The only time there's been an issue with ground coffee going all over the counter was the time I didn't make sure the cup was locked in place. We haven't had an issue with static at all. The only thing I would change (OXO pay attention if you're reading this) is the timer dial - it's easy to move it from your preferred setting without meaning to - I'd prefer it "click" lock on the grind time.

I am replacing the more costly OXO model with this one. (the old one served well and I liked it a lot) This one is far lest messy and much less temperamental. There is a feature that cuts the static build up in the grounds container by at least 75%. The grounds are uniform and the process is fast and consistent. I like it enough that if it quits I will get another one just like it.

This grinder looks very sharp and compliments the coffee pot for a pleasing paring. I ran several grindings thru the machine, following the instructions in their manual. I read some reviews on this grinder and their seems to be two problems that pop up. Grinder cup not clicking into place and coffee bean jams. Well to date I have had no coffee bean jams. In addition when I put the grinder cup on there is a very low click and the cup locks in place very securely. Machine works better than any other low to mid price coffee grinder I had in the past. I at this point am very well pleased with the brain coffee machine and the grinder

reviews.reviewTitle: Consistent even grind and easy to keep clean
reviews.reviewText: You can experiment for the absolute perfect brewing result for your taste. It has 16 grind choices from powder to coarse, and the ability to determine how much coffee to grind per pot by varying the number of seconds to dispense your beans into the grinder. The dials make it easy to set and repeat your choices. And the big, easy to empty stainless cup is ideal; even when the room's air is very dry creating static, it brushes out cleanly. I also like its compact footprint. I highly recommend this product for serious coffee lovers.

This is my 4th burr grinder and by far the best of them all. Super easy to clean and NOT MESSY. This one doesn't create static electricity, causing the grinds to fly everywhere. So, no mess! This became the most important feature to me. It's also built solid with easy adjustments for grind and time. Look no further this is the one and you won't be disappointed!

reviews.reviewTitle: A good grind every time so far
reviews.reviewText: The slower cooler grind is an obvious plus. Faster grinds are probably geared to the super size me mentality. It doesn't take much longer and the grounds are uniform throughout. The grind settings seem to be accurate. I left one star off for whatever might lie waiting to happen in the future. I've only been using it for a little while.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder, but draws some current when not in use.
reviews.reviewText:
The grinder works great. I like the simplicity of operation. Only two small issues.
- If you are weighing your coffee, some grounds will collect in the spout, reducing your final weight. This requires smacking or tilting the grinder to get them out.
- It is a bit of a power vampire, meaning that it draws some current even in not in use. Based on 19c/kwh (in CA) you can expect it to cost $1.66 per year when idle.
- It makes a slight buzzing noise when not in use, similar to a flourescent light tube. The noise is what prompted me to throw the Kill-A-Watt on it.

This is the best conical burr grinder out there for the price. It works amazingly, and produce a grind small enough for most home espresso machines. I've used it in an espresso machine, carafe, pour over, and French press, and it makes fantastic coffee each time. My machine does make low, quiet humming noise while plugged in (which other people have reported too), but as long as you unplug it while not in use, you'll likely never really notice it.

reviews.reviewTitle: The quick, luxurious way to grind coffee
reviews.reviewText: We never thought we'd be grinding our own coffee, but then we discovered cold brew, one thing led to another, and soon we were grinding beans using a ceramic hand grinder. That was fine, worked great, but slow, a bit messy, and we always seemed to grind too much or too little for the next batch of coffee, with inconsistent coarseness. This is quick, works great, is very consistent in the grind, and we now are grinding the exact amount we need.

I have had burr grinders in the past as a coffee enthusiast, but my complaint had been the electrostatic cling of the grinds to the plastic bins, cleaning difficulties, etc. This grinder has pretty much changed my life and works perfectly with my stainless steel French press. It's easy to use, grinds as expected, an the stainless carafe empties fairly easily with little static. No more messes on our kitchen counter.

No static problem like previous grinders I’ve used. Easy to clean. Some grinds fall out of the hole at the bottom which is annoying, but isn’t horrible. The grind size seems fairly consistent and the machine isn’t too loud. At first I tried to use the grinder to grind directly on my portafilter, but when it starts to fill up the basket, the grinds back up and clogs the machine. Therefore, you need to use the metal grind holder and transfer to portafilter. I dump the grinds onto my portafilter through the small container lid, over my trash can.

I have had this grinder for about 3 months now and absolutely love it. I have used it for a rougher Aeropress grind and also very fine for an espresso grind. I use the number 2 setting for espresso and it comes out perfect and uniform. It is a bit loud, but that is what I would expect with an electric grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: So far, everything I had hoped for
reviews.reviewText: We use this for both an automatic drip coffee maker and and espresso machine. The grinds are very uniform. It can produce grounds even more fine than necessary for our espresso maker. Changing grind size settings is relatively easy (but maybe not ideal for those with very small hands). Static cling of the grounds is somewhat of a problem, but that seems to always be a problem with any system I have used. Overall, I definitely recommend this product, given the price.

This grinder was very easy to use and quiet. Set the time for the number of seconds you would like to grind and coarseness of the grind. Since I want the enough for one pot of coffee each day, I found that 17 seconds produced just the right amount of ground coffee. Thus, in the morning, while the water is being heated for my French press, I just press the button and 17 seconds later pour the ground coffee into the French press glass. As soon as the water boils, I pour that in, wait 3 1/2 minutes and perfect coffee every time.

I was looking for a grinder that wouldn’t wake the neighbors in the morning and give me a variety of grinds. This was it. It’s quiet and gives a consistent grind for my percolator, where enough beans for 4-5 cups are ground in twenty seconds. The steel receptacle is not completely static-free, but it’s easy to tap the remaining grounds to the bottom. The clear plastic cap for the top of it seems a bit fragile compared to the thicker plastic lid above the hopper. Overall, definitely worth the money!

Bought this for my daughter. It's works quietly and seems to be made well. It did start having a bit of a problem with the beans not going down into the grinder after a month or so. I would simply remove the hopper cover and push down on the beans gently to facilitate this. Not sure what causes this. Others have mentioned it speculating it was due to the fact the unit runs so smoothly not enough vibration occurs to drive the coffee beans into the burr grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to pour, but won't grind in cold temp.
reviews.reviewText:
Super easy to use with quick pull of the output cup and then pour straight into the carafe.

But in cold weather it won't grind beans. We keep it in the garage because it's messy and noisy.

I have to jostle the beans by tapping on the top or opening the lid and stirring the beans.

Sometimes it requires multiple grind cycles to get the right amount of ground beans. I wish it worked on the first go. My previous grinder did much better in cold weather.

I bought this September 2018. Have had it for 6 months. Now I can't use it because the cheap plastic parts have broken. The front piece broke first then we turn the lip and it work. Until the second latch broke too. The lid wont stay on because of this and the safety button that is pressed only when the lid is on securely wont work because of the broken parts. Basically I now have a useless product.

+Super quiet, wow!
+Look sleek thanks to the brushed aluminum finish
+Lots of grind settings: 1-15 (with .5 increments)
+Grind timer
+Grinds fast/a lot of coffee (even on the lowest timer setting)

-Feels delicate, thin metal and plastic lids

This thing has been great! I’ve been a pour over and iced coffee guy for a little over 6 months and this has taken my hobby and passion to a new level! The coarse grind isn’t super consistent, and the “fine” wouldn’t cut it for espresso. But for drip, iced coffee, French press, pour over, it is a CHAMP!
At this price, it’s competitive with some of the big name grinders that fall into this entry level area.

Nice consistent grind size.

I had doubts about the time setting instead of being able to grind a specific weight. However, at a given time setting, the grinder produces an exact weight of grounds each time. An option to bypass this is to use a high time setting, still weigh the whole beans, adding only the weight you want.

It does make noise, however, it's a bit quieter that other grinders I've used.

reviews.reviewTitle: Quit after 3 months of sporadic use
reviews.reviewText:
It worked pretty well, then just stopped grinding. I tried cleaning it out as per the directions, tried it on multiple outlets - no luck. I'm sending it back to Oxo - maybe the warrantee will cover it.

Concept is good, execution is bad.

EDIT - Received a replacement promptly from Oxo, so that's good. Will re-evaluate in 3 more months

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder has got me in the ( coffee ) dumps
reviews.reviewText: I normally love OXO products. This is not one of them. The basket does not need to be pushed against the back so if the basket moves the grinds go ALL OVER. You would think it would have a button or cradle to keep the basket near the spout but no.. Also the printing of the buttons and rest of the unit has bled so no more OXO logo or marks of some of the nobs . This is after 2 months of use. The grinds are nice quality but I would get another unit due to the spillage and the lack of quality of the unit .

reviews.reviewTitle: Good basic grinder, no dusty countertops!
reviews.reviewText:
Does a good job for the price. Quick, not too loud, no spray of grounds around the machine (much better than competing grinders) and easy to clean. I’ve been using it daily for over a week and am pleased with the large adjustment range for grounds.

Since amount dispensed is based on a timer it is recommended that you experiment and weigh out grounds for various timings/grinds to get the optimal amount of ground beans with the press of the grind button.

OXO needs to work on their quality control. I had high hopes when I purchased this unit but upon receiving it and plugging it in, I soon realized that I received a defective unit as it was 100% dead. I promptly returned it and purchased a grinder from KRUPPS and I'm completely happy with the new unit. It cost a little more but the added features are worth the price and it actually worked when I plugged it in!

reviews.reviewTitle: Sure beats my old grind abd brew, except for convenience
reviews.reviewText: Night and day difference. I loved old Grind and Brew, but it sadly died after six years. The ngrind quality is so much better and the resulting brew is definitely better. But it was nice toi set the pot the night before and have a fresh pot waiting for me when I awakened. So, all I need is aa automatic pot with a good burr grinder and I would be set. Highly recommended.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to setup & use - anti-static is brilliant
reviews.reviewText: Don't overlook the anti-static aspect of this - a small grounding finger touches the SS hopper that the grounds come into. Brilliant! Good, simple, adjustable grinder that has been great for our chemex drip setup. Seems great for the price $

I struggled with whether to give this grinder 3 or 4 stars, simply because the amount of static it produces is ABSURD and makes cleanup very frustrating. I thought it was supposed to be static free, so that was disappointing. Otherwise the grinder functions beautifully, and is surprisingly quiet compared to other models I’ve used.

My Barista (a Starbucks item) burr grinder gave out after 20 years of grinding every day. Bought the OXO and have used it daily for about 2 months. What I like:
1. Small footprint
2. Large capacity for whole beans.

What needs improvement:
1. The coffee ground receptacle seems to wander from under the grinding spout causing the grounds to spill out from the receptacle and onto the platform. I have tried to keep this from wandering, but have yet to find the solution. This definitely needs to be addressed.

This item was dead on arrival. I suspect a micro switch/sensor malfunction. I did like the conical, stainless steel grinding mechanism and the simple features. There is no way to change the SPEED of the grind, but that feature comes at a price I'm not willing to pay for a home grinder. I'll adjust this review when my replacement arrives.

Super consistent grind size, my wife commented on the improvement in taste the very first pot. As mentioned in other posts, much quieter than I'm used to - had Cuisinart that was much louder. As noted, you will probably have to press the grind button twice for anything over 6 cups.

Easy to take apart and put back together. Still early, but I'd definitely recommend this.

reviews.reviewTitle: bought two and both of them started jamming within a month
reviews.reviewText: Forget this dumb device. I bought one for my parents which seems to work okay but then I bought one for myself and it started jamming after a month of use. I bought a second one and this one is jamming too. Difficult to clean and the product is cheaply made so the blade is not very powerful and there isn't enough torque to spit the ground coffee down. Garbage

I love this grinder, ground coffee is always consistent. The grinder is very easy to use, however make sure you clean it out once in a while, or the grinder will get clogged up.

I particularly like this grinder over the smaller counter top grinders since it can hold a good amount of coffee beans, has multiple grinder setting levels, and it does not take up too much counter space.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grind control is awesome, not too loud.
reviews.reviewText: Poking a button and having exactly the right amount of my favorite bean, ground exactly how I want it for my glorious one cup of coffee per day is quite the luxury. It was embarrassing to buy this expensive grinder, but it works perfectly, isn't insanely noisy, and honestly, anything that can ease the launch of my teaching/parenting days in the morning when I'm constitutionally slow-witted is a blessing.

reviews.reviewTitle: great for pour over and french press coffee
reviews.reviewText: It's a great coffee grinder if you want freshly ground coffee for your pour over or french press! It does not have fine enough setting for espresso; but, it's not advertised as an espresso grinder. It is easy to clean. The time setting can easily to dialed in so you grind just the perfect amount of coffee with a single push of a button. It's relatively quiet (for a coffee grinder), I grind coffee before my family gets up and it does not wake anybody up. It holds a good amount of beans. No real cons. For the price it's a great value.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Buy for the Coffee Snob
reviews.reviewText:
In our house we do a variety of specialty coffee styles. From V60, to Chemex, to French Press, to Syphon/Vacuum brew. Each of these requires a different grinding level.
This grinder not only allows to find the right level but is really quiet compared to other grinders we have owned.
We are VERY pleased with it!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great performance, but check the fine grind settings
reviews.reviewText: This grinder looks great, is reasonably quiet, and has no static issues, even with a fine grind setting. However, some of the finest grind settings will cause the burrs to contact each other, creating metal shavings and damage to the burrs. On my grinder, setting 4 is the finest setting that can be achieved (which is extremely fine on my unit). I may contact OXO to see if there is a way to adjust the settings to ensure a full range of grind sizes are available (as my unit may not be able to effective perform the coarsest grinds.

I did like this grinder, it was convenient (especially versus my hand grinder), but it was super noisy, and the grinds seemed pretty inconsistent, and grinds still got out of the grind bin despite it having a cover, so it was a bit messy.

I think it's good but not so much at the price tag it is currently.

I’m a coffee snob. I make coffee everyday at home. I was hand grinding my beans because most electric grinders cut the beans rather than grind. Do yourself a favor and spend the money on a good conical burr grinder such as this one.

Truly mediocre product that worked like a dream for three weeks and then stopped working entirely.

I’d suggest buying something else as I was very dissatisfied after the three-week honeymoon period.

I tried cleaning out the burr grinder area —changed the type of beans too—all to no avail.

I strongly suggest buying something else

Had a Baratza Barista, Starbucks-branded, grinder for many years. But this OXO looked like a better replacement than another Baratza. The static control is great! A metal bin for the ground coffee, a contact strip touching it, and a (no pun) grounded electrical cord. No more flying coffee bits! The precise timer is also a fine improvement, as is the sealed coffee hopper. I can finally leave a few days' beans ready to grind.

I had an old coffee grinder (man, it was from the 70s!) - decided finally to upgrade when I got an espresso maker. What a difference! I love this OXO Conical Burr Coffee Grinder, and use it all the time. Perfect grind for my espresso.

I purchased this after a review I read. The review said there was no static, and the grounds stay in the cup. No grounds flying around, hooray! I did learn, the hard way, that the machine will run if the top of the grounds cup is off.

Love it. I mean to get real picky, the bin that holds the ground coffee might click in a bit more satisfactorily but other than that this works perfectly. Pleased as usual, Oxo is an extraordinary company.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good grinder but electrical hum when not being used is bothersome
reviews.reviewText: The grinder works well. However, the grinder hums when not in use. It hums all the time unless unplugged. I can imagine it is using electricity the entire time, as well. For that reason, I have taken to unplug the unit after each use. It’s annoying but not enough to discontinue use. Am I the only one with this issue?

reviews.reviewTitle: Best Coffee Grinder for the price!
reviews.reviewText: I bought this as a gift and the person loved it. Then I bought one for myself. The ability to change the grind and the duration for grinding make it so easy to grind just enough beans for one cup or a whole pot. Easy to use, no mess when removing the ground coffee from the grinder to the coffee pot. Definitely recommend.

I'm very satisfied with the grinder. Grinds perfectly and the flavor off coffee is much better then if you grind at the store. I use it for espresso machine and on setting 2 is very fine and impressively consistent. Even to much for us. We set it on 2 2/3 setting and works perfect for our espresso needs. I have to admit that we had the same problem as other people with the grinds container not clicking in. I choose to keep not to replace with amazon due to nice discount offer. Folded paper towel under container fixes issue and it clicks in. Buy and enjoy.

As other reviewers have noted, this grinder clogs easily and does not feed the beans consistently. The result is a frustrating daily trial-and-error ritual to get the right amount of grounds for our morning French press. Consequently, we invariably suffer from too strong or too weak coffee. Oxo’s products are usually ingeniously designed. This one is just frustrating, infuriating, and ineffective. It should be recalled.

Works well, easy enough to clean and the noise level is nothing compared to the blade grinder I replaced. People may complain about grounds spilling out and it does occasionally, but a simple wipe will take care of it. Very happy with this product like all of our other OXO things.

The grind size is always consistent and the timer grinds very close the same number of gram each time! The only concern I have is that the timer dial is very loose. I would prefer some drag to restrain any changes. Oh, it is really quiet compared to other grinders! I Love it!!!

So much better then my noisy old one. No longer do the cats run and hide, or my wife flinch when i need some fresh grounds. Quality for the cost is excellent for any serious coffee drinker. Using it for some course grounds for cold brewing, as well as normal for a ninja coffee bar

This was a splurge buy and it works way better than our old one. We bought it because we needed a course grinder for cold brew coffee. It works and we are happy thus far although we have only used this machine once.

I had a bodum grinder for about a year and it never did grind coarsely and I had to replace the bit. Then it died. Grinder works great. Great course grind for cold brew coffee. Very consistent not very noisy and doesn't throw grinds all over the kitchen. Would highly recommend this.
