My satisfaction using this grinder is 5 star, however, the smallest grind setting is not as fine as I was hoping for but is still acceptable. The consistency of grind is good. Set it and forget it. All in all I am very happy with the machine. The noise level is to be expected from any grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works as expected, satisfied w purchase.
reviews.reviewText: Just bought it, followed directions on cleaning and using for the first time. Works perfectly, no mess at all from the collecting container, grinds evenly and uniformly. Set it to course #13, going at the suggested 10 seconds at a time for first use. Enjoyed it w French press.

I've owned 2 other grinders before this one. This is by far the best. Put in beans, set time, press button and you get evenly ground coffee. A little less noisy, too. Click in metal cup means no mess, very little static so it empties clean. Nice.

I have been putting off purchasing a coffee bean grinder for years because I didn't want to spend the extra money. I finally got this one and I'm so happy with it. The grinds are consistent and the coffee has a great flavor. The grinder is surprisingly quiet and it's easy to clean. I wish I would have bought it much sooner.

Was gifted a Breville espresso machine for Christmas but didn't have a grinder that could grind fine enough for it - also a daily coffee drinker, so over that could do both was a necessity. The grind for espresso is perfect. This machine is so much quieter than my old one too!

reviews.reviewTitle: burr grinders improve flavor of the coffee
reviews.reviewText: The OXO burr grinder is easy to use, easy to adjust the grind settings, and simple to clean. The metal cup that holds the ground beans does cut down on the static cling after grinding. The machine is also relatively quiet. The end result is better tasting coffee. I use it primarily with a Chemex coffee pot.

This grinder is so much better than my old burr grinder that would NOT give me a consistent grind. I also didn’t realize how slow my old grinder was until I used the OXO grinder. I used to have so much coffee silt in my glass at the bottom, but I barely have any now. Seriously...I’m impressed. Yet another wonderful product by OXO!

This grinder does not have the static mess of other burr grinders. It is easy to use. Really happy with the consistent quality of the grind. Switching from blade to burr grinder has been unbelievable improvement in taste of the coffee. I have not had problems with it getting stuck as other reviewers have mentioned. I have had it for about 2 mos now.

reviews.reviewTitle: Brew the best coffee you can
reviews.reviewText: I buy whole beans from Coffee Bean Direct and receive them 3 days from when they are roasted. Grinding fresh beans makes for much better coffee and this little unit does a great job. I am enjoying a great cup as I write this review!

Fairly quiet, considering the type of grinder this is. Easy to clean, because the entire hopper assembly comes apart. It's also possible to remove the hopper with beans still in it - this is also VERY helpful. Stainless steel hopper is less susceptible to "static coffee problem" than other grinders. It produces a nice, even grind, without clumps.

This is a great coffee grinder and makes the coffee taste so much better than my old blade grinder. Very versatile with easily adjustable grind levels and time setting. Very quiet. The static electricity does not generate a lot of “dust”. Easy to clean. If you love coffee you will love this grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best coffee grinder that I have ever used!
reviews.reviewText: Best coffee grinder that I have ever used! I cannot find any fault with the grinder. Very happy to find that there was absolutely no static and no mess with this machine. I use it to grind Italian roast beans for espresso machine and a courser grind for a drip machine.

reviews.reviewTitle: 11 mo later still a pain to use
reviews.reviewText: It grinds my coffee really well but jams up every time. I have to take it apart & clean it after each use. Granted I grind a half bag at a time but that's why I purchased an expensive large capacity model. I find myself avoiding it because I know I'm going to have to go through taking it apart and cleaning it. I'm giving up. Too much hassle.

Although I need to "practice" more with this grinder to get the perfect grind size for my coffee maker, I'm very happy with this product. It is well made and attractive. I don't wake my whole family when I use this machine except with the smell of freshly ground/brewed coffee wafting up to their rooms.

reviews.reviewTitle: Close to a 5 star, but not quite
reviews.reviewText: The only reason I'm not giving this a 5 star review is because as the coffee grinder is running, the receptacle for the grounds vibrates away from the stand and grounds can get all over the counter top unless you hold it in place. Other than that, it's quiet, efficient, and has enough settings for the coffee snob in me!

My husband and I love this coffee grinder! We can grind only what we need each morning, and it's quick and quiet. Further, the stainless steel receptacle is easy to use (when we're bleary-eyed). Definitely worth the price!

Consistent grind, a bit loud but then again it is a grinder so that’s to be expected. Neat, no loose ground everything I grind is placed in the cup without spillage. Intuitive controls, beautiful clean design. No complaints after several months of use.

I had a manual burr grinder that became too inconvenient to use so I thought I’d give this a try. Took a few runs with some cheap beans to get my grind right, but once I got the grind and timer set the way I like it, I just push a button and I’m good to go. It’s great for my morning espresso. So far, I really like it.

I was hesitant to purchase after reading the feedback. I've found it to be very easy to use and maintain. It's quiet, grind is consistent and there is little or no static problems. My old grinder used to get grounds all over. I'd recommend it to friends.

Can continue talking while it runs. Strong. Options for days on that grind
I use a pour over and found 10.5 to be perfect.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is an outstanding coffee grinder.
reviews.reviewText: I’ve been using the OXO for about a month now, and could not be happier. It produces a consistent-throughout grind without static cling, with the exception of slight cling in the chute below the burrs which is easily coped with. It took some experimenting to establish the grind time for a specific quantity, but now I’m getting the perfect grind and quantity with the push a button. I’ve had no problem with flow of beans into the burrs, but none of the blends I use are particularly oily.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great and makes the best coffee
reviews.reviewText: The only complaint is the noise, but that doesn't affect the taste of the coffee.It makes a clean, fine cup. Love this grinder.
This is so easy to use and clean. It grinds the beans perfectly and quickly.

I have been using a Breville "Smart Grinder" for about ten years. We recently misplaced two parts and I purchased this replacement at one-half the price of a new Breville. It works just as well for our purposes.

This is a wonderful product. Well made, reasonably quiet, and performs well. The anti-static feature isn't perfect, but works well and much better than that for any other grinder I have tried. I like the stainless steel container. It's so much better than the blade coffee bean grinders. It actually grinds all the beans! We alternate between different kinds of coffee for different coffee makers, so I just measure out the amount of whole beans I need, select the coarseness, and then grind them.

Like the anti static grounded plug. As far as some people complaining about the stainless steal cup I find it perfect. And I have not had any issues with any beans get stuck above the burr guard like some have mentioned. Still getting used to getting the timer dialed in to get the right amount of ground.

This is a very nice grinder, it is quiter than my last grinder, and has solved the static electricity problem with a grounded plug. the grind is consistent. The grind time needs to be a little longer that my previous grinder but that is not an issue.

Takes care of beans very nicely, always a nice, uniform consistency. I use it for pour over coffee and finding the right coarseness took a bit of trial and error, but now that it is set, I get a consistent grind every time.

For many years we used A cuisinart burr grinder. It wasn't performing well so I researched and decided on the OXO. It is everything I expected and more. The grind is very uniform, it is easy to clean, and it is very quiet. It is an excellent value. Very pleased.

This is an awesome coffee grinder. It cost more since it is a conical burr grinder, but its worth the money. Gives a good consistent grind on my coffee. Have had it for about 6 months now and me and my wife are avid coffee drinkers, never have issues.

So far so good... I am amateur in coffee grinder but this item seems to be a good option. I don’t have to go to stores to grind coffee and can make small batches of coffee at the time with better aroma

Works very well. Since it gives a consistent grind, I'm finding that I'm using fewer beans to get the strength I like as compared with the blade grinder I've used for years - so, money saved on beans.

My one design issue: the dark plastic bin looks stylish, but it's difficult to see if its empty when the unit is tucked away in a corner of the counter. A clear bin would be better.

I needed a perfect grind for my poor over coffee and this grinder has the adjust-ability for grind size and quantity!
It makes a perfect grind every time. The only negative if any is the coffee spout holds a bit when finished and if I move the grinder it spills out leaving a small clean up job.

This conical burr grinder is so easy to use and it creates perfectly ground coffee.
I roast from green beans and want my coffee to taste like the freshest coffee possible. This grinder satisfied all my needs.

reviews.reviewTitle: Everything I wanted in a burr grinder
reviews.reviewText: Love this thing, functions well, easy to use, set and forget once you get your timing / coarseness dialed in. Looks great and the price is reasonable.

I love it. I have the timer preset for my desired amount, and the fineness set to where I want it. I just press the button and get exactly what I want. It’s reasonably quiet, and not much coffee sticks to the basin. I’m not sure what could be done to make it better. I drink drip or French press.

reviews.reviewTitle: High quality and looks great on counter.
reviews.reviewText: Perfect course grind for my French press. Easy to load and clean, and comes with a nice measuring scoop. Very little noise and grinds quickly. Had it jam up one time on me, gave it a quick shake and it started feeding again. I think this was because a very oily dark roast.
Awesome grinder. Powerful but slightly noisy for the apt neighbors. Grinds evenly and consistently. Buy this before you by a $35 one. You will be glad you did.

I've only been using this for about a month, but I'm very happy with it. I was hesitant to spend $100 on a coffee grinder, but am liking this one much better that my last one, a Braun that was about $50. This one is quieter, and much less messy than the Braun, which left ground coffee on the kitchen counter.

reviews.reviewTitle: Big improvement over my old grinder
reviews.reviewText: I use this every day. It's pretty quiet for a grinder, and ground coffee does not accumulate on the receptacle. A very good grind, too, once you get it set. My only wish would be that you could set it to produce more ground coffee at once - for a full 12-cup pot, I need to run it twice.
The only reason for four stars is that the grind isn't consistent; there are some very fine particles that get through the filters, but in general it works well.

I grind 6 cups of coffee at a time for cold brew using the most coarse setting. This little machine is quick and convenient, makes little dusty mess and is really pretty quiet. No need to spend a lot to get the job done.

Only used for coffee beans. Easy to move from fine to course and back, large canister for beans and container for ground coffee large enough to grind for ten cups. Latter easy to clean if necessary due to size and material.
It works good but I have to always tap it because the last few beans get stuck. It's noisy but I really like fresh ground coffee so what the heck.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder, no static charge, consistent grind
reviews.reviewText: Nice relatively quiet unit. I'm very happy with the stainless steel collector, eliminates the static charge that plague other grinders with non metal containers. Liked this unit so much, bought one for my daughter's family. Everybody is happy...freshly ground coffee every morning.

Like most other reviewers, I too have noticed that the grind catching pot does not latch in place into the grinder. That said, I've not needed it to. This grinder consistently grinds evenly, quietly, and with very little vibration. Probably one of the best grinders for the money.

Man, this thing is consistent. What a great pile of evenly-sized crumbs it makes. Coffee tastes great. Only trick is you need to work out your own grind time, based on weighing the grounds... but a small price to pay...

reviews.reviewTitle: A coffee grinder that doesn't spray grounds all over the counter!
reviews.reviewText: Uniform grind, easy to clean and no static. So much better than the Capresso we had before this.

This grinder does espresso well, and a nice grind for my percolator. The only issue so far has been infrequent 'bean jams' in the hopper, a thump on the counter gets things moving again but then you end up guessing how much more you need to grind to make up the difference. Longevity is an issue I can't address yet but after a few months all is well.
My blade grinder wasn't cutting it and frankly, while my hand crank grinder worked well, I'm just too lazy. I was able to dial this in for each of my brewing methods and was able to get great coffee.

So far so good. Recently upgraded to this grinder from a spice grinder that (obviously) gave really inconsistent grounds. This thing is super quiet and seems to give a really consistent grind on my coffee for pour overs at home :)

We loved this grinder until it stopped working. We mostly grind French Roast beans which are very oily and I suspect the grinds get too jammed up. We have disassembled and performed intense surgery on the grinder to free up the plugged area, but it jams up again after about grinding a couple tablespoons worth of beans. Very disappointed.

I previously owned a burr grinder that was messy and loud. This grinder is comparatively quiet and keeps the ground coffee to itself. I can use it when I get up early and not wake up the household. Perfect grind every time!
I should have bought this years ago! I get a very consistent and even grind and I think I end up saving $ because I don’t have to use as much coffee.
I like my coffee grounds very corse. This will grind corse enough, and it's fast. Easy to clean. Every one should have one of these.
Works great fir consistent grinding of beans. Makes that first sip in the morning amazing!
Does a good job grinding the beans and I like the variety of settings. It does have a buzzing sound when it is plugged in which is rather strange but I just unplug it after use

Bought this grinder for pour over coffee and so far it’s been pretty great. Had it for about 2 months and have played with the grind sizes. They seem really consistent. The thing is a bit loud but not too bad. Sometimes the hops don’t filter into the grinder and it will whir but I just give it a little shake and it’s fine. Would buy again.
Use it all day everyday. Researched several months before buying this. Super happy with my purchase. So many settings to make THE perfect grind depending on the coffee! HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

I read a ton of reviews and went back and forth on several models. I ended up selecting the OXO. I have been very pleased with the quality of the grind and the low noise level of the machine. Very easy to use, looks great, and makes a great cup of coffee.
After hours of research chose this reasonable grinder. It is a 5-star grinder and results in a an even grind that makes an excellent cup of coffee.
Wow, I didn’t know it was possible to have evenly ground coffee at home! I no longer have to depend on the supermarket grinder. Don’t even bother with no-burr grinders.
I really like it. I used it to make a fine expresso grind for aeropress and then a course grind for french press when friends came over. Worked quickly and easily and seems very well made.
Very quiet smooth running grinder. More expensive than previous grinder, but worth it. This one is also a lot less messy
Love the convenience of pushing the button and walking away. Also love that I get the same tasting coffee pot after pot because my grounds are consistently the same.
Beautiful and simple. No silly glowing lights or beeping tones, just a dial a button and ground coffee. It’s nice and narrow as well, doesn’t take up too much space.
Well-thought design produces an even grind and nice appearance. The hopper, the burrs, and the grounds cup are all easily cleaned.
No messy as my previous grinder. It works well and has setting for a variety of grinds. I really like it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best grinder we've purchased to date!
reviews.reviewText: We especially like this grinder, having had several others. It is all of the above: Easy to clean, easy to use, but best of all, the noise level is very acceptable. Do not be afraid to purchase this grinder.
relatively quiet for a grinder, wide range of grind settings, large reservoir...what's not to like.
This burr grinder is excellent. Relatively quiet, and the neutralized bin is a great feature. It's a snap to set up and use. You won't be disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Anti-static really does cut down on dust
reviews.reviewText: Upgrading to this grinder has made us happy our last (mr coffee) broke. It did take a few tries to find the right settings for the perfect cup. It did jam up on us once, but was easy to disassemble and clear.
I researched coffee grinders for many hours and I’m glad I bought this one! We’ve used it daily for a month and it’s flawless plus it looks very stylish.
This is the best grinder I have ever used, it's easy to clean, grinds well, and is easily disassembled.

I love this grinder. It replaces a perfectly functional Cuisinart grinder that made such a ridiculous mess I had to keep it on a big tray.. There is still a little dust but nothing like what I was living with, it sits on the counter like it's supposed to. Better grind too.
I am impressed, this machine is very quiet, enabling me to listen to NPR while using, it is also fast and efficient, I highly recommend this product.
This is an A+ device.

reviews.reviewTitle: A quality grinder makes all the difference.
reviews.reviewText: We are so happy with this grinder. It's made our morning coffee brews SO much more palatable. Perfect for home use.
The best coffee grinder I have ever used and I have used them for many years
Perfect for making enough coffee grounds for a pot of coffee, while the rest of the beans stay fresh. No more mess in my kitchen! Should have purchased this a long time ago.
We have used several grinders through and found the OXO Brew to do a good job grinding and easy to clean after each use. We would recommend OXO.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use with uniform results
reviews.reviewText: Ground bean size very uniform. Size selection easy to read.I prefer this unit to a more expensive one that stopped working
Nice and quiet!! And grinds quickly. There is some static. Wish the grind size could go bigger
Grinds consistently to the desired coarseness. Noise is low. No cleaning problems

This has been a great coffee grinder so far. Have only used it a couple of weeks and can't give a full five star on the durability and cleaning. After putting it together I would assume the cleaning part will be very easy.
Dont know a bunch about coffee grinders, however this one works perfect for what I need. Easy to use, multiple adjustments for grind, quick and quiet.

Which the time had longer settings
Other than that best grinder we have owned.
I love this grinder! Much quieter than other models too. Stainless steel cup is a definite PLUS and puts this above other models with that alone.
Been using it in our office for a few months now and it works great!

First burr grinder!
Makes coffee like never before!
We bought this based after researching ratings for grinders, and it lives up to expectations. Very nice machine, very easy to keep clean.
Overall, this is a decent burr grinder but I find it messy (especially in the winter when the humidity is lower) to clean up.
Worth every penny. Grinds coffee perfectly, quietly, and effortlessly.
Awesome! Quieter than my Cuinart Burr grinder. Easier to clean. Looks great

This is my first burr coffee grinder and I Love it! I don’t even use a scoop for measuring. I figured out how long to set the grind timer for a pot. It has a lot of grind settings and is quieter than my old blade grinder. It seems to be well made. I have not had it long enough to review durability. So far it has worked great!
Did a lot of research before we bought this grinder. My husband loves it, it works great. Grinds evenly with a reasonable noise level. Plus the static is handled well since it has the grounded clip.
Stopped working in less than 3 months. Would get clogged constantly

The instructions say that the grounds holding container clicks into place. I have found this not to be true or I am missing something. This is a nice grinder. I have only used this for a week. I find the grind "mess" to be more than I had anticipated.
8-23-18. Upgrade to 4 stars. This grinder does all you ask of it. Do not overlook manufacturer's recomendation to coarsen grind to remove bitternace. It works 1 click at a time.
has been excellent and it is now a month later
This grinder works well. Not to noisy. Grinds are consistent. I like that I can grind for expresso or french press.

I can't say anything about the long term reliability. But after the first couple of weeks, its clear that the OXO punches way above its weight class. Its easy to keep clean. The design is very well thought out. This is yet another great OXO product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wow! Yes, this is the one. Best value conical grinder period.
reviews.reviewText:
Love this grinder. I have a Breville Smart Grinder for my home but picked this up for my office! I love everything about it. It's way quieter than a burr grinder and grinds my beans uniformly for a great pour over.

If you're in the market for a great conical grinder at a great price this is the one to get!
If you like fresh coffee you must have one of these.
The timer is accurate, the noise level is low and the amount of "dust" is minimal. And it's about $150 cheaper than the Barzata we loved in the past. (Until it got to $250.)
I do find this grinder to be a bit noisy but the ability to grind from fine to coarse out weighs that. Easy to read dial and adjustments are simple. A very good buy for the price!
Works wonderfully! Easy to use and does what is needed
I barely compliment a product but this is a solid machine. Looks like it will last decades.
Works perfectly wouldn’t change a thing! Great grind.
Purchased for making cold brew coffee. We love it.
This grinder has worked perfectly for me thus far. I use it almost exclusively to grind coffee for a French presss. It really does a great job. Totally satisfied.
This grinder is awesome, it's quite and does a superb job of grinding coffee (well it is a "coffee grinder").

reviews.reviewTitle: Has several grind settings which are very accurate
reviews.reviewText: Works well designed well a bit noisy
This has stepped up my coffee game. Awesome and super user friendly
This is the best of three grinders ive had. Quite and easy to use
Seems to be well made with metal gears. Only downside is that sometimes I have to tweet the bin to get it to start.
Sure is great to have no coffee mess. Uniform grind makes perfect coffee. We love it.
Husband loves this one. Perfect grind everytime.

reviews.reviewTitle: A quiet grinder can use in early morning
reviews.reviewText: Much better than my previous burr grinder ( Mr coffee) easy to use/clean and important to me the OXO grinder is fairly quiet.

This grinder does an excellent job with consistency and smoothness. Love that you can store a few days of beans in the hopper and set your preferred grind and just push the button each morning. By the way it is also quiet.
Very pleased with this product. Worth the price.
Works well.
Purchased as a gift. Used it with the person I gave it to and seemed great.
This thing is awesome! Highly recommend.

Very happy with this grinder. Finally enjoying freshly ground coffee in the morning!
Worked very nicely...for three months. Then it stopped grinding. I thought it was clogged. I cleaned it thoroughly, and it still doesn't work. Hopefully I can return it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Simple to use and great coffee grounds
reviews.reviewText: I was looking for a new coffee grinder when this became available on Amazon. It has an easy setup, easy to clean, and simple to use. The quality of the grind is accurate to the setting. It can easily be taken apart to clean or store. Highly recommended.
This is a great grinder. I am very happy with it. Works as it should.

Clogs regularly, depending on how fine you grind, the oil and moisture content. For us it’s an issue. The appliance makes a humming sound when not in use, we unplug it afterwards. Good consistent grind.

This coffee grinder is very quiet and fast! We love it and it’s a total upgrade from our old one.
I absolutely love this grinder.
So as expected it is a bit loud, easy to clean and use. The grind is great for espresso all the way to a simple cup of coffee.
It's a fine burr grinder for the price. Definitely has some feeding problems, but overall for $100 you can't expect too much. The grind is consistent enough to keep it.

reviews.reviewTitle: but it is so much better than the Krups I have been using for the ...

Works well but the grind is a little variable. That said it is a good value for the money.
Quit working after 10 days.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works well, cleAn right away, be happy

So much quieter than our old unit.

Kind of expensive, 30 seconds is the longest it will grind before restarting. Usually takes 3 cycles to grind 80 grams of beans. Must weigh beans separately.

reviews.reviewText: First, this is not the higher priced OXO Conical Burr Grinder with a scale, but rather a striped down version. Hence, the lower price. reviews.reviewText:
I really like this grinder, but it has a few flaws for its price. The plastic knob jiggles and shakes as it grinds; I've seen worse, but this one hasn't broken (yet). The grind looks great, but a few beans get left in the hopper on occasion; I regularly get yesterday's beans in today's grind (which isn't really a problem unless it stays for too long or I switch beans).
Overall, I like it.
Stopped working after one use.

This OXO On burr grinder is tall so it has a small footprint, a plus when counter space is limited. The hopper holds a full pound of beans while my current unit only holds 3/4 pound. There are ample selections (15 choices) between fine and coarse (turn the hopper to select) to accommodate any taste or coffee brewing technique from fine for espresso, medium for automatic drip to coarse for French press.

My last burr grinder is a popular model made by a company with a name that starts with the letter C. The other has served me well but this one is superior in a number of ways but most importantly in sound level during grinding. My old model is deafening to the point that I usually leave the kitchen while it is operating. This just can’t be good for hearing long-term. The OXO operates quietly--a world of difference.

Other pluses with this unit—the bean hopper is made of tinted UV plastic to protect the coffee beans from light. The brushed stainless steel housing is fingerprint resistant and the grounds do not adhere to the sides of the stainless steel grounds container like they do with the plastic receptacle on my previous machine.

Quantity is selected by time between 10 and 30 seconds chosen by turning the OXO dial. It is suggested that to determine amount of grounds needed start using the 10 second selection and measure the output, etc.

I ran the test on medium grind using the included coffee scoop which holds approximately two scant tablespoons. At 10 seconds roughly two scoops were created, 20 seconds 5 scoops and 30 seconds 8 scoops. This is offered as a general guideline and may vary.

There is a clearly written Instruction book included but operation is straightforward just be sure not to overfill the grounds container because it can back-up in the grinding shoot and burn out the motor. If the bean hopper empties before it finishes grinding just press the OXO button on the timing dial to stop the motor.

The heavy-duty cord is about 38 inches long and has a three-prong plug. A comparable extension cord may be used if needed. The motor has overheating protection so it automatically turns-off. Excellent unit with user-friendly features.

This thing makes great ground coffee very quickly and quietly. On its finest settings, it’s too fine for espressos, and on its most coarse, whole beans just fall though. Actually I don’t know that, because who wants course ground coffee? 3 is good for my aero press.

It is much larger than you’d expect, and it comes in four slightly-smaller-than-the-next boxes, like a corrugated Russian doll. You can re-nest them and only fill half of your giant recycle bin.

Let's acknowledge up front I'm just as likely to fill a styrofoam cup with some swill that has been burning all day on a Bunn machine while I'm waiting for my oil change to be completed as I am to buy unroasted single sourced beans, roast and eventually grind to craft my own very special cup of espresso. However, when the mood strikes me, I will hand grind beans in a ceramic conical burr grinder to fill nespresso capsules (because despite what Nestle tells you I have no idea what's actually in those pods) or K-cup pods since I'm too cheap to regularly buy at retail prices. I understand the potential differences in particle uniformity associated with use of steel blades or ceramic, conical burr as opposed to flat, the possibility of heating in the grinding process, static and all the other buzz words and phrases. What it devolves to is, at 6:30am I really don't care all that much and if the grinder in the Cuisinart hadn't stopped working I probably wouldn't be posting on this product page.

This is a very good machine for those of us who don't have to have the absolute best and it is definitively less labor intensive than cranking a hand grinder for 5 minutes to get enough grinds for a single 8 oz cup. It has 15 grind settings from very fine to coarse, has a one touch adjustable timer setting for up to 30 seconds per grind, a convenient steel container for collection of product and will accept up to one pound of beans in the UV protective hopper. It employs steel blades and is relatively easy for cleaning and maintenance. For those who demand precise measurements, unfortunately it does not have an integrated scale.

Are there better machines? Absolutely, however for most coffee drinkers who prefer to use whole beans, I'm confident this model will do just fine.

I was pleasantly surprised by this grinder. I have a less expensive burr grinder that does the job. But like many grinders, my old one pushes the grounds horizontally out of a chute. The grounds fall into an all plastic container. There are two problems with that. When you remove the plastic container, some of grounds inevitably fall out, each time adding to a growing mess of grounds that ends up all over the counter. Also, grinding causes the grounds to become statically charged and they stick to the plastic container.

This grinder uses a metal collector with a plastic lid. The grounds don't stick to the metal. Also, the grounds drop straight down from a vertical chute. No mess from spillage and no mess from static cling. I'm really happy that this machine does not make a mess on the counter top.

The grinder is simple to understand, adjust, and use. But the real kicker is that it is relatively quiet. My old grinder left no doubt that it was working, as it made a loud grinding sound. This one makes a much softer sound. It was so quiet relative to my old grinder, that I thought maybe the beans were stuck and the grinder was "spinning its wheels". I turned it off to prevent damage, but to my surprise, it was functioning perfectly. The grounds were in the container.

If you are looking for a burr coffee grinder, I highly recommend this one.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice, relatively small and works quite well
reviews.reviewText:
I researched coffee grinders a lot - reviews, comparisons and whatever I could find. It appeared that I was looking at spending between $230 and $300 to get a basic, intro level grinder. For those aficionados who insist on the very best and can swill some coffee and tell you the bush it came from, the cost can go far, far higher. And even then there were reviews about static cling, beans jamming, etc.

I simply wanted to grind my own beans for a decent cup of coffee each morning. This $100. grinder works great. In the months I have had it I have never experienced a jam or problem of any kind. It might not have the super fine separation of hundreds of different grind settings some folks want (it has 15 though) and I have no idea if it will grind fine enough for espresso, but for grinding coffee I fail to see the downside. It has conical burrs and you just set the timer and press go. At first I just tried different times and then used a measuring spoon to make sure I had the correct amount of coffee I needed. Soon I could just set a particular time and I was good to go with no further measuring needed.

Now, please be aware that this grinder does not have burrs coated in unicorn dust like the machines costing up to $1000 and if your life revolves around pulling that perfect espresso shot, you may want to look elsewhere. But for most "normal" people, this machine will work just fine.
Manual says this grinder comes with an integrated scale for grinding by weight. It does not.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good looks and performance. Incredible grind consistency.
reviews.reviewText: I just replaced my old burr grinder with the OXO unit. Ok, now I know what a consistent grind should look like. It delivers an absolutely uniform grind. It’s quieter than my old grinder and feels solid and well put together. Nice looking too. It’s a great match for my Bonavita Brewer. Super easy to clean, the parts just lift right out. Although it delivers a great grind, it does it slowly. For 80 - 90 grams of ground coffee, it’s going to take the full 30 seconds on the timer and then some. From what I understand, slow isn’t necessarily bad when it comes to grinding coffee. I like the fact that you can remove the hopper with beans still in it. In case you want to empty out the hopper and fill it with an exact measured amount of beans, or if you need to clean the unit. My old grinder didn’t do that and I had to turn the entire unit upside down to empty the hopper.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds Evenly, Quietly, and Consistently for Drip & Aeropress Grinds
reviews.reviewText:
I must admit that since I could not find a "discount" price on this grinder I bought it from the place that always offers 20% off discount coupons. I consider this an amazing price for a grinder that so far (one month) does a great job compared to the manual, ceramic burr grinder it replaced. Even at the full price it's still a good buy compared to the prices for other conical steel burr grinders. I have been using both medium roast and the oily, dark roast beans without any problems. I have not tried espresso or french press grinds since I use either my Aeropress for single cups and regular drip grind for larger pots.

Since I measure the weight of beans I need before I put them in the grinder, I set it to grind for 20 seconds, and either press the grind button multiple times to finish grinding or press to stop early if I'm grinding only 20-25 grams for a single serving. I do find that if I tap the body of the grinder and then turn it on for just an additional second I get the final bit of coffee out of it.

I've cleaned the unit once a week by removing the outer burr, which just takes a twist to remove, and brushing out any partially ground beans that remain. Takes just a minute.

The stainless steel grind cup really is antistatic. After dumping out the grounds, I only have to tap a few times on the side to release the few remaining grounds. Much, much better than an old grinder with a plastic cup I had many years ago.

I really like the way Oxo designs their products. The coffee scoop included with this unit is shaped like a shovel, which makes it very easy to add coffee bit by bit either before grinding the beans or after they have been ground. I had another grinder that came with a conical scoop that is more difficult to use when adding the last few beans or ground coffee to get to just the right reading on my digital scale.

One more shout out to Oxo. They get 6 or 7 stars for customer service. Before I bought this unit I called their customer service to find out if I could get replacement burrs. The phone rep. took my name and address and then apologized for the burr not working and said they would ship me out a replacement right away. I told her it was just a pre-sales information call, but I got a replacement burr in the mail anyway. Thanks Oxo!

I can say I liked to Oxo grinder so far. It is not perfect, however it game me consistent coffee, cup after cup. So far I went thru 5-6 pounds of it, and was generally satisfied.

The grind is mostly consistent. It is not a "high end" device, however as can be seen from the attached photo it gives nice results at different coarseness settings. The only thing I would have asked for would be a "0" level for Turkish coffee. The lowest "1" is good for espresso.

There are two settings on the device. First the mentioned coarseness, and I found 2 worked best for Aeropress, and 1 for espresso. The second is the timer, allowing a consistent output volume. (It is based on time, not directly volume though, so grind size also affects it. The photos shows this as well). For a reference, I was getting ~15 grams of level "1" espresso at 12 seconds.

Finally, the cleaning is also easy. However make sure you put everything back tightly. Otherwise it does not work right, and it is very noticeable. If this were to happen, just remove the bin and the metal grinder, and reattach again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use, good result, some small issues
reviews.reviewText:
I had a few questions about this grinder -

- Can it grind directly into the filter cone? I use a Hario Number 2 pourover cone and filters, and the answer is yes. See picture. (YMMV).

- Does it have a consistent grind? The answer is that the grind is very good - I put about a quarter cup of medium grind though two strainers, large and small hole, and the too-large pieces were negligible, while the too-fine pieces were about a tablespoon's worth. See picture.

- Is it cleanable? Mostly. Both hoppers are hand washable, but the instruction have warnings about using any kind of liquid to clean the chute and the two burr plates. I may take a screwdriver to the guts anyway, inasmuch as I really want to periodically deep clean my burrs.

- Is it easy to use? The grinder is utterly intuitive. Choose grind, choose time, push button. If you do basically the same grind every morning you will quickly fine tune both of those settings. My one beef here is that the grind is selected by rotating the entire top hopper. I'm sure someone thought that this was clever, but if you have any kind of grip issues this is problematic (and OXO should know better).

Pretty good. 4.5 stars.

reviews.reviewTitle: A great solution for drip or cold brew coffee
reviews.reviewText:
I've used a variety of burr and conical burr grinders, and this is a nice one. It does have the capacity to measure out a set dose of ground beans via a timer. This is fine for drip, French press, cold brew, or I suppose peculator (do people still use them?). I suppose you could for espresso, but I'd still measure by volume, and it's not the best at super fine grounds. For starters there's a ton of static, and the metal burrs get hotter faster than ceramic ones, and it just never gets the size right. I won't dock this machine, as I didn't expect this to replace a $400 specialty grinder.

I've had great results with drop coffee and cold press (using a French press). I like the tall format, which should still fit under most cabinets.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perfect Espresso at a Good Price
reviews.reviewText:
I absolutely love this OXO grinder. The design makes it easy to disassemble for cleaning and looks sleek on the counter. The grounds container does not make a mess and the material is not too prone to fingerprints. The top bean container has a wide mouth with a lid that stays in place without any vibrating noises when in use. The controls are super intuitive and the sound level is not bad. In short, a very well designed machine for everyday use.

One of the weaknesses of many coffee grinders in this price range is the espresso grind being too large. The cheapest blender style grinders can do it if left for around 3-4 minutes, but by then the coffee is hot and has a burnt bitter flavor. On the finest setting, this OXO grinder gives an ideal texture with no burnt or bruised flavor at all.

I sometimes like OXO products and other times find them junky. This is my favorite one, and possibly the best grinder around for the price.

SET-UP
Set-up was a breeze. I washed the hopper and 'grounds container', let them dry, and assembled the unit, which was simple. I put a few ounces of beans in the hopper and plugged it in.

IN USE
You rotate the hopper to select a grind (the adjustment is very fine, so you should have no problem finding a grind you like). I set it to '6' for pour-over coffee. Then you set the dial to the number of seconds of grinding you want and press the button (if you need to, you can stop it grinding by pressing the button again). It grinds fast, about 1 gram per second at the '6' setting. I use 17 grams (3 scoops) for my morning coffee, so I set it to 17 seconds. The grind looks very consistent, and so far, the coffee we've made has tasted excellent.

I'd prefer not to store my beans in the hopper, so I'd love to know if I can measure my three scoops into the empty hopper and grind them, but the manual doesn't mention whether you can use the unit this way. It could be bad for the burr to grind until it's empty every time.

I will say this is the first and only burr grinder I've ever had so I cannot compare it to other burr grinders, but just to other coffee methods. But I was excited to try it!

I must say it does a great job on the whole! Nice consistent fragrant grinds that work well!

It's noisy...but less than I expected to be honest. The design is nice, thoughtful...contains everything well.

Biggest complaints are: it's tough to clean fully. There are going to be grinds in it that are just hard to get out without a lot of effort. The other complaint is that it sometimes takes a second grind to finish the job...in particular if I put in a small amount, oddly. Minor nit though.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good burr Grinder with simple controls
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using the grinder for quite a while now, making coffee daily at the office with a wide variety of coffees. First, the static electricity problem is extremely minor. A little coffee sticks to the metal cup, but can easily be cleaned out. The grinder works every time and has not clogged yet. I have it set for 20 seconds to make 8 standard cups of coffee at a medium fine setting. If you use a really fine setting, the grinding time increases a lot. A really coarse setting does not make very good coffee for a drip maker with a paper filter. I just read other people's reviews, since I was thinking of buying a second grinder, and am surprised at some of the reviews compared to my experience. This suggests a quality control issue in manufacturing, with some very good and others flawed. I do not know about the manufacturer's exchange policy, but at $99, I would find out if I got a bad one. So far, I am very happy after months of use.

Easy to set up. But, it takes a few tries to calibrate. This is because it uses a timer for grinding. The solution is to put the regular number scoops that you have been using into the hopper at the top, set the timer for 20 seconds or longer, and time it with a watch or cell phone. Next time, you can fill the hopper and use the same time that you measured. This should do it. Operation is easy. Set the grind. I recommend fine grind for most methods of making coffee that use a paper filter. You will have to periodically clean out the steel cup, since coffee will stick to it If you change coffee type, you will have to re-calibrate. Day 3: I am close to calibrating the timer vs grind fineness to grind the proper amount of coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Consistent grind and quiet operation are only a few of the things I love about this grinder
reviews.reviewText:
There is a lot to love about this coffee grinder. It is much nicer than it looks in the photo and performs every bit as well as described. I have owned both blade and burr grinders and this is by far the nicest one. And it is also very attractive looking. It is tall but has a small footprint. I do not have a lot of spare real estate on my counter top but was able to fit this in nicely.

It is easy to operate. Drop the beans in the hopper, set the timer and grind, and press the button. The grounds drop into a metal container. My old machine had a plastic container and when I would open it static would make the beans go everywhere. That does not happen with this machine. Almost no mess! I tested several type of beans and dark, oily ones have no mess; drier ones will have a very small amount of static.

It may take a few attempts to find the right grind, but there are a wide variety of settings, everything from espresso to French Press with 15 settings in all. I tested several different settings and they all produced a consistent grind.

And finally, this grinder is quiet. Very quiet. It won't wake up the household if you are the first person up and making the coffee.

A big 5 stars from me. And not just because I got it to test it, but because I love it!

I bought this based on all the good reviews compared to the negative ones. I’ve looked at many. What sold me was the static container, it truly is, just leave it be for 30 seconds after you’re done. Also, it is quiet and fast. Only problem was I don’t hear the “click” when I put the canister back in it’s position. Not sure if it would work it’s way out when grinding my beans, so to not have a “mess”, I put my finger on it. No big deal as the beans are done in no time. I’m very happy with it. Would recommend.

I'm loving this grinder. It's easy to use. The hopper comes off for easy cleaning or refilling, and the beans don't spill out, as it has a gated closure on the bottom. The grind can be adjusted from fine to course. And the grind mechanism is timed. One of my favorite features is that you can keep the time set, and then you just push the center button to run it for that duration. That means that if you brew the same amount of coffee everyday, all you need to do is push the grind button when your'e ready; no loading beans, no setting the time, and it's ready to go.

For how expensive this grinder was, I'm so disappointed that most times I press the grind button, nothing happens, or it stops grinding after about 3 seconds. I have also found that the timer function is pretty useless - the amount of time grinding beans does not seem to correlate to a specific time. Sometimes the machine functions if a shake it around a bit. I have only had the grinder for 5 months. It seems for $100 a grinder should last longer than that. The grinder is also huge and takes up a lot of counter space. I received this as a gift, so unfortunately, I don't think I can return it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds well - No Chunks - Easy Care
reviews.reviewText: I bought my grinder from Bed Bath and Beyond, ONLY because of their open return policy. I have to say, I love the way this grinds my beans. I'm currently using Starbucks, Sumatra, Medium Roast. Grinder sets at 1 notch short of 5 and it gives me the perfect (for me) cup. Even grind from start to finish, easy to clean. I'll review more once I have more *if anything as of today, I would recommend this to a friend. For those reading - I did PURCHASE this machine, so my review is strictly from my experience, not a "buy my review thing" just, thought you would like to know. :-)

reviews.reviewTitle: Received as a gift, too much work
reviews.reviewText: I had a grinder I loved for years that had the grinder timer as how many cups you wanted. You turn the dial and dump the coffee in. Then after a few years it broke and I received this over priced monstrosity. No cup setting, only seconds. So you can measure your own, because that's what you want to do before you've had your coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Any coffee grinder that weighs 1 pound is worthless.
reviews.reviewText: The Cuisinart grinder for $39 weighs 5 pounds and does a great job, no way can the motor in a 1 pound grinder be up to the job. Buyer beware, the most important spec in any coffee grinder is the weight.

reviews.reviewTitle: Honey, that's a great cup of coffee! (Update)
reviews.reviewText:
I received this item to try and review. I am a big fan of Oxo products so I was excited to see this.

My family has been using a grinder for many years that has lasted well. Initially when seeing this I thought this was not going to be a great contribution to making coffee at home. However, after trying this, I swear I can taste a difference.

1. What's in the box?: You receive the item, plus instructions and a measuring scoop (which I like is made of pretty substantial plastic).

2. Aesthetic?: well, this looks like a coffee maker. But of course this is a grinder (and personally I like the two separate since you aren't tied into one system as the grinder should last a lot longer). Here, the stainless steel (okay plastic color) is a nice touch and this looks spiffy. The buttons and everything else have a nice look and feel.

3. Use? This has an interesting way to change the grind in that you turn the grinder hopper to the desired grind (I love this!) from denser to lighter depending on the desired grind and personal preference. Then you choose the time needed, which will also depend on the amount of beans in the hopper (this takes some getting use to and isn't intuitive). From there you press the button and this grinds to the desired status into a stainless steel hopper and the coffee is ready to be placed into the machine. This couldn't be easier. Given out older traditional grinder this dines't require any real effort and the coffee is evenly ground.

The instructions do say that this isn't for a long term storage of beans and I think thats is true since the system isn't closed to the air. But really given the size (and this is about the size of a small personal coffee maker), this produces great results. I am very pleased.

The next question I like to satisfy is whether I would purchase this item. Yes, absolutely. This is far better than a simple grinder, though a bit more expensive of course. But really given the options out there for drinking great coffee (machines, this grinder, beans available) given the money laid out to the coffee stops, this isn't that much. Enjoy.

Update 3/2019: Well I have been using this for more than 7 months now. Here are some thoughts. One is the Oxo logo on the power button has worn right off from use. Also, I started to notice that the machine would quit working. So definitely there needs to be a cleaning that takes place. In fact, the machine stopped working totally. After removing the upper burr ring and putting this upside down, this worked for a bit and stopped again. I looked and took this apart and I concluded this was kaput. However, after reading some further reviews, it appeared that the machine probably had some beans sticking and causing the burrs unable to move. Sure enough, I took a Q tip and cleaned out the lower burr inside and out popped some pieces of beans. i then put this upside down and hit the bottom and more pieces of beans popped out. After that, I replaced the pieces and voila! the thing operated better than it had in months probably. So the conclusion is ion the machine does that start and stop and whatever, it isn't broken or done, it just needs to be cleaned (and frankly after understanding this, I can't imagine any similar design wouldn't have this same issue). So now, I understand the machine a bit better and this should be good to go. I suspect OXO should put out better instructions in this regard and warn users that this is possible and very fixable.

What more can I say? AS my husband mentioned, there's something about grinding your own coffee-I'm sure it's all in our heads, but when the beans are freshly ground you can taste it. The coffee is just a little bit better.

In the past, I've gotten cheaper versions of coffee bean grinders. Originally, we had a manual one-while it worked it wasn't convenient and it was hard to clean. Our next version was just a cheap electric one-also hard to clean and ground the beans very inconsistently. So for awhile we stuck to ground coffee and pods. Pods while convenient can get expensive, and the machine we had you could only get your pods online or about an hour away from our home-scratch that, not very convenient.

But this grinder? AMAZING! you can set a timer-up to 30 seconds. We've found that gives us exactly what we need for a full pot on our coffee brewer. You can set how course your want it-we like it a bit courser. And it comes with a convenient little cup to catch it all. The larger size actually makes it easier to clean for me. This grinder is a bit pricey, but I'm finding the ease of use and convenience make the price justifiable.

reviews.reviewTitle: They did everything that needs to be done.
reviews.reviewText:
Wow - quickly grinds at the finest level (the one I select) without much noise. Low enough profile to put under standard kitchen cabinets with plenty of room to spare.

I like the size; it's right for me. It's slim and tall, and I wouldn't want a larger coffee grinder, and this is more than sufficient for a household. It has a high pitch hum during operation; a blender is far louder.

Operation is easy, made simple. Rotate the bean hopper for desired fine/course setting. Rotate the front dial for grinding time. Grinding time determines the amount of grounds desired, and one can leave it on a preferred setting.

The hopper lid is dark, transparent but dark. It's dark because it blocks UV rays, thereby preserving the freshness of the beans. The instructions were ten pages followed by two pages of troubleshooting, and then the warranty - nothing dramatic, just reasonable coffee grinding. One can keep coffee in the hopper, no problem.
It seems like the opening for the ground coffee is to small and as a result it gets clogged. Also the coffee beans do not flow into grinder . Not worth the money
It works good, but I have noticed it usually misses the larger particles of the coffee beans which I have to grind again. The good thing is it does not make sound as usually the grinders make.

I have been using a good coffee grinder. It was not a burr grinder and I thought that didn't matter. I now have a different opinion. This is very adjustable for grind size and amount. We got the right setting right out of the box. The same coffee has a much better taste and the grinder is a better model that the one we had. Love it.

Since I got a cold brew maker I've just been using the preground coffee. This seemed like a way that maybe I could save money. Though I'm not really sure how much since coffee grounds seem fairly expensive compared to the stuff that's already ground. Maybe if I buy those here they would be cheaper.

Anyway, this worked really well. It was really easy to set up too. Basically you just have to slide the cup for the grounds onto the machine and then you pour some grounds in the top, put the plastic lid on, twist the timer knob, and then push the button. Depending on how much coffee you put in and how fine you want it ground you may need to repeat a few times. Then you just empty the grounds into your coffee maker or into another container for storage.

I guess the question for me is how long it will last; I'll have to update if it suddenly breaks down or anything.

This, like much of what OXO sells, is a work of art. Form and function are joined, fine engineering and aesthetics make this a beautiful addition to your kitchen counter. If you are currently using a blade style coffee grinder, the least you need to know is a conical burr grinder will give you much more consistent grind size. This results in a more consistent cup of coffee, and better control over flavor. Buy freshly roasted beans (no more than a week ago is best) and experiment with settings until you find the one that results in coffee heaven. Life is good.

Love the smell of the fine coffee this makes. My home feels and smells like a fancy coffee shop now. Very well designed and built. Excellent capacity and quality. This is with no doubt a coffee lover must have. Easy to operate.

qAndA.question: Am i the only one uncomfortable seeing that all the reviews are from people who got a free machine?
qAndA.answer: Yes. Amazon is overrun these days by fake reviews and it's only slightly better if they disclose they received a free product in exchange (as I do think a reviewer's time is worth something). I am now in the habit of going to a 3rd party, like Fakespot, to see if fake reviews are influencing overall rating of product… see more

qAndA.question: Is anyone having good results for both french press and espresso grind settings? aeropress?
qAndA.answer: I have not done a fine espresso grind yet, but for French Press, Aeropress, and V60 this has been a home run.

qAndA.question: How loud is this grinder?
qAndA.answer: It's quieter than my previous burr grinder from Capresso and much quieter than any of my blade grinders. I'm sorry I can't be more specific than that.

qAndA.question: How is static cling on the grinder body or grounds container? (my cuisinart and bodum both generate static.) is there any cord storage?
qAndA.answer:
I have had this grinder for about 2 weeks, but so far so good. No static cling, as advertised. No cord storage.
I've owned half a dozen grinders over past 30 years. Eventually they all gum up from oil in coffee beans. Therefore, it is critical to be able to disable the grinder to clean the burr. The Oxo allows for c… see more

qAndA.question: Has anyone tried this for Turkish coffee?
qAndA.answer: It should work well for Turkish, I use the 3 setting for espresso as 1 and 2 are too fine.

qAndA.question: How hard is this to clean?
qAndA.answer: Actually pretty easy. The top bean holder and the bottom ground bean receptacle both come out very easily to be washed. Inside the unit, the burr grinder comes out by simply pulling up a lever and lifting out. You'll need a small brush to dust off the coffee particles. Only part left is the base (the electronics and ma… see more

qAndA.question: Can I grind directly into a portafilter?
qAndA.answer: Probably it you hold it. Not much room but it does exit the grinder away from the back.
